2024-11-05 - UNLV: 93 vs Alabama State: 79

LAS VEGAS -- — Jeremiah Cherry scored 24 points as UNLV beat Alabama State 93-79 on Monday. Cherry also added 11 rebounds for the Rebels. Dedan Thomas Jr. added 17 points while shooting 3 for 9 (1 for 3 from 3-point range) and 10 of 11 from the free-throw line while they also had seven assists. Julian Rishwain had 13 points and finished 4 of 8 from 3-point range. The Hornets were led in scoring by Amarr Knox, who finished with 19 points, five assists and two steals. Antonio Madlock added 14 points and four assists for Alabama State. Micah Octave had 13 points. UNLV led Alabama State 46-41 at the half, with Cherry (12 points) its high scorer before the break. UNLV outscored Alabama State by nine points over the final half, while Cherry led the way with a team-high 12 second-half points. ------ The Associated Press created this story using technology provided by Data Skrive and data from Sportradar.

2024-11-10 - LSU: 74 vs Alabama State: 61

BATON ROUGE, La. -- — Cam Carter and Jordan Sears each scored 18 second-half points Sunday and LSU used a 34-11 second-half run to erase a double-double deficit and beat Alabama State 74-61. Carter, a Kansas State transfer, made 4 of 5 from 3-point range and finished with 21 points. Sears, who was scoreless on 0-for-4 shooting in the first half, made 9 of 11 from the free-throw line and finished with five assists and two steals. Richmond transfer Dji Bailey added 15 points, seven rebounds and four assists for LSU (2-0). Antonio ‘TJ’ Madlock scored 21 points, Amarr Knox added 20 and CJ Hines finished with 13 points for Alabama State (0-2). The Hornets outrebounded LSU 24-15 and outscored the Tigers 16-8 in the paint before intermission. LSU, which made just 8 of 25 (32%) from the field, 3 of 13 (23%) from 3-point range and 7 of 14 from the free-throw line in the first half and went into the break trailing 32-26, made 11 of 15 from the field to close the game. Sears scored 15 points and Carter added 11 in the final 12-plus minutes as the Tigers turned a 10-point deficit into a 72-59 lead when Carter hit a 3-pointer with 1:22 to play. Daimion Collins threw down a dunk and then a steal by Sears led to a fast-break basket by Robert Miller III to cap a 9-0 run that gave LSU a one-point lead with 13:16 to play. Madlock answered 20 seconds later with a layup and added five more points in a 14-3 spurt that gave Alabama State a 10-point lead with 12:30 to play. The Tigers beat Alabama State in the only other meeting between the programs 74-56 last season. The Hornets led at halftime in that game as well. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP collegebasketball: and

2024-11-28 - Cincinnati: 77 vs Alabama State: 59

CINCINNATI -- — Simas Lukosius scored 16 points to lead No. 16 Cincinnati to a 77-59 win over Alabama State on Wednesday night. Jizzle James had 13 points and five assists for the Bearcats who have started 6-0 for the second time in coach Wes Miller's four seasons. Dillon Mitchell, who had 14 points and 11 rebounds in the Bearcats' win at Georgia Tech on Saturday, scored 10 points with eight boards before leaving the game with an injury with 11 minutes remaining. Amarr Knox scored 17 of his 24 points in the first half for Alabama State (3-4) while Jalen Keago added 12 points for the Hornets. Lukosius hit a pair of 3-pointers to help the Bearcats build an early 10-2 lead. Cincinnati led 46-33 at halftime and the Bearcats' defense helped them pull away in the second half as Alabama State went 7 for 30 from 3-point range. Takeaways Alabama State: The Hornets faced a ranked opponent for the first time since the 2021 season when they had consecutive losses to No. 16 Texas and No. 25 Texas Tech. Cincinnati: Last year's leading scorer Dan Skillings Jr. could return soon after being injured in the season opener. Skillings had minor surgery on his knee but began shooting and doing light work in practice this week. Key moment TJ Madlock missed a wide open dunk that would have cut Alabama State's deficit to six points late in the first half. Mitchell responded with six straight points to extend the Bearcats' lead to 39-25. Key stat Connor Hickman, who transferred to Cincinnati after three seasons at Bradley, needed four points to reach 1,000 for his career. He only played 24 minutes due to an injury in the first half and didn't score. Up next Alabama State plays at SMU on Tuesday night, and Cincinnati plays at Villanova also on Tuesday night. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. 2024-12-31 - Missouri: 82 vs Alabama State: 65

COLUMBIA, Mo. -- — Tamar Bates scored 16 points, Mark Mitchell added 14 and Missouri closes its nonconference schedule with an 82-65 win over Alabama State on Monday. Trent Pierce and Tony Perkins added 12 points apiece as 10 players played at least 10 minutes in the Tigers' last warmup before Southeastern Conference play begins on Saturday. D'Ante Bass scored 14 points for the Hornets (4-9) and Tyler Mack had 11. Pierce drilled a 3-pointer 19 seconds into the game and Missouri never trailed. Marques Warrick hit a 3-pointer to put the Tigers up 22-11 midway through the first half and a couple minutes later they pulled away, going up 42-22 when T.O. Barrett made three free throws. The Hornets had the last basket of the half to trail 42-24. Missouri had a balanced attack and shot 50% while the Hornets shot 29% and made just one free throw. Bates had two quick baskets as Missouri scored the first six points of the second half and the Hornets never got closer than 18 until the last minute. Alabama State was 15 of 30 from the floor in the second half. Exactly 37 years ago Missouri beat Alabama State 129-64 in their only other meeting. The 129 points still stands as the Tigers' scoring record and the 65-point margin of victory is now the fourth largest. Missouri starts SEC play at No. 2 Auburn on Saturday. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2025-03-18 - Alabama State: 70 vs St. Francis (PA): 68

DAYTON, Ohio -- — Amarr Knox's layup with a second left lifted Alabama State to its first NCAA Tournament win Tuesday night, 70-68 over Saint Francis (PA) in a matchup of No. 16 seeds at the First Four. Knox scored 16 points to help the Hornets (20-15) earn a date with No. 1 overall seed Auburn on Thursday in a South Region game at Lexington, Kentucky. “You just said it: March Madness,” said Alabama State coach Tony Madlock. “I think I’ve talked about this with all of the media, that all of our games end just like this, either we have to get a bucket or we have to get a stop. Fortunately enough we were able to get a bucket to finish this game off.” After forcing a turnover in the final seconds, Alabama State had the ball out of bounds under its own basket. With the score tied, Micah Simpson threw a long pass nearly the length of the court toward a scrum of players in the lane at the other end — not unlike a Hail Mary in football. The ball deflected off a teammate and right into Knox's hands near the rim, giving him a simple layup for the winning points. “We put our tallest athletic person to go get the ball,” Knox said. “And fortunately everybody tipped the ball, and it landed to me, and I got the rebound and made the layup.” Saint Francis chose not to pressure Simpson on the inbounds pass. Officials determined there was 1 second remaining after Knox’s layup, but a desperation heave by the Red Flash fell short. Saint Francis, which lost its season opener at Dayton, made an unlikely return to the arena as the 19th team to enter the NCAA Tournament with a losing record. Those teams are now 0-19. “These guys for 34 games left it all out on the court for us,” coach Rob Krimmel said. “I know that they’re disappointed. That’s the thing that I love about them. They’re champions, and nothing can take that away from our group.” Alabama State is making its fifth NCAA Tournament appearance. Micah Octave’s steal and dunk put the Hornets ahead by four with 1:36 left, but the Red Flash tied the score at 68 on Chris Moncrief’s 3-pointer with 40 seconds remaining. Juan Cranford Jr., playing in his hometown, led Saint Francis with 18 points. Valentino Pinedo scored 17 for the Red Flash (16-18), who squandered a nine-point lead. Saint Francis shot 59% and went 6 of 12 from 3-point range to take a 39-34 lead into halftime. “We’ve been in that moment, that situation, a few times this year, and we knew we just had to come out and play ball,” Knox said. “We stayed positive. We knew as soon as the next half started that we would come out, fly around, play aggressive and just do whatever it takes to win the game.” The Red Flash committed 15 turnovers, leading to 26 points for the Hornets. “We turned the ball over too many times,” Cranford said. “We turned the ball over that many times, you can’t expect to come out with a good outcome.” Following a missed shot by Knox down the stretch, TJ Madlock was fouled scrambling for the rebound. He missed the front end of a 1-and-1, but Saint Francis committed a turnover at the other end, setting up the dramatic finish. Up next: Auburn. “I’ll figure that all out tonight,” Tony Madlock said. “We’re going to enjoy this tonight. We’re going to have this bus ride, I guess a couple hours down the road to play in Lexington at Rupp Arena. How can you beat that?” Seeing red Things didn’t start out so well for Saint Francis. During player introductions, the officials asked several Red Flash players to remove their black undershirts. By rule, undershirts must be the same color as the jersey. Saint Francis wore red. Charity stripe Alabama State didn’t attempt a free throw until there was 5:09 remaining. The Hornets went 1 of 4 from the line. ------ AP March Madness bracket: and coverage: Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here.
profile_summary:
Alabama State enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 16-seed with a 20-16 record — a résumé built almost entirely within the SWAC, with a brutal non-conference slate that exposed real limitations against high-major competition. Against power-conference opponents this season, the Hornets went 0-7, losing to UNLV (93-79), LSU (74-61), Cincinnati (77-59), SMU (101-72), Southern Miss (81-64), Missouri (82-65), and Akron (97-78) — none of those games were particularly close in the final minutes, and the 29-point loss to SMU and the 17-point loss to Missouri illustrated a significant talent gap when facing elite rosters. That said, Alabama State won the SWAC Tournament to earn their automatic bid, beating Texas Southern (84-79), Grambling (64-62), Jackson State (60-56), and St. Francis PA (70-68 in the First Four) in succession — a four-game postseason run that speaks to genuine toughness and the ability to win when it matters most. Their final five meaningful games show a team playing its best basketball of the season: wins over Alabama A&M (94-52), Grambling (59-47), and then four consecutive tournament wins, capped by one of the most dramatic finishes of the First Four — Amarr Knox catching a deflected full-court pass and converting a layup with one second remaining to defeat St. Francis PA.

Alabama State is defined by clutch, grind-it-out basketball and an almost pathological comfort in close games — they have won repeatedly on buzzer-beaters, late free throws, and last-second stops, while also dropping gut-punch losses the same way, such as the Delaware State collapse (83-80) and the Bethune-Cookman losses. Their identity runs through Amarr Knox, who erupted for a career-high 32 points against Florida A&M, hit the winning layup against St. Francis, and has been their most consistent closer all season, and CJ Hines, who provides secondary scoring punch and handles in crunch time. Antonio Madlock contributes with double-double production and veteran poise as the coach's son, while Micah Simpson offers a three-point threat off the bench. The Hornets are scrappy and resilient rather than dominant — they rarely blow teams out and almost never build comfortable leads, but they compete hard to the final buzzer. Defensively, they capitalize on opponent turnovers (St. Francis committed 15, leading to 26 Alabama State points), and they play with evident energy on neutral sites, going deep in the SWAC Tournament in Atlanta before advancing in Dayton. However, there is no evidence they can compete with the size, depth, or athleticism of a No. 1 seed like Auburn — who already dismantled far more talented opponents all season — and their non-conference record against high-major programs was an unambiguous 0-7. **Alabama State's realistic tournament ceiling is a first-round exit against Auburn**: they have earned enormous credit for winning the First Four in iconic fashion, but a 16-seed facing the No. 1 overall seed with this non-conference profile has almost no path to an upset, and the Hornets' tendency to play from behind against elite competition will be punished at a level they have not come close to handling all year.

2025-03-18 - Alabama State: 70 vs St. Francis (PA): 68

DAYTON, Ohio -- — Amarr Knox's layup with a second left lifted Alabama State to its first NCAA Tournament win Tuesday night, 70-68 over Saint Francis (PA) in a matchup of No. 16 seeds at the First Four. Knox scored 16 points to help the Hornets (20-15) earn a date with No. 1 overall seed Auburn on Thursday in a South Region game at Lexington, Kentucky. “You just said it: March Madness,” said Alabama State coach Tony Madlock. “I think I’ve talked about this with all of the media, that all of our games end just like this, either we have to get a bucket or we have to get a stop. Fortunately enough we were able to get a bucket to finish this game off.” After forcing a turnover in the final seconds, Alabama State had the ball out of bounds under its own basket. With the score tied, Micah Simpson threw a long pass nearly the length of the court toward a scrum of players in the lane at the other end — not unlike a Hail Mary in football. The ball deflected off a teammate and right into Knox's hands near the rim, giving him a simple layup for the winning points. “We put our tallest athletic person to go get the ball,” Knox said. “And fortunately everybody tipped the ball, and it landed to me, and I got the rebound and made the layup.” Saint Francis chose not to pressure Simpson on the inbounds pass. Officials determined there was 1 second remaining after Knox’s layup, but a desperation heave by the Red Flash fell short. Saint Francis, which lost its season opener at Dayton, made an unlikely return to the arena as the 19th team to enter the NCAA Tournament with a losing record. Those teams are now 0-19. “These guys for 34 games left it all out on the court for us,” coach Rob Krimmel said. “I know that they’re disappointed. That’s the thing that I love about them. They’re champions, and nothing can take that away from our group.” Alabama State is making its fifth NCAA Tournament appearance. Micah Octave’s steal and dunk put the Hornets ahead by four with 1:36 left, but the Red Flash tied the score at 68 on Chris Moncrief’s 3-pointer with 40 seconds remaining. Juan Cranford Jr., playing in his hometown, led Saint Francis with 18 points. Valentino Pinedo scored 17 for the Red Flash (16-18), who squandered a nine-point lead. Saint Francis shot 59% and went 6 of 12 from 3-point range to take a 39-34 lead into halftime. “We’ve been in that moment, that situation, a few times this year, and we knew we just had to come out and play ball,” Knox said. “We stayed positive. We knew as soon as the next half started that we would come out, fly around, play aggressive and just do whatever it takes to win the game.” The Red Flash committed 15 turnovers, leading to 26 points for the Hornets. “We turned the ball over too many times,” Cranford said. “We turned the ball over that many times, you can’t expect to come out with a good outcome.” Following a missed shot by Knox down the stretch, TJ Madlock was fouled scrambling for the rebound. He missed the front end of a 1-and-1, but Saint Francis committed a turnover at the other end, setting up the dramatic finish. Up next: Auburn. “I’ll figure that all out tonight,” Tony Madlock said. “We’re going to enjoy this tonight. We’re going to have this bus ride, I guess a couple hours down the road to play in Lexington at Rupp Arena. How can you beat that?” Seeing red Things didn’t start out so well for Saint Francis. During player introductions, the officials asked several Red Flash players to remove their black undershirts. By rule, undershirts must be the same color as the jersey. Saint Francis wore red. Charity stripe Alabama State didn’t attempt a free throw until there was 5:09 remaining. The Hornets went 1 of 4 from the line. ------ AP March Madness bracket: and coverage: Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here.
profile_summary: St. Francis (PA) enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 16-seed with a 16-18 record — a losing mark that tells most of the story, though context matters. The Red Flash were thoroughly outclassed in non-conference play, suffering blowout losses to Power Conference programs including Dayton (87-57), Clemson (88-62), Penn State (92-62), and Maryland (111-57), going 0-4 against that tier of competition and never truly competing in those contests. Their season was largely a Northeast Conference survival act, and even there they struggled early, falling to 5-11 before finding some footing. Heading into the tournament, St. Francis won five of their final seven games by the close of the regular season, including a gutsy overtime win at Le Moyne behind Chris Moncrief's 25-point effort, an overtime home win over Chicago State with Riley Parker pouring in 22, and a victory over Wagner in the conference tournament before stunning Central Connecticut — the NEC's dominant team at 19-6 — 46-43 in what appeared to be the conference championship to earn the automatic bid. That late-season surge demonstrated genuine resilience, but the margins were razor-thin throughout, reflecting a team that wins ugly rather than dominates. St. Francis is defined by late-game drama: they have been involved in an extraordinary number of games decided by a possession or two — winning on a free throw with a second left against Campbell, losing on a bank shot in double overtime to Wagner, and nearly pulling off a first-round upset before losing 70-68 on a full-court deflection layup with one second remaining against Alabama State in the First Four. The offensive engine runs through Riley Parker, who has been the team's most consistent performer down the stretch, and Valentino Pinedo, who scored 17 in the First Four game and has been a reliable double-figure presence; Juan Cranford Jr. led the team with 18 points in Dayton in his hometown but the Red Flash ultimately committed 15 turnovers — a recurring vulnerability — that Alabama State converted into 26 points, proving that error-prone ball security remains a fatal flaw under pressure. St. Francis has no wins against ranked opponents and was outscored by a combined 116 points across their four games against Power Conference programs, offering zero evidence they can compete with elite competition. Their tournament ceiling was the First Four, and they have now been eliminated — a predictable outcome for a team whose identity, while admirably scrappy and resilient, is built on surviving close games in a weak mid-major conference rather than any discernible advantage that translates to the national stage.

2025-03-19 - San Diego State: 68 vs North Carolina: 95

DAYTON, Ohio -- — RJ Davis and his North Carolina teammates certainly looked as though they belonged in the NCAA Tournament on Tuesday night. Davis scored 26 points and shot 6 of 6 from 3-point range to help the Tar Heels silence some skeptics with a dominant 95-68 victory over San Diego State in their First Four matchup. UNC was a controversial NCAA selection on Sunday, but the Tar Heels played like a team with something to prove. “We know we deserved to be here,” junior guard Seth Trimble said. North Carolina coach Hubert Davis said his players were simply focused on the task at hand. “I don’t think it was a weight on us to try to get into the NCAA Tournament,” he said. “My communication with them is to focus on us. It’s not the noise on the outside in terms of comments and critics. Focusing on our preparation, our practice and our play.” Some hot shooting from long range didn't hurt. RJ Davis' six 3-pointers tied Caleb Love's program record for an NCAA Tournament game. Love had six against UCLA in 2022. Hubert Davis went 5 for 5 from deep against Eastern Michigan in 1991. “As a head coach, I don’t know what it looks like to exist without him on the sideline and on the floor, and I don’t want to think about it,” Hubert Davis said about RJ Davis. The 14 made 3-pointers were the most for North Carolina in an NCAA Tournament game. UNC drained 13 against Marquette in 2022. “I know that we hit a record number of 3s here, but made shots come and go,” Hubert Davis said. “The thing I was most proud of is we were getting steals and deflections, and I thought our defense was real good.” Trimble had 16 points for the Tar Heels in a matchup of No. 11 seeds. They advanced to play No. 6 seed Mississippi in a South Region game Friday in Milwaukee. Nick Boyd and Wayne McKinney III each scored 12 for the Aztecs (21-10). North Carolina shot 61% in the first half and went 7 of 9 from 3-point range. RJ Davis' long 3 just before the halftime buzzer gave the Tar Heels their largest lead to that point, 47-23. “I think we did a good job of sticking to our game plan and playing Carolina basketball,” he said. “We got out in transition, we shared the ball.” North Carolina (23-13) seemed a long shot to make the tournament with a 1-12 record in Quadrant 1 games, but was chosen Sunday thanks to a strong nonconference schedule and other metrics. The Tar Heels were out to show the world they belonged, and San Diego State took the brunt of it. “Obviously, we wish we’d have given them more of a game,” Aztecs coach Brian Dutcher said. “We hang our hat on our defense, and we couldn’t get stops. We knew we had to play in the 70s to have a chance, and they were up in the 90s.” Unstoppable San Diego State led the nation in field goal percentage defense, but had no answer for the Tar Heels. It was the most points the Aztecs allowed all season. The previous high was 80 in a loss to then-No. 3 Gonzaga on Nov. 18. North Carolina shot 52.6% from the field, and 58.3% from 3-point range. “We know who we are on the offensive end,” Trimble said. “We know what we’re capable of. This doesn’t surprise me, what we did tonight. It’s what I expect every single night.” Extra work Despite not knowing whether they were in or out, the Tar Heels practiced on Sunday, hours before the tournament selection show, and prepared to play. “Yeah, we practiced on Sunday and then when we got here, and because of flight delays, this was the only practice that we had,” Hubert Davis said. “But it was a really good 40-minute practice. Look, we’ve had 98 practices and 35 games. We knew what we needed to do.” ------ AP March Madness bracket: and coverage: Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here.
profile_summary:
San Diego State enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as an 11-seed with a 21-10 record — a résumé built on defensive tenacity and hard-fought wins, but undermined by a troubling inability to consistently compete with elite competition. The Aztecs' most impressive moments came early, when they upset then-No. 21 Creighton 71-53 in Las Vegas behind BJ Davis's career-high 18 points and a suffocating defensive effort that forced 33.8% shooting, and when they edged No. 6 Houston 73-70 in overtime on Miles Byrd's two clutch free throws with 13 seconds left in regulation. Against ranked opponents overall, SDSU went a modest 3-5: wins over Creighton, Houston, and Colorado State were offset by losses to No. 3 Gonzaga (80-67), Oregon, UNLV (twice), and a blowout exit at New Mexico. Their final five games told a story of a team grinding to survive rather than surging: they beat Wyoming 72-69, lost to UNLV 74-67 in Las Vegas despite 19 points from Nick Boyd and a monster 15-10-6-4-3 line from Byrd, closed the regular season with a comfortable 80-61 home win over Nevada, and then were bounced in the Mountain West quarterfinals by Boise State 62-52 — a team they had beaten twice during conference play. Their First Four matchup against North Carolina ended in a 95-68 demolition, the most points San Diego State allowed all season, with UNC shooting 52.6% from the field and 58.3% from three; the Aztecs, who led the nation in field goal percentage defense, had no answer whatsoever.

San Diego State's identity is a defensive grind — they win ugly, they win close, and they rely on composure in clutch moments rather than offensive firepower. Wayne McKinney III's buzzer-beating layup in overtime at Air Force and Byrd's steady two-way play (including a 15-point, 10-rebound, 6-assist, 4-steal, 3-block line against UNLV) reflect a roster that competes hard and rarely folds, but the offense is too inconsistent and too dependent on individual nights from Boyd, Byrd, or Magoon Gwath — the 7-foot freshman who flashed genuine upside with a 25-point, 10-rebound career game at Fresno State — to sustain deep tournament runs. The team is notably stronger at home (wins over Houston, Boise State twice, New Mexico, Fresno State twice) and vulnerable on the road and at neutral sites, going 3-5 away from Viejas Arena in conference play. The UNC blowout is the definitive red flag: when elite shooting teams attack them with pace and three-point volume, SDSU's defensive system breaks down completely, and they have no offensive ceiling to compensate. **Verdict: San Diego State has already been eliminated** — their First Four loss to North Carolina ended their 2025 tournament run. Had they advanced, the evidence suggests a team capable of a scrappy second-round upset but not equipped for a Sweet 16 run, given their offensive limitations and demonstrable vulnerability against elite, shot-making opponents.

2024-11-09 - Kansas: 92 vs North Carolina: 89

LAWRENCE, Kan. -- — Hunter Dickinson had 20 points for top-ranked Kansas, which blew a 20-point first-half lead against No. 9 North Carolina before holding on for a 92-89 victory when the Tar Heels’ Elliot Cadeau missed a 3-pointer as time expired Friday night. Zeke Mayo had 21 points and KJ Adams Jr had 14 for the Jayhawks (2-0), who led 49-29 in the first half but trailed 87-83 with 3:28 to go. Dickinson and Mayo responded with a series of baskets to tie the game at 89, and Dickinson’s basket with 1:15 to go and free throw with 12 seconds remaining made it a three-point game. The Tar Heels (1-1) raced up the floor, but Cadeau’s 3 from the wing never had a chance. Seth Trimble scored 19 points to lead North Carolina. RJ Davis had 16 points and Cadeau finished with 12. It was just the 13th matchup of the Tar Heels and Jayhawks, and the first since Kansas rallied from a 16-point deficit to win the 2022 national championship. The only other time they have met on campus was in 1960, when Larry Brown — who would later coach the Jayhawks to the 1988 title — helped the Tar Heels win in Allen Fieldhouse. Kansas made a repeat seem unlikely when it built a 20-point first-half lead. But the Tar Heels trimmed the deficit in the second half, and Jae'Lyn Withers' 3-pointer gave them an 80-79 lead with 7:06 to go. The two bluebloods wrestled it away several other times before Kansas finally put the game away. Takeaways North Carolina stayed alive by getting to the basket and drawing fouls, ultimately going 28 of 31 from the line. Kansas avoided what would have been the biggest blown-lead loss in school history while giving coach Bill Self his 590th win at the school, matching Phog Allen's record. Key moment Dickinson's basket inside with 1:15 left gave Kansas the lead, and the All-American center's free throw forced North Carolina into needing a 3-pointer to tie the game. Key stat 20 — The lead that Kansas had in the first half. And that the Tar Heels overcame in the second. Up next North Carolina plays American next Friday night. The Jayhawks play Michigan State on Tuesday night in Atlanta. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 all season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

Gytis Nemeiksa led Hawaii with 16 points and had 10 rebounds. Akira Jacobs made three 3-pointers and scored 13 points off the bench. Tanner Christensen had 10 points and 10 rebounds and Marcus Green added 10 points for the Rainbow Warriors (4-1). North Carolina never trailed and led by as many as 21. Duke (30-3) will play the winner of the second semifinal between No. 10 Clemson and No. 13 Louisville in the title game. After North Carolina cut a 24-point, second-half deficit to one, Ven-Allen Lubin had two free throws with 4.1 seconds left to potentially give the Tar Heels (22-13) the lead. But he missed the first and had the second made free throw waved off after teammate Jae'Lyn Withers stepped in the lane too early. Knueppel made two free throws with 2.8 seconds left and Lubin missed a 3-pointer at the buzzer. It's the first time since 2001-02 that Duke has beaten North Carolina three times in a season. The Blue Devils swept the Tar Heels in the regular season that year and then beat them in the ACC Tournament quarterfinals en route to winning the national championship. Lubin had 20 points and 10 rebounds for North Carolina. Takeaways North Carolina: The Tar Heels simply don't have the size to match up with the Blue Devils, but showed plenty of heart with the comeback Duke: The Blue Devils showed they have plenty of punch and more than enough defense despite being without Flagg and top reserve Maliq Brown. Key moment Withers stepping the lane too early was a monumental mistake. Key stat UNC started the second half 15 of 24 from the field. Up next Duke will play the winner of No. 10 Clemson-No. 13 Louisville winner in the championship. UNC hopes it has done enough to get an NCAA Tournament berth. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2025-03-19 - San Diego State: 68 vs North Carolina: 95

DAYTON, Ohio -- — RJ Davis and his North Carolina teammates certainly looked as though they belonged in the NCAA Tournament on Tuesday night. Davis scored 26 points and shot 6 of 6 from 3-point range to help the Tar Heels silence some skeptics with a dominant 95-68 victory over San Diego State in their First Four matchup. UNC was a controversial NCAA selection on Sunday, but the Tar Heels played like a team with something to prove. “We know we deserved to be here,” junior guard Seth Trimble said. North Carolina coach Hubert Davis said his players were simply focused on the task at hand. “I don’t think it was a weight on us to try to get into the NCAA Tournament,” he said. “My communication with them is to focus on us. It’s not the noise on the outside in terms of comments and critics. Focusing on our preparation, our practice and our play.” Some hot shooting from long range didn't hurt. RJ Davis' six 3-pointers tied Caleb Love's program record for an NCAA Tournament game. Love had six against UCLA in 2022. Hubert Davis went 5 for 5 from deep against Eastern Michigan in 1991. “As a head coach, I don’t know what it looks like to exist without him on the sideline and on the floor, and I don’t want to think about it,” Hubert Davis said about RJ Davis. The 14 made 3-pointers were the most for North Carolina in an NCAA Tournament game. UNC drained 13 against Marquette in 2022. “I know that we hit a record number of 3s here, but made shots come and go,” Hubert Davis said. “The thing I was most proud of is we were getting steals and deflections, and I thought our defense was real good.” Trimble had 16 points for the Tar Heels in a matchup of No. 11 seeds. They advanced to play No. 6 seed Mississippi in a South Region game Friday in Milwaukee. Nick Boyd and Wayne McKinney III each scored 12 for the Aztecs (21-10). North Carolina shot 61% in the first half and went 7 of 9 from 3-point range. RJ Davis' long 3 just before the halftime buzzer gave the Tar Heels their largest lead to that point, 47-23. “I think we did a good job of sticking to our game plan and playing Carolina basketball,” he said. “We got out in transition, we shared the ball.” North Carolina (23-13) seemed a long shot to make the tournament with a 1-12 record in Quadrant 1 games, but was chosen Sunday thanks to a strong nonconference schedule and other metrics. The Tar Heels were out to show the world they belonged, and San Diego State took the brunt of it. “Obviously, we wish we’d have given them more of a game,” Aztecs coach Brian Dutcher said. “We hang our hat on our defense, and we couldn’t get stops. We knew we had to play in the 70s to have a chance, and they were up in the 90s.” Unstoppable San Diego State led the nation in field goal percentage defense, but had no answer for the Tar Heels. It was the most points the Aztecs allowed all season. The previous high was 80 in a loss to then-No. 3 Gonzaga on Nov. 18. North Carolina shot 52.6% from the field, and 58.3% from 3-point range. “We know who we are on the offensive end,” Trimble said. “We know what we’re capable of. This doesn’t surprise me, what we did tonight. It’s what I expect every single night.” Extra work Despite not knowing whether they were in or out, the Tar Heels practiced on Sunday, hours before the tournament selection show, and prepared to play. “Yeah, we practiced on Sunday and then when we got here, and because of flight delays, this was the only practice that we had,” Hubert Davis said. “But it was a really good 40-minute practice. Look, we’ve had 98 practices and 35 games. We knew what we needed to do.” ------ AP March Madness bracket: and coverage: Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. profile_summary: North Carolina enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as an 11-seed with a 23-14 record — a résumé built on resilience and late-season momentum rather than consistent excellence. The Tar Heels finished the regular season on a six-game winning streak before going 2-1 in the ACC Tournament, including a gutsy 68-59 win over Wake Forest and a near-miraculous comeback against Duke that fell agonizingly short 74-71 when Ven-Allen Lubin missed the front end of a crucial free throw and Jae'Lyn Withers stepped in the lane too early on the ensuing attempt. Their five-game closing stretch tells a compelling story: wins over NC State (97-73), Miami (92-73), Virginia Tech (91-59), and Wake Forest in the ACC Tournament, sandwiched around a narrow 82-69 loss to No. 2 Duke in the regular-season finale — a game in which they trailed by 15 at halftime but showed real fight before Duke pulled away late. Against ranked opponents across the full season, the Tar Heels struggled considerably, going approximately 3-12: their wins came over No. 18 UCLA (76-74 at MSG), No. 21 UCLA adjacent wins, and tournament-tested opponents, while suffering losses to No. 1 Kansas, No. 4 Auburn, No. 10 Alabama, No. 7 Florida, No. 23 Clemson, and Duke three times — a brutal Quadrant 1 record that nearly cost them their tournament bid. The defining identity of this North Carolina team is comeback artistry bordering on addiction: they erased 21-point deficits against Dayton and UCLA, rallied from 24 down against Duke in the ACC semis, and consistently spotted opponents large first-half leads before mounting second-half charges — a pattern that is simultaneously inspiring and deeply concerning against elite tournament competition. The engine of this team is fifth-year senior RJ Davis, who proved his tournament credentials immediately by shooting 6-of-6 from three and dropping 26 points in their First Four demolition of San Diego State (95-68), while freshman Ian Jackson has emerged as a genuine secondary star, scoring 20-plus points in multiple straight games at one point mid-season. Jae'Lyn Withers has been a critical third option down the stretch — he torched Notre Dame for seven 3-pointers in the ACC Tournament opener — and Ven-Allen Lubin provides a physical interior presence with back-to-back double-doubles late in the season. The Tar Heels are notably better at home (strong) and on neutral sites (competitive) than on the road, where they were blown out at Clemson (85-65) and struggled at Pittsburgh, though their MSG win over UCLA and the dominant First Four performance in Dayton suggest they embrace the neutral-site tournament stage. The First Four blowout of San Diego State — a team that led the nation in field-goal percentage defense — was a genuine statement, with North Carolina shooting 52.6% from the field and 58.3% from three, and the locker room energy postgame radiated a team with a chip on its shoulder after being a controversial selection. The realistic ceiling for this North Carolina team is the Sweet 16: Davis and Jackson give them enough individual firepower to knock off a higher seed or two riding momentum, their comeback DNA makes them dangerous in close games, and their neutral-site comfort suits March perfectly — but their chronic first-half holes, shaky free-throw shooting in critical moments, and a 3-12 record against ranked opponents over the full season reveal a team that has not yet demonstrated the sustained forty-minute dominance needed to reach an Elite Eight against genuinely elite competition.

profile_summary:
Mount St. Mary's enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 16-seed with a 23-13 record, a résumé built almost entirely within the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference with very limited success against power-conference competition. Against quality opponents outside the MAAC, the Mountaineers were handled decisively — blowout losses to Maryland (86-52) and Georgetown (79-51) early in the season revealed significant gaps against high-major talent, and a defeat at George Mason further underscored the ceiling. The lone marquee win of the season was a remarkable overtime upset at Miami (78-74) in December, where Mount St. Mary's erased a 10-point halftime deficit by shooting 50% from the field and going 9-of-11 from the free-throw line in overtime — an impressive moment of resilience, though Miami was just 4-8 at the time and struggling badly. Against ranked opponents, the Mountaineers appear to be 0-2 or worse, with no wins over teams receiving significant national recognition, making their tournament résumé thin by any meaningful metric. Recent form, however, tells a more encouraging story: over their final five games in the provided summaries — wins over Marist (62-52 regular season, 62-58 MAAC quarterfinal), Merrimack (57-55), and Iona (63-49) in the conference tournament, sandwiched around a loss at Quinnipiac (70-79) — the Mountaineers have won four of five and are clearly peaking at the right time. The MAAC Tournament run was particularly impressive, as the 6-seed knocked off the 3-seed (Marist), 2-seed (Merrimack), and 4-seed (Iona) in succession, winning three games in three days with gritty, low-scoring defensive performances and clutch free-throw shooting down the stretch.

Stylistically, Mount St. Mary's is a scrappy, resilient team that wins ugly and thrives in close games rather than blowing opponents out — their season is littered with one-and-two possession finishes, including a buzzer-beating three-pointer from Carmelo Pacheco to beat Niagara (84-83) and a come-from-behind overtime win at Miami. They are, however, dangerously inconsistent: a 34-point blowout loss to Quinnipiac (91-57) in January followed by competitive games in both directions illustrates a team that can either show up or completely disappear depending on the night. The offensive engine runs through Dola Adebayo, who routinely delivers 15-20 point, double-double efforts and is their most reliable two-way presence, while Dallas Hobbs, Terrell Ard Jr., Jedy Cordilia, and Carmelo Pacheco provide complementary scoring that can be streaky from three. Ard is particularly dangerous as a physical, attacking guard who shoots well from the free-throw line and creates off the dribble. Location-wise, the Mountaineers were reasonably competent at home but struggled notably on the road against better competition, and their neutral-site MAAC Tournament performance — three straight wins in Atlantic City — is the most encouraging sign entering the NCAA field. Nevertheless, as a 16-seed facing an opponent with a dramatically higher talent ceiling, Mount St. Mary's realistic tournament ceiling is a first-round exit; they are a gritty, well-coached mid-major that earned their bid and will compete, but lack the athleticism, depth, and big-game résumé required to pull off one of college basketball's rarest upsets.

The rest of the Longhorns shot a combined 7 of 29 (24.1%) from the floor. Takeaways Ohio State: The Buckeyes built a 15-point lead in the first half after opening the game by shooting 50% (10 of 20) from the floor, including 9 of 12 from 3-point range. Texas: The Longhorns had won 21 of their previous 22 season openers before Monday’s loss. Key moment After the Longhorns pulled within four early in the second half, Ohio State’s Evan Mahaffey snatched a rebound off the defensive glass and converted in transition with a layup at the other end. The bucket triggered a 9-3 run that instilled confidence in the Buckeyes, who controlled the pace after rebuilding a 49-39 lead. profile_summary: Texas enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as an 11-seed with a 19-16 record — a résumé built almost entirely on survival rather than dominance, and one that reflects the brutal reality of a first-year SEC schedule that included early-season gauntlets against Auburn, Tennessee, Florida, and Alabama. Against ranked opponents, the Longhorns went a modest 4-11: notable wins include a come-from-behind 70-69 home victory over #13 Texas A&M (erasing a 22-point second-half deficit), an 82-78 upset of #15 Kentucky, a 61-53 win over #22 Missouri, and a 77-73 road win at Oklahoma when the Sooners were ranked — but the losses include beatdowns from #2 Auburn (87-82), #1 Tennessee (74-70), #5 Florida (84-60), #2 Alabama (103-80), and #23 Ole Miss (72-69), painting the picture of a team that is competitive but not elite against top-tier competition. Their final five games tell a story of maddening inconsistency: a gutty overtime win at #25 Mississippi State (87-82), a home loss to Oklahoma in the regular season finale (76-72), then three straight tournament wins over Vanderbilt (79-72), Texas A&M in double overtime (94-88), and a quarterfinal loss to #8 Tennessee (83-72) — playing their third game in three days — leaving them 3-1 in Nashville with momentum that is real but earned against an exhausted schedule. In terms of style, Texas is a comeback team that thrives in chaos: they are rarely dominant wire-to-wire and have shown a tendency to spot opponents large leads before mounting scrappy, frenetic rallies, which is both their greatest strength and most alarming vulnerability. The engine of everything is freshman guard Tre Johnson, who is playing at a genuinely spectacular level — he set a program freshman record with 39 points at Arkansas, had 30 against Texas A&M in the regular season comeback, and has been the team's closer in multiple pressure moments; however, he has also gone quiet in critical stretches, including late against Tennessee twice and in a poor shooting night against Syracuse early in the year. Arthur Kaluma (34 points vs. Auburn, consistent double-doubles) and Tramon Mark (24 points vs. Mississippi State, 19 vs. Vanderbilt in the SEC Tournament) provide important secondary firepower, though Kaluma has been hampered by a left knee issue that caused him to miss games in February — his availability and health entering the tournament must be monitored closely. Texas is notably stronger on neutral courts than on the road: they went 5-1 at neutral sites (winning the UKG Legends Classic and going 3-1 in Nashville) compared to a shaky road record that includes blowout losses at Florida and South Carolina, suggesting the neutral NCAA Tournament setting may actually suit them. The Longhorns carry a scrappy, never-quit identity — the A&M double-overtime win on a Johnson go-ahead three and Shedrick's buzzer-forcing dunk in OT1 is a defining moment — but they are also collapse-prone and give up big leads and absorb big runs with alarming regularity, which could be fatal against a disciplined tournament opponent. **Verdict:** Texas is a dangerous but flawed 11-seed — capable of pulling off a first-round upset on the strength of Johnson's star power and their resilient comeback identity, but unlikely to advance deep into the bracket given their inconsistency against elite competition, ongoing injury concerns, and a tendency to wilt in the final minutes of close games; a realistic ceiling here is the Round of 32, with a Sweet 16 appearance possible only if Johnson is playing at his peak and Kaluma is healthy.

profile_summary: Xavier enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as an 11-seed with a 22-12 record — a résumé that reads as genuinely competitive within a strong Big East but defined by an uneven first half and a spectacular late surge. Against ranked opponents, the Musketeers went 4-7: quality wins include a road victory at then-No. 7 Marquette (59-57), a home win over No. 19 UConn (76-72), and a regular-season win over No. 22 South Carolina (75-66), while losses came to Michigan, Cincinnati, UConn (in overtime), Marquette (twice), and St. John's (twice) — a mixed but respectable body of evidence against elite competition. Xavier's recent form is the most compelling part of their case: they won seven straight to close the regular season, with wins over Creighton (83-61), Butler (91-78), and Providence (76-68) by comfortable margins before falling 89-87 to Marquette in the Big East Tournament quarterfinals on Ryan Conwell's career-high 38-point performance — a game they led by 14 in the second half before collapsing down the stretch, a recurring vulnerability that cannot be ignored. Zach Freemantle is the team's engine, a bruising presence who returned from a knee injury suffered in December and has been exceptional lately, posting 23, 24, and 25 points in the final three regular-season games; his ability to score in the paint and on the glass gives Xavier a legitimate interior weapon at the tournament level. The Musketeers play a multi-layered offensive style — capable of exploding from three (11-of-23 in the Big East Tournament), grinding through free throws, and generating points in the paint — but they are dangerously collapse-prone, having blown double-digit leads against both St. John's (lost in OT after leading by 16) and Marquette in the Big East quarterfinals. Locationally, Xavier is notably stronger at home (where they beat UConn and Marquette during their seven-game streak) and has struggled on the road and at neutral sites, going just 1-4 away from Cincinnati against ranked opponents. The Musketeers carry the energy of a team that has found its identity late — Conwell's clutch scoring, Freemantle's interior dominance, and Dailyn Swain's versatile playmaking give them legitimate star power — but their tendency to surrender large leads and accumulate turnovers under pressure (19 against Michigan, a near-collapse against South Carolina State) suggests a team that can beat anyone on a given night and also beat itself. **Verdict: Xavier is a dangerous first-round opponent and a realistic Sweet 16 threat — their late-season momentum, balanced scoring, and ranked-game experience make them capable of a second-round upset, but their lead-protection issues and road/neutral-site inconsistency make a run beyond the Sweet 16 a significant ask.**

The Cardinals are now 32-12 all-time against the Eagles. The game was the first meeting between the schools since the second round of the 2011 NCAA Tournament. The Volunteers (2-0), who shot 57%, outrebounded the Cardinals 40-26 (28 defensively) and outscored them 40-10 in the paint in the first meeting between the schools since 2018. Tennessee led 10-0 after five minutes and several times by at least 20 points, pulling away for the last time after Louisville (1-1) closed within 47-38 early in the second half. Zeigler made 7 of 13 from the field, including 4 of 7 from beyond the arc. Lanier went 7-of-15 shooting and 3 of 6 from long range as Tennessee made 10 of 19 (53%) on 3s. Reyne Smith came off the bench to score 18 points for the Cardinals, who shot 16 of 60 for the game. That included just 10 of 39 from beyond the arc (26%). Takeaways Tennessee: The Volunteers showed their quickness and athleticism throughout on both ends, going hard to the rim on offense and sealing off the lane defensively. They were sometimes ragged in committing 20 turnovers, but that led to just 12 points thanks to the Cardinals' errors. Louisville: The Cardinals initially struggled controlling the ball, and then it was getting off a shot against the Vols' defense. That left them firing from long range, which often resulted in misses other than the one second-half stretch in which they closed within single digits. SOUTH BEND, Ind. -- — Chucky Hepburn scored 16 points with six assists, James Scott had his fourth double-double of the season and Louisville beat Notre Dame 75-60 on Sunday night to snap a four-game skid in the series. After the game, Notre Dame coach Micah Shrewsberry got emotional, repeatedly defending his team and saying the Irish would turn things around. “I understand a lot of people have quit on us," the coach said. “... If you hate me, absolutely, man. Great. If you think I (stink). If you think I can’t coach, I’m with you, man, good. Good for you because you’re allowed to have opinions.” Shrewsberry said his team, which lost for the fourth time in five games, has not and will not quit. “Don’t give up on these kids, man,” the coach said. "What have they done for people to give up on them? I know if you’re not with us because we’re losing, you don’t want to come watch us, fine. Fine. But do it because of me, then, not these kids. They don’t deserve that. "I don’t care about anybody else’s opinion. I know who I am. I know I can coach basketball. I know I’m turning this program around. He said the game was attended by more Louisville fans than Notre Dame fans and called that embarrassing for him. “I got us in this predicament,” Shrewsberry said. “But don’t come back when we’re winning.” Moments later, he knocked a microphone away and stormed out of the interview room. 2025-03-16 - Duke: 73 vs Louisville: 62
profile_summary: Louisville enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as an 8-seed with a 27-8 record — a résumé that dramatically outpaces expectations for a program that went 8-24 just one season ago under a completely overhauled roster. Against ranked opponents, the Cardinals went 4-7: notable wins include a dominant 89-61 demolition of then-No. 14 Indiana in the Battle 4 Atlantis (scoring 52 second-half points at 66.7% shooting), a commanding 98-73 road win over No. 25 SMU, and victories over North Carolina and Clemson in the ACC Tournament; losses came against No. 12 Tennessee (by 22), No. 23 Ole Miss (by 23), No. 9 Duke (twice — once in December by 11 and again in the ACC Championship 73-62), and No. 5 Kentucky (by 8). Over their final five games, Louisville went 4-1: a 85-68 win over California, a 68-48 defensive shutdown of Stanford to close the regular season, then a stunning buzzer-beater comeback from 15 down to beat Stanford 75-73 in the ACC quarterfinals, a 76-73 semifinal win over No. 10 Clemson, and a 73-62 loss to No. 1 Duke in the ACC Championship — a game in which they were without key contributor Reyne Smith (ankle). That final stretch reveals both the Cardinals' ceiling and their vulnerability: capable of dramatic, resilient performances against quality opposition, but ultimately unable to close against truly elite competition. Louisville's style is built around guard play, perimeter shooting, and relentless pressure defense — they regularly force 20-plus turnovers per game and convert them into transition points, and they shoot a high volume of threes, with Smith (100 3-pointers this season, a program-era record), Chucky Hepburn, and Terrence Edwards Jr. capable of getting scorching hot on any given night. Hepburn is the unquestioned engine: the Wisconsin transfer posted a career-high 37 points against Pitt, delivered a buzzer-beating putback jumper to stun Stanford in the ACC quarterfinals, and has repeatedly delivered in clutch moments, though he can be streaky from the field and the Cardinals are noticeably diminished when he struggles. Edwards has emerged as a legitimate star, scoring a career-high 35 against California and providing playmaking (10 assists vs. Miami) alongside scoring; Hadley provides a physical interior presence with multiple double-doubles; and Smith, when healthy, is one of the ACC's elite perimeter weapons. However, Smith's ankle injury is a legitimate concern — Louisville was a demonstrably different team without him, struggling with chemistry in ACC Tournament play and failing to cover the offensive void. The Cardinals carry genuine big-game experience: they survived a near-collapse against Stanford, gutted out a narrow overtime win over West Virginia, and beat Clemson twice — but they have also been blown out by Tennessee and Ole Miss, collapsed at Georgia Tech after leading by 13, and needed a career performance from Hepburn to hold off a struggling Virginia Tech team late in February. Louisville is 9-3 in road and neutral-site games, which is genuinely impressive and suggests they will not be intimidated by the tournament environment; their nine road wins are a program highlight and their neutral-site record (Battle 4 Atlantis, ACC Tournament) reflects a team that rises in high-stakes moments. First-year coach Pat Kelsey has instilled a confident, competitive identity in a program that was a bottom-feeder one year ago, and this team carries itself with resilience — they do not quit, as evidenced by the Stanford comeback and multiple second-half surges — but they are also turnover-prone against elite pressure defenses and can go cold from three for extended stretches, as seen against Tennessee and Duke. **Tournament ceiling: Sweet 16.** Louisville is dangerous enough as an 8-seed to knock off a 1-seed — their perimeter firepower, turnover-forcing defense, and Hepburn's clutch gene make them a legitimate threat in any single game — but their inability to sustain performance against top-15 competition, Smith's injury cloud, and a thin bench make a run to the Elite Eight or beyond an unlikely outcome absent a favorable bracket path.

2025-03-15 - St. John's: 82 vs Creighton: 66

NEW YORK -- — Regular-season champs. A tournament title. Pride in the program fully restored. The pied piper of college basketball rebuilds, Rick Pitino has St. John's back atop the Big East. And this time, the nets were coming down. RJ Luis Jr. scored all but two of his 29 points after halftime and No. 6 St. John's made 14 straight shots from the field in the second half to beat Creighton 82-66 on Saturday night for its first Big East Tournament title in 25 years. “Wow, this is incredible just to come from last year to this year and to see the transformation,” Luis said. “Coach P is the mastermind behind all of this. I mean, it’s truly special.” Zuby Ejiofor added 20 points and Kadary Richmond had 12 points and 12 rebounds for the top-seeded Red Storm (30-4), who reached 30 wins for the third time in program history before a roaring hometown crowd at sold-out Madison Square Garden. They earned the conference's automatic bid to the NCAA Tournament for their first trip since 2019, making the 72-year-old Pitino the first coach to take six schools to the Big Dance. The others were Boston University, Providence, Kentucky, Louisville and Iona. “Great win for the city. Great win for our university. You hear it all along that it’s New York’s team, and it truly is,” the Hall of Fame coach said. “As a New Yorker myself, I’m very, very proud that St. John’s has gotten to this level.” Pitino, in his second season with the Johnnies, also became the first coach to win the Big East Tournament at two schools. He’s won three times in his last four seasons in the league, after guiding Louisville to championships in 2009, 2012 and 2013. “I saved the best for last,” Pitino announced to loud cheers from the crowd of 19,812, pausing to remove falling confetti from his lips during a postgame interview on the court. Luis, the Big East Player of the Year, also grabbed 10 rebounds and was selected the tournament's Most Outstanding Player. He was draped in a Dominican Republic flag as fans chanted “MVP! MVP!” after the game. “Just still trying to soak it in, and it’s just crazy how much you can speak things into existence and just watch it all come together,” Luis said. “This has by far been the most emotional, happiest week of my 22 years of existence.” Ejiofor and Richmond made the All-Tournament team. “The three of them have been unstoppable,” Pitino said. Ryan Kalkbrenner scored 15 points for second-seeded Creighton (24-10), which fell to 0-5 in Big East championship games since joining the conference for the 2013-14 season. “It's hard to get to this game, let’s be honest,” coach Greg McDermott said. “We’ve been fortunate to be here quite a few times. Unfortunately, we haven’t been able to finish the job.” When the resurgent Johnnies clinched their first outright regular-season conference championship in 40 years with a victory over Seton Hall at The Garden on March 1, they had already decided not to cut down the nets to celebrate. More work to do. But on this night, players and staff climbed the ladder and snipped their souvenirs. It was the fourth Big East Tournament title for the Johnnies, who made the championship game for the first time since winning the 2000 trophy under Mike Jarvis. The previous two came in the 1980s under Hall of Fame coach Lou Carnesecca, who died Nov. 30 about five weeks shy of his 100th birthday. “To finally get over the hump, it’s really an unbelievable feeling,” Ejiofor said. “I’m so happy to be a part of history.” And after the Red Storm cut down the nets, a message appeared on the giant video screen above center court: “For Looie." “I’m thinking he would be so proud of this team,” said Pitino, who has quickly revived St. John's into a national power again late in his illustrious but checkered career. “Humility is a big part of my life right now. It wasn’t always that way,” he added. “I don’t believe in redemption. I believe in humility.” The drought between Big East Tournament titles for the Johnnies was the longest for any team in league history. “St. John’s didn’t get built by the NIL. St. John’s got built with character of the players," Pitino said. Luis was whistled for his second foul with 7:19 left before halftime and sat out the rest of the half. After falling behind by eight early, St. John’s finally took its first lead at 43-41 with 11:55 remaining when backup big man Vince Iwuchukwu scored left-handed in the post over the 7-foot-1 Kalkbrenner, the four-time Big East Defensive Player of the Year. That came 33 seconds after Ejiofor converted a tying three-point play that began a streak of 14 consecutive made field goals in 7:12 for the Red Storm, giving them a 70-55 lead. They connected on 17 of their final 19 field goal attempts to finish at 72% in the second period (23 for 32). Quite an offensive display for a team that entered the game shooting 45% from floor. “We definitely fed off the crowd, the energy, the atmosphere," Luis said. “It was ridiculous. It was very loud.” By the numbers St. John’s has won nine straight games, and 19 of 20 since the new year. The team finished 21-0 on its home courts, including 12-0 at MSG — the program’s most wins at The Garden since compiling 13 in 1958-59. The last time the Johnnies finished unbeaten at home was the 1931-32 season. Creighton injury Bluejays reserve Fedor Zugic injured his right ankle with 11:23 left in the first half and had to be helped off the court to the locker room. He didn’t return. Key stat Creighton, which entered shooting 74% on free throws, missed six of its first eight from the line and finished 8 for 16. Up next Creighton: Headed to its fifth straight NCAA Tournament when the brackets are revealed Sunday. St. John’s: Hasn’t won an NCAA Tournament game in 25 years. Pitino and the streaking Red Storm seem likely to receive a No. 2 seed Sunday. “We still have a lot to prove. We’re not done,” Ejiofor said. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 all season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and
profile_summary:
Creighton enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 9-seed with a 25-11 record — a résumé that reflects a team capable of genuine excellence but haunted by troubling inconsistency at the worst moments. The Bluejays' best wins are legitimately impressive: an upset of No. 1 Kansas 76-63 in Omaha behind Pop Isaacs' 27-point explosion, a road win at UConn that snapped the Huskies' 28-game home winning streak, and a second win over Marquette 77-67 that briefly made Creighton look like a Big East title contender. Against ranked opponents, Creighton went approximately 6-8, with signature neutral-site losses to San Diego State and Texas A&M in November, road losses to Alabama and St. John's, and back-to-back home losses to UConn and St. John's that ended a nine-game winning streak in February. In the Big East Tournament, the Bluejays beat DePaul and upset No. 3 UConn 71-62 — with Jasen Green and Jamiya Neal combining for 38 points — before getting routed 82-66 by St. John's in the championship game, a loss that exposed their vulnerability when a hot offense goes cold at the free-throw line (8-of-16) against elite opposition. Creighton's final five games produced a 3-2 record: wins over DePaul and Seton Hall by comfortable margins, a bad 22-point blowout loss at Xavier, then the Big East semifinal win over UConn and the championship game defeat — a pattern that perfectly summarizes their season-long identity as a team that can beat anyone but can also lose to anyone.

The engine of this Creighton team is Ryan Kalkbrenner, the 7-foot-1 Big East Defensive Player of the Year who has been dominant all season — posting 35 points and 12 rebounds at Providence, 29 points against Xavier, and 27 with 15 rebounds in the regular-season finale against Butler — and Steven Ashworth, a deadly three-point shooter who hit the game-winning three at Villanova with seven seconds left and erupted for six threes against Marquette. Jamiya Neal has emerged as a genuine third option, and Jasen Green's breakout Big East semifinal performance (8-of-10 from the field, 19 points) adds intrigue entering March. The Bluejays play a high-scoring, three-point-dependent style — they are electric when the threes fall, as evidenced by Ashworth's six-three explosion against Marquette, but painfully flat when they don't, shooting 26.7% from three in the St. John's loss and 28.6% in the regular-season loss to Nebraska. Injury concerns linger: Kalkbrenner missed time with a lower-body injury in early December, took a hit to his right foot late in the St. John's regular-season loss, and reserve Fedor Zugic injured his ankle in the Big East final and did not return. Location-wise, Creighton is strong at home (where they upset Kansas and UConn) but markedly inconsistent on the road and neutral sites, going 0-2 in the Players Era Festival and absorbing ugly losses at Georgetown and Xavier. At their best — Kalkbrenner dominating the post, Ashworth and Neal raining threes, the bench contributing — this team has the talent and big-game experience to reach the Sweet 16, but their three-point volatility, demonstrated vulnerability against physical, aggressive opponents, and tendency to go flat in second halves against elite defenses make a run deeper than the Sweet 16 a difficult case to make. **Ceiling: Sweet 16 — a genuinely dangerous 9-seed capable of pulling a first-round upset, but too streaky and three-point-dependent to be trusted against elite tournament competition beyond that.**

2024-11-09 - Purdue: 72 vs Northern Kentucky: 50

WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind. -- — Fletcher Loyer scored 16 points and Trey Kaufman-Renn had 14 to lead No. 14 Purdue to a 72-50 rout of Northern Kentucky on Friday night. Braden Smith added 11 points and seven assists for the Boilermakers (2-0). Caleb Furst scored eight off the bench. No one reached double figures for the Norse (0-2). Trey Robinson, Sam Vinson and Keeyan Itejere each had eight points. The Boilermakers used a 12-0 spurt to take an 18-4 lead in the opening half. However, a nearly six-minute scoring drought kept Purdue from pulling away early. The Boilermakers settled for a 37-24 halftime lead. In the first minute of the game, Purdue freshman center Daniel Jacobsen, who scored 13 points in the season opener, fell and needed to be helped to the bench. He was able to walk to the locker room and returned to the bench with ice on his shin, but did not play again. Boilermakers coach Matt Painter said Jacobsen sustained a lower leg injury and will have an MRI on Saturday. Takeaways Northern Kentucky: The Norse shot just 30% from the field. They did manage to tie Purdue with 33 rebounds each. Northern Kentucky had a 15-8 edge in offensive boards. Purdue: The Boilermakers did a better job of finishing off an overmatched opponent than they did in a 90-73 victory against Texas A&M Corpus Christi. Purdue’s lead was narrowed to three points late in that game. Purdue was helped by shooting 50% from the field, but was just 9 of 14 at the free-throw line. Key moment Freshman guard Gicarri Harris sank a pull-up jumper in the paint as the shot clock expired to fire up the crowd and give Purdue a 60-40 lead. That started an 8-0 run. Key Stat Loyer shot 4 of 5 from 3-point range as Purdue made 9 of 22 attempts from long range. Northern Kentucky went 5 for 23, with two of those makes coming late in the game. Up next Northern Kentucky: Will host Nicholls on Thursday. Purdue: Will host Yale on Monday. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 all season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2024-11-12 - Purdue: 92 vs Yale: 84

WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind. -- — Braden Smith finished with 22 points, nine rebounds and six assists Monday night and Trey Kaufman-Renn added 17 points to lead No. 13 Purdue past Yale 92-84. The Boilermakers (3-0) extended their home winning streak to 21, tying the third-longest in Mackey Arena history. They've also won 24 consecutive November games and still have not lost a regular-season non-conference game since December 2020. John Poulakidas scored 23 points and made five 3-pointers to lead Yale (1-2). Samson Aletan had a career high 14 points and seven rebounds for the defending Ivy League champs. The Boilermakers student section also was on its best behavior Monday after university officials threatened to remove anyone who repeated Friday's chant about firing football coach Ryan Walters. Takeaways Yale: The Bulldogs managed to withstand Purdue's size and speed, but the perimeter struggles were costly. Eventually, Yale ran out of gas. But this is a team that could win another conference crown. Purdue: Coach Matt Painter's squad continues to dominate the season's first month, even against potential NCAA Tournament teams. The Boilermakers must play much cleaner basketball when they face tougher foes, a challenge that begins in this weekend. WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind. -- — Trey Kaufman-Renn scored a career-high 26 points and grabbed eight rebounds, and freshman C.J. Cox scored nine of his 11 points during a game-turning 13-0 run midway through the second half to help No. 13 Purdue get past No. 2 Alabama 87-78 on Friday night. The Boilermakers (4-0) have won 21 consecutive home games and 25 straight in November. They have not lost a regular-season nonconference game since December 2020. Braden Smith had 17 points and 10 assists as he moved into third place on Purdue's career assists list with 483. Fletcher Loyer also scored 17. Takeaways Alabama: Coach Nate Oats rolled the dice playing such an early road game against a team so traditionally strong at home, especially in November. After three straight rocky performances, coach Matt Painter’s squad delivered its best game yet. If Purdue continues playing this way, it could be the Big Ten contender everyone expects. 2024-11-20 - Marquette: 76 vs Purdue: 58

MILWAUKEE -- — Kam Jones had 17 points, 13 rebounds and 10 assists as No. 15 Marquette defeated No. 6 Purdue 76-58 on Tuesday night to snap the Boilermakers’ 39-game regular-season nonconference winning streak. Purdue (4-1) hadn’t lost a regular-season nonconference game since falling 58-54 at Miami on Dec. 8, 2020, compiling the fourth-longest such streak in NCAA history. The record is held by Syracuse, which won 52 straight nonconference regular-season games from Dec. 17, 2008, through Dec. 17, 2012. Jones’ triple-double was the third in school history and first since Dwyane Wade had 29 points, 11 rebounds and 11 assists when Marquette beat Kentucky 83-69 in a 2003 regional final to earn its most recent Final Four appearance. Marquette’s only other triple-double came from Tony Miller against Wisconsin on Dec. 31, 1994. Stevie Mitchell scored a career-high 21 points for Marquette (5-0). Chase Ross had 12 and Ben Gold added 11. Trey Kaufman-Renn had 16 points, Fletcher Loyer 13 and Braden Smith 11 for Purdue. Marquette: Jones has been a productive scorer much of his career, but Tuesday's game showed how much he has developed as an all-around player. His 13 rebounds and 10 assists were both career highs. profile_summary: Purdue enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 4-seed with a 24-12 record — a résumé that reflects genuine Big Ten relevance but also real vulnerability against elite competition. Against ranked opponents, the Boilermakers went roughly 7-9, with notable wins over then-No. 2 Alabama (87-78), No. 23 Ole Miss on a buzzer-beating putback, No. 13 Oregon on the road, and USC and NC State in neutral-site tournament play, but with damaging losses to No. 2 Auburn (87-69, blown out by 18 at halftime), No. 15 Marquette (76-58, 15 turnovers), No. 16 Wisconsin (94-84 at home), and No. 14 Michigan State (75-66) during a brutal four-game losing skid in February. That late-season collapse — four straight losses to Indiana, Michigan State, Wisconsin, and Michigan — is the defining blemish on their tournament profile, and while Purdue did recover with wins over UCLA and Rutgers to close the regular season, they were then beaten soundly by Michigan 86-68 in the Big Ten Tournament quarterfinals, with Braden Smith going just 5-of-18 from the field and 2-of-10 from three. Entering the tournament, Purdue's last five results read: win over UCLA (76-66), win over Rutgers (100-71), loss at Illinois (88-80 on a late collapse after leading by 10), win over USC in the Big Ten Tournament (76-71), and loss to Michigan (86-68) — a sequence that screams inconsistency rather than momentum. The Boilermakers are built around a genuinely elite 1-2 punch in Trey Kaufman-Renn (averaging over 20 points in recent weeks, including back-to-back 29-30 point efforts) and Big Ten Player of the Year Braden Smith, who is one of the most complete guards in college basketball when locked in — capable of 30-point, 12-assist, near-triple-double nights — but who has been alarmingly streaky in big moments, shooting 3-of-14 in the Ohio State loss and 5-of-18 against Michigan in the conference tournament. The supporting cast of Fletcher Loyer, Camden Heide, C.J. Cox, and Myles Colvin provides enough shooting and depth to be dangerous on a given night — Cox erupted for 23 on 9-of-11 shooting against Nebraska, and Loyer and Smith combined for 46 points and 14 threes against Rutgers — but this bench has been a persistent weak point, famously contributing zero points in the loss at Michigan. Purdue is emphatically a home team: they won 26 consecutive home games during the season and dominated teams like Nebraska (104-68) and Michigan (91-64) at Mackey Arena, but went just 3-5 in true road games and have shown a troubling tendency to go flat away from home, including a 16-turnover first half at Penn State, a 15-turnover meltdown at Marquette, and a second-half collapse at Illinois. On neutral sites, the Boilermakers are battle-tested — they won the Rady Children's Invitational with a dramatic buzzer-beating win over Ole Miss and beat NC State in a Final Four rematch — but the Michigan beatdown in Indianapolis raises real concerns about whether they can execute under tournament pressure when Smith struggles. The team's identity is paradoxical: capable of wire-to-wire dominance (the 91-64 Michigan blowout, the 104-68 Nebraska demolition) but equally capable of catastrophic collapses, having blown a 16-point lead to Ohio State and coughing up a 10-point second-half lead at Illinois in the final two minutes. Purdue has the star power and big-game experience to be a legitimate threat through the first weekend, and Kaufman-Renn's interior dominance gives them a size advantage against most opponents, but the turnover issues (48 turnovers in three games at one point), Smith's inconsistency in elimination settings, and the absence of a reliable rim protector since losing 7-foot-4 freshman Daniel Jacobsen to a fractured tibia in November are all real concerns at this level. The realistic ceiling for this Purdue team is the Sweet 16: their frontcourt talent and offensive
