2024-12-22 - Gonzaga: 86 vs Bucknell: 65

SPOKANE, Wash. -- — Graham Ike had 25 points and 10 rebounds, and No. 13 Gonzaga moved past an early cold spell to beat Bucknell 86-65 on Saturday night. Ben Gregg scored 15 points and Nolan Hickman added 14 for the Bulldogs (9-3), who improved to 6-0 at home. Ike was the only Zag to score in the first 7 1/2 minutes of the game. He kept Gonzaga afloat with a trio of buckets in the paint and a 3-pointer from the left wing. Gregg's 3 tied the game at 12-all with 12:31 left in the first half. From there, the Zags ran out to a 38-27 halftime lead and stretched their lead to 20 points with a 9-0 run to open the second half. Noah Williamson led Bucknell (4-8) with 16 points and Josh Bascoe added 14. Takeaways Bucknell: After six straight losses, the Bison have one more nonconference game before starting Patriot League play. Gonzaga: None of Gonzaga’s opponents have shot at least 33% from 3-point range. The Zags held Bucknell to 32.3% (10 of 31). Key moment Bucknell made five 3-pointers, three by Bascoe, in a span of just over three minutes in the second half but only got within 60-47 in that stretch. Gregg responded with a 3 that began a 9-0 run for Gonzaga. Key stat Gonzaga scored 24 points off Bucknell’s 19 turnovers. The Zags finished with 10 steals, including four by Ryan Nembhard, who also had nine points, nine assists and six rebounds. Up next Bucknell: At Syracuse next Saturday. 2024-12-28 - UCLA: 65 vs Gonzaga: 62

INGLEWOOD, Calif. -- — Eric Dailey Jr. scored 18 points, making four 3-pointers, and No. 22 UCLA edged 14th-ranked Gonzaga 65-62 on Saturday in the first college basketball game played at Intuit Dome, the new home of the NBA’s Los Angeles Clippers. Ryan Nembhard’s basket gave Gonzaga a 60-58 lead with 56 seconds left before the Bruins (11-2) scored five points in a row. Sebastian Mack converted a three-point play with 33 seconds remaining to put UCLA ahead, and Skyy Clark hit two free throws 20 seconds later. Nembhard then drove the length of the court and scored while getting fouled. After a timeout, he missed the potential tying free throw with 8 seconds to go. Graham Ike fouled Clark, who made both free throws for a 65-62 lead with 5 seconds left. Nembhard's 3-point heave from halfcourt missed at the buzzer. Ike led the Bulldogs (9-4) with 24 points and eight rebounds. Nembhard had 16 points and eight assists. Graham was 11 of 16 from the floor on a day when both teams struggled offensively in the 18,000-seat arena. It was a tough shooting day for UCLA's Tyler Bilodeau, who was limited to seven points — well under his team-leading 15.1 average — while going against Ike. Takeaways Gonzaga: The Zags fell to 3-4 on neutral courts. UCLA: The Bruins improved to 2-2 on neutral courts. They were coming off a two-point loss to North Carolina in New York City last weekend. Key moments The Zags lost starter Khalif Battle (five points) when he was ejected with 4:12 remaining in the first half for a flagrant-2 foul against Dailey. Before it was reviewed, UCLA coach Mick Cronin tore off his jacket. Early in the second half, Dailey and Nembhard were called for double technicals when things got heated between the teams. Key stat The Zags went 2 of 11 on 3-point attempts in the first half, when they trailed by 11. They made five 3s in the second half. Up next Gonzaga stays in the Los Angeles area to visit Pepperdine on Monday. UCLA visits Nebraska on Jan. 4 in Big Ten play. ------ The dateline of this story has been corrected. 2024-12-31 - Pepperdine: 82 vs Gonzaga: 89

MALIBU, Calif. -- — Khalif Battle scored 21 points, Braden Huff added 19 points on 9-of-10 shooting and No. 19 Gonzaga beat Pepperdine 89-82 on Monday night in the West Coast Conference opener for both teams. Huff converted a three-point play that gave the Bulldogs the lead for good 7:10 into the first half, and Gonzaga (10-4) led 50-32 at the intermission. Freshman Jaxon Olvera scored a season-high 27 points on 12-of-21 shooting for Pepperdine (6-9). Moe Odum added 24 points and eight assists. After Battle made a layup to open the scoring in the second half and push Gonzaga's lead to 20 points, the Waves scored 22 of the next 26 points — including 13 points and three assists by Odum. Gonzaga scored six in a row after that to keep Pepperdine at bay. Takeaways Gonzaga: The Bulldogs were inconsistent on both ends of the floor but found another gear each time Pepperdine threatened. Pepperdine: The Waves, who went into the game averaging 11.7 turnovers, committed 11 in the first half, helping Gonzaga build an 18-point halftime lead. Pepperdine had just four turnovers and outscored the Bulldogs 50-38 in the second half. Key moment After Olvera made back-to-back baskets to make it a four-point game with two minutes to play, Battle went 4 for 4 from the free-throw line and scored six points down the stretch to seal it for Gonzaga. Key stat Gonzaga has won 48 consecutive games against the Waves. Pepperdine’s last win against the Bulldogs was an 88-79 home victory on Jan. 18, 2002. Up next Gonzaga plays Portland at the Spokane Arena in the Community Cancer Fund Classic on Thursday. Pepperdine hits the road to play at Saint Mary's on Thursday. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2025-01-03 - Gonzaga: 81 vs Portland: 50

SPOKANE, Wash. -- — Nolan Hickman had 13 points and No. 19 Gonzaga cruised to an 81-50 victory over Portland on Thursday night in the Community Cancer Fund Classic at Spokane Arena. Ryan Nembhard added 10 points and nine assists for the Bulldogs (11-4, 2-0 West Coast Conference). Dusty Stromer scored 12, Braden Huff had 10 points and Michael Ajayi pulled down 15 rebounds. Redshirt freshman Vincent Delano was the only player in double figures for the Pilots (5-11, 0-3) with 12 points. Delano shot 6 for 16 from the field and Portland was held to 33.3% overall. Ben Gregg had four of Gonzaga's 10 steals. Takeaways Gonzaga: After shooting 2 for 15 from 3-point range in their conference opener against Pepperdine, the Zags went 11 of 24 (45.8%) in this one. Portland: The Pilots have been outrebounded by double digits in all three league games. Key moment After giving up the opening score, Gonzaga went on a 20-0 run. Huff and Nembhard had six points apiece during the spurt. Key stat Coming into the game, Gonzaga had held opponents to 28% from behind the 3-point line. Portland went 1 for 14 in the first half and finished 4 of 25 (16%). Up next Portland returns home to face Saint Mary’s on Saturday. Gonzaga visits Loyola Marymount on Saturday. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2025-01-05 - Loyola Marymount: 68 vs Gonzaga: 96

LOS ANGELES -- — Graham Ike scored 27 points, Khalif Battle added 26 and No. 19 Gonzaga rolled to a 96-68 victory over Loyola Marymount on Saturday. Michael Ajayi came off the bench with 15 points for the Bulldogs (12-4, 3-0 West Coast Conference), who have won 11 straight true road games. Gonzaga has won 13th straight over Loyola Marymount on the Lions' home floor. Will Johnston had 18 points and Jevon Porter 17 for Loyola Marymount (9-7, 1-3). Gonzaga led by double digits midway through the first half and kept extending its lead. The Bulldogs were up 46-28 at halftime and their largest advantage was 30 (96-66) late in the game. LAS VEGAS -- — The metrics — and oddsmakers — indicated Gonzaga was far better than its record, and there was little doubt the Bulldogs had the ability to once again compete at a high level. Maybe it was simply a matter of timing. Braden Huff scored 18 points in just his second start of the season as Gonzaga avenged two regular-season losses to Saint Mary's, beating the 19th-ranked Gaels 58-51 in the West Coast Conference Tournament championship on Tuesday night. The Bulldogs (25-8) secured the WCC's automatic bid to the NCAA Tournament, though both teams were safely in the field regardless of the outcome. “We've had an inordinate amount of one-possession games,” Gonzaga coach Mark Few said. “I think that's why we're such an interesting seed going into this NCAA Tournament. I think we were 350th in luck in Kenpom. We've had more banked 3s on us than I could ever, ever remember in my entire career. "Whether it's law of averages coming through or just a little resiliency ... or maybe it's just desperation by some seniors who don't want this thing to end.” The Bulldogs also got some measure of revenge for losing to the Gaels in last year's title game, which ended Gonzaga's run of four conference championships and 10 of 11. Gonzaga also extended its national record to 18 consecutive 25-win seasons. Saint Mary's (28-5) had its seven-game winning streak stopped. The Gaels also had won 17 of 18 games. “We've had a great year,” Saint Mary's coach Randy Bennett said. “We did not play well tonight.” Khalif Battle scored 14 points for the Zags, Graham Ike added 11 and Ryan Nembhard had 10. Mitchell Saxen led Saint Mary's with 20 points but scored only six after halftime. Two-time WCC Player of the Year Augustas Marciulionis finished with 12 points. Saint Mary’s was attempting to become the first team since San Diego in 1996-97 to beat Gonzaga three times in a season. But Gonzaga entered the game with the higher Kenpom rating, ninth to 22nd for the Gaels, and was a 3 1/2-point favorite at Sportsbook. “You've got to go through some hardships in order to win,” Battle said. “We've been practicing for this moment. I think we were prepared more than ever going into this tournament, so I'm happy we were able to hoist the trophy.” Takeaways Gonzaga: The Bulldogs committed just four turnovers while forcing 18 that included two shot-clock violations in the closing minutes. Saint Mary's: The Gaels are the first ranked team since No. 25 Texas A&M in 2011 to go at least 0 for 16 from 3-point range and commit 18 or more turnovers. Key moment Marciulionis' layup with 15:09 left brought Saint Mary's within a point, but the Gaels went the next 7:36 without a field goal as Gonzaga built a 48-42 lead. Key stats The teams combined to shoot 1 of 31 on 3-pointers, the third-worst combined percentage in any game over the past 20 years. Saint Mary's went 0 for 16. Up next Both teams will find out their NCAA Tournament seeds and destinations on Sunday. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 all season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and
profile_summary:
Gonzaga enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as an 8-seed with a 26-9 record that dramatically undersells their actual quality — coach Mark Few himself noted the Bulldogs ranked 350th in KenPom luck, citing an "inordinate amount of one-possession games" and more banked threes against them than he could ever remember. Against ranked opponents, the Zags went an impressive 5-7, with signature wins over then-No. 8 Baylor (101-63, their largest margin over a top-10 opponent in school history), No. 14 Indiana (89-73), and No. 19 Saint Mary's in the WCC Tournament championship (58-51), while suffering narrow losses to No. 4 Kentucky (89-90 OT), No. 18 UConn (71-77), No. 22 UCLA (62-65), and Saint Mary's twice in the regular season. Their final five games tell a compelling story of a team catching fire at the right time: a 95-76 win at Santa Clara, a 95-75 regular-season finale win at San Francisco, a WCC quarterfinal win over San Francisco (85-76), and then the WCC championship upset of Saint Mary's — four straight wins capped by a gritty, turnover-forcing performance in which Gonzaga committed just four turnovers while forcing 18. The Bulldogs extended their national record to 18 consecutive 25-win seasons and avenged both regular-season losses to the Gaels to close the year on a high note.

Stylistically, Gonzaga is a multi-dimensional, offense-first team capable of going wire-to-wire in blowouts — they routed Baylor by 38, Portland twice (105-62, 81-50), and Pepperdine by 52 — but they are equally capable of tight-game vulnerability, as their losses to Oregon State (89-97 OT), Santa Clara (99-103), and UCLA (62-65) demonstrated during a mid-season rough patch. The engine of this team is senior point guard Ryan Nembhard, the nation's assists leader (295 assists, 9.8 per game) who recorded back-to-back 15-assist games to close the regular season; his playmaking and ball security (4.15 assist-to-turnover ratio) give Gonzaga an elite offensive architecture. Graham Ike is the team's premier scorer and rebounder — posting 26 points and nine rebounds against Oregon State and 28 and 11 against Kentucky — while Khalif Battle provides explosive scoring off the bench and Braden Huff (9-of-10 shooting against Pepperdine) offers efficient frontcourt depth. Nolan Hickman's three-point shooting (five threes against Washington State) adds another perimeter weapon. Location-wise, the Zags are dominant at home (losing only once, to Santa Clara) but have been inconsistent on neutral courts (3-4), with close neutral-site losses to Kentucky and UCLA tempered by the WCC Tournament run. As an 8-seed, Gonzaga is one of the most dangerous teams in the bracket — a program with Final Four pedigree, elite playmaking, and genuine star power arriving at peak form. Their realistic ceiling is the Elite Eight: experienced and talented enough to knock off a 1-seed in an upset, but their neutral-site inconsistency and vulnerability to elite perimeter shooting (Santa Clara's 18 threes exposed them) make a Final Four run a stretch rather than an expectation.

The Bulldogs made four free throws in the first four minutes of the second half. profile_summary:
Georgia enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 9-seed with a 20-13 record — a résumé built on genuine moments of brilliance undermined by persistent inconsistency, particularly against elite competition. The Bulldogs' season narrative is defined by an extraordinary gauntlet: they faced a school-record 12 Top-25 opponents during SEC play, going 3-9 against ranked teams in conference, with quality wins over No. 6 Kentucky (82-69), No. 17 Oklahoma (72-62), No. 3 Florida (88-83), and a narrow 70-68 home loss to No. 1 Auburn that came down to a final possession. Their ranked record overall sits roughly 4-11, meaning they've been beaten far more often than not against elite competition, but those four wins carry real weight — the Florida victory in particular, snapping a 12-game series losing streak and sending fans storming the court, stands as the signature moment of their season. Georgia's recent form is a mixed picture: they won four straight to close the regular season — beating Florida, Texas (83-67 wire-to-wire), South Carolina, and Vanderbilt — before losing 81-75 to 14-seed Oklahoma in the first round of the SEC Tournament, a genuinely alarming exit that snapped their momentum just days before Selection Sunday. In that tournament loss, Jeremiah Fears torched them for 29 points and Oklahoma shot 52% in the first half, with Georgia never fully recovering from a 10-0 run that put the game out of reach late — a collapse pattern that has recurred all season, most notably in a 26-4 second-half run surrendered to Tennessee and a 22-0 run absorbed at Texas A&M.

Stylistically, Georgia is a multi-faceted but volatile team: they are capable of dominant first halves and wire-to-wire wins, as demonstrated against Texas and in their home blowouts of Kentucky and Oklahoma, but they are dangerously prone to second-half collapses and extended scoring droughts, shooting 17-of-58 in the Ole Miss opener and going scoreless for stretches in multiple road losses. The engine of this team is freshman Asa Newell, a 6-foot-11 consensus five-star recruit who has delivered double-digit scoring in nearly every game and is coming off 21 points and 17 rebounds in the SEC Tournament loss — he is a legitimate pro prospect and a matchup nightmare at the college level. Sophomore guard Silas Demary Jr. has emerged as the team's other alpha, earning SEC Player of the Week honors after averaging 23.5 points in wins over Florida and Texas, and he scored 24 in the tournament loss. The supporting cast — Dakota Leffew off the bench, Blue Cain, and transfers RJ Godfrey and De'Shayne Montgomery — provides enough depth to be dangerous, though Tyrin Lawrence's hamstring injury is a concern worth monitoring. Geographically, Georgia is dramatically better at home (13-2 at Stegeman Coliseum) than on the road, where they've absorbed blowout losses at Florida (89-59), Alabama (90-69), and Texas A&M (69-53) — neutral-site results are a smaller sample but include a win over St. John's and the loss to Marquette in the Bahamas, suggesting middling performance away from Athens. The Bulldogs play with genuine resilience and competitive spirit — they rallied from 17 down to beat South Carolina State and came back from a 78-67 deficit to beat Florida — but they lack the defensive consistency and offensive composure to sustain pressure against elite opponents for 40 minutes. **Realistic ceiling: Round of 32.** Newell and Demary give Georgia enough firepower to knock off their 8-seed opponent in a first-round upset scenario, but the recurring second-half collapses, road/neutral-site struggles, and the fresh wound of losing to a 14-seed Oklahoma team in the SEC Tournament make a run to the Sweet 16 unlikely without a dramatic reversal of their most persistent flaws.

Takeaways Gardner-Webb: Coach Jeremy Luther’s first game at Gardner-Webb was a whopper. The Bulldogs will be spending the early part of the season trying to fit five new faces into the rotation. Tennessee: After a four-point exhibition loss to Indiana, the Vols cleaned up their shooting woes (they shot 24% in the first half of the exhibition and 31% for the game). The improvement will need to show as the season goes on. They still need to find the “hair on fire” defense that made them special last season. Reyne Smith came off the bench to score 18 points for the Cardinals, who shot 16 of 60 for the game. That included just 10 of 39 from beyond the arc (26%). Takeaways Tennessee: The Volunteers showed their quickness and athleticism throughout on both ends, going hard to the rim on offense and sealing off the lane defensively. They were sometimes ragged in committing 20 turnovers, but that led to just 12 points thanks to the Cardinals' errors. Louisville: The Cardinals initially struggled controlling the ball, and then it was getting off a shot against the Vols' defense. That left them firing from long range, which often resulted in misses other than the one second-half stretch in which they closed within single digits. Jordan Gainey made a 3-pointer with 3:33 to left to give Tennessee (22-5, 9-5 Southeastern Conference) a 63-59 lead. Zakai Zeigler hit a 3 in front of the Vols' bench on an inbound pass with 21 seconds remaining to seal the victory. The Aggies (20-7, 9-5) started the game with three consecutive dunks before the Vols finally scored a little more than three minutes into the raucous setting at Reed Arena. A&M led 17-8 early before the Vols scored the next seven points to climb back in the game. Wade Taylor IV led the Aggies with 18 points, despite missing all nine of his 3-point attempts. Takeaways Texas A&M: The Aggies were coming off a 16-point loss at No. 21 Mississippi State that snapped a five-game winning streak, and they’ve lost two straight games for the first time since mid-January (at home against Alabama and at Kentucky). A&M, despite failing to collect its first home victory against a top-10 opponent in program history, likely won’t be affected much in the NCAA Tournament seedings. Tennessee: The Volunteers hadn’t played since an 81-76 home victory over Vanderbilt a week earlier, and the rested crew appeared to have more energy and spirit from the start against the Aggies. Key moment The Aggies led 40-38 with 15:27 remaining when Tennessee's Jahmai Mashack collected an acrobatic, improbable tip-in while trying to grab the rebound off a Gainey missed 3-pointer. Key stat Both teams made 90% of their free throws, each hitting 18 of 20. Up next The Volunteers play at LSU on Tuesday night. The Aggies host Vanderbilt on Wednesday night. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

Chaz Lanier added 14 points and a season-high nine rebounds for the Volunteers (23-5, 10-5 Southeastern Conference), who struggled offensively in the first half but built a 15-point lead on Cade Phillips' free throw with 3:24 left. By the time LSU (14-14, 3-12) trimmed Tennessee's lead down to 64-59, just 11 seconds remained. Vyctorius Miller scored 17 points and Cam Carter had 12 for LSU, which lost its second straight game against a team ranked in the top five. The Tigers just couldn't shoot well enough to pull off the kind of SEC stunner that Georgia had against No. 3 Florida earlier in the evening. 2025-03-14 - Tennessee: 83 vs Texas: 72

NASHVILLE, Tenn. -- — Chaz Lanier scored 17 of No. 8 Tennessee's first 21 points, and the Volunteers never trailed Friday beating Texas 83-72 in the Southeastern Conference Tournament quarterfinals. The fourth-seeded Volunteers (26-6) also gave coach Rick Barnes the 832nd victory of his career, moving him into sole possession of 10th all-time after being tied with Cliff Ellis. The Vols will play regular season champ and third-ranked Auburn, a 62-57 winner over Ole Miss, in the semifinals Saturday. Lanier finished with 23 points. Zakai Zeigler scored all of his 19 points in the second half after playing nine minutes with two fouls in the first half. Jahmai Mashack added 13 and Igor Milicic Jr. 12. Texas (19-15) came to its first SEC Tournament as the 13th seed after winning the Big 12 Tournament two of the last four seasons. Kadin Shedrick and Jordan Pope each had 14 apiece for Texas. Tre Johnson had 11. Tennessee led 41-38 at halftime, then jumped out to a 65-50 lead halfway through the second against a team playing its third game in as many days. Takeaways Texas: The Longhorns came to Nashville having lost four of their last five. They won their first two games in a desperate bid to fight their win into NCAA Tournament, and boost coach Rodney Terry, whose job status after this season remains uncertain. Tennessee: The Vols are back in the semifinals for the first time since winning this tournament in 2022 when it was held in Tampa, Florida. That was their first win at this event since it resumed in 1979. Key moment Mashack's putback with 16:34 left broke the game's second and last tie at 4-all. 2025-03-15 - Auburn: 65 vs Tennessee: 70

NASHVILLE, Tenn. -- — Zakai Zeigler scored 20 points as No. 8 Tennessee held off regular-season champion and third-ranked Auburn 70-65 on Saturday to reach the Southeastern Conference Tournament championship for the first time since 2022. The fourth-seeded Volunteers (27-6) got revenge both for their Jan. 25 loss at Auburn and their 2019 loss to the Tigers in this tournament's title game. Tennessee will play fourth-ranked Florida, a 104-82 winner over No. 5 Alabama, on Sunday for the tournament title. The Vols and the winner of that semifinal likely wind up with No. 1 seeds in the NCAA Tournament — only fitting for the nation’s best league. Jordan Gainey added 15 points for the Vols, and Chaz Lanier had 12. The Tigers (28-5) go home losers of three of their last four games. SEC player of the year Johni Broome led Auburn with 23 points, Miles Kelly added 13 and Denver Jones had 10. Auburn led 33-32 at halftime thanks to a late 10-0 spurt. The Tigers last led at 48-47. Takeaways Tennessee: The Vols are playing in their fourth final in the last seven tournaments. They won in Tampa in 2022 and lost the title game in both 2018 and 2019. They improved to 12-8 in this tournament under coach Rick Barnes, who got his 833rd career victory. Auburn: The Tigers came in looking for a fourth tournament title and third under coach Bruce Pearl. Not only did they win with Pearl last year and in 2019, they also won in 1985. Key moment Tennessee never trailed after a 13-1 run to go up 60-49 capped by Zeigler's 3 from the top of the circle with 7:17 left. Key stat The Vols had an edge at the free-throw line, making 25 of 27, including 18 of 20 in the second half. Auburn was 13 of 22. Jahmai Mashack sealed the win with 14 seconds left with the final pair. Up next Auburn will see where it lands in the NCAA Tournament Sunday. 2025-03-16 - Florida: 86 vs Tennessee: 77
profile_summary:
Tennessee enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 2-seed with a 30-8 record — a résumé built on genuine elite-level wins, a historically strong start (14-0, best in program history), and a defense that has been among the nation's best all season. Against ranked opponents, the Volunteers went approximately 10-8, with marquee wins over then-No. 13 Baylor (77-62, neutral), No. 23 Arkansas (76-52), No. 5 Florida (64-44, at home without Zeigler and Milicic), No. 6 Alabama on a Mashack buzzer-beater (79-76), No. 7 Texas A&M (77-69, road), No. 1 Auburn (70-65, neutral), and No. 6 Tennessee's signature moment was repeatedly beating quality teams in multiple environments — though losses to Florida (73-43, a 30-point road demolition), Kentucky twice (78-73 and 75-64), Auburn (53-51, road), Vanderbilt (76-75, road), Ole Miss (78-76, road), and Florida again in the SEC title game (86-77) reveal a team that consistently struggles away from Knoxville. The Vols closed the regular season and conference tournament on a mixed but intriguing run: wins over Vanderbilt (81-76 comeback from 16 down), Texas A&M (77-69), LSU (65-59), Alabama on a buzzer-beater (79-76), and South Carolina (75-65), before dropping the regular season finale at Ole Miss (78-76) and the SEC championship to Florida (86-77) — a 4-2 stretch that is encouraging in its competitiveness but concerning in its inability to close out close games on the road or neutral sites. In the SEC Tournament, however, Tennessee was genuinely impressive: they dismantled Texas (83-72), upset No. 3 Auburn in the semis (70-65) behind Zakai Zeigler's 20 points and a brilliant free-throw performance (25-of-27 as a team), before running out of gas against a rested Florida squad in the final.

Tennessee's identity is built around suffocating defense — they set a 64-point defensive benchmark and held opponents under it nine of eleven times early in the season — combined with a dangerous three-point attack led by Chaz Lanier, who has erupted for 25, 26, 29, 30, and 23 points in various games and shoots with the kind of volume and efficiency that can single-handedly torch opponents (7-of-10 from three against Baylor in the Baha Mar Championship). Senior point guard Zakai Zeigler is the engine — a career 600-assist, 200-steal distributor who scores, orchestrates, and competes in the biggest moments, evidenced by his SEC semifinal performance against Auburn. Igor Milicic Jr. provides a versatile frontcourt presence with rebounding and scoring upside, while Jordan Gainey has emerged as a reliable secondary creator and Jahmai Mashack delivered one of the season's most memorable shots with his half-court buzzer-beater against Alabama. The roster is thin — only nine scholarship players, with J.P. Estrella lost for the season to injury and Cameron Carr having departed — which raises real stamina and depth concerns over a six-game tournament run. Notably, Tennessee is 16-2 at home, 4-5 on the road, and has performed well on neutral sites (Baha Mar Championship title, two SEC Tournament wins over ranked opponents), suggesting the neutral-site NCAA Tournament environment suits them better than true road environments. The Vols are at their best when playing composed, defensive-minded basketball with Lanier running hot from three — and at their worst when shots are cold on the road and opponents attack their paint. Tennessee's realistic ceiling is the Elite Eight: they have the defensive backbone, star power, big-game experience, and neutral-site credibility to make a serious run, but their offensive inconsistency, thin rotation, and vulnerability in close games against elite competition make a Final Four appearance a high bar rather than an expectation.

profile_summary:
Wofford enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 15-seed with a 19-16 record — a modest résumé that reflects a team that spent much of the season fighting for relevance before catching fire at the right moment. The Terriers' schedule told a brutal early story: a 51-point demolition at the hands of #6 Duke (86-35) in November exposed real limitations against elite competition, and non-conference losses to Lipscomb, Presbyterian, Milwaukee, and Portland State painted a picture of a team prone to vulnerability against mid-major peers. Against ranked opponents, Wofford went 0-1, with that Duke blowout standing as the only measurable data point — hardly encouraging big-game pedigree. In Southern Conference play, however, Wofford proved legitimately competitive, finishing 10-8 in league play and earning the sixth seed heading into the conference tournament. Their final five regular-season and tournament games tell the most compelling story: a 90-67 road blowout of Western Carolina, a narrow 78-75 home loss to Furman on a buzzer-beating three, followed by tournament wins over East Tennessee State (72-60), VMI (85-65), and a stunning 92-85 championship victory over Furman — avenging that late-game gut-punch and clinching the automatic bid. That three-game tournament surge, including outscoring opponents by a combined 44 points, represents genuine momentum.

The engine driving Wofford is a multi-headed offensive attack anchored by Corey Tripp, who has been the team's most reliable performer all season — dropping 31 points against ETSU in late February, 20 in the Citadel overtime win, and consistent double-figure contributions throughout league play. Kyler Filewich is a load inside, routinely posting double-doubles (16 points and 11 rebounds in the regular-season finale against Furman; 18 points and 11 rebounds against VMI in the championship run) and providing a physical presence few mid-major opponents can match. Dillon Bailey and Jackson Sivills offer reliable secondary scoring, with Sivills contributing 17 points in the tournament quarterfinal win over ETSU. The Terriers play a high-scoring, guard-and-post complementary style that can erupt offensively — they topped 80 points six times — but are equally capable of flat, disengaged performances; the Elon loss (56 points), VMI home loss (67 points), and early non-conference stumbles illustrate a team that is inconsistent rather than reliably locked in. Locationally, Wofford was strong at home but showed they can win on the road and at neutral sites when playing with confidence, as evidenced by their tournament run in Asheville. The squad projects as scrappy and resilient — capable of clutch moments (Tripp's regulation-tying free throws against The Citadel, the Furman championship comeback) — but the Duke blowout and early non-conference stumbles make it hard to envision them sustaining that energy against a high-major opponent. **Verdict: Wofford is a near-certain first-round exit.** A 19-16 record, zero wins against ranked opponents, and a résumé built almost entirely on mid-major competition makes them a feel-good story with a hard ceiling — a dangerous underdog for 40 minutes, but realistically overmatched against any competent high-major 2-seed.

name: Kansas
summaries:
2024-11-05 - Kansas: 87 vs Howard: 57

LAWRENCE, Kan. -- — Zeke Mayo, a grad transfer from South Dakota State, had 19 points in his Kansas debut and the top-ranked Jayhawks beat Howard 87-57 on Monday night in the season-opener for both teams. Kansas led 46-19 at halftime and its biggest lead was 38 points. The game was the second annual McClendon Classic, named in honor of Kansas graduate and Naismith Memorial Hall of Fame honoree John McClendon. Kansas (1-0) used the game as a tune-up before a top-10 showdown with North Carolina on Friday night. The Jayhawks had 10 players score, with three in double-figures. Hunter Dickinson, who missed Kansas' scrimmage and exhibition games, had 16 points and six rebounds, and Flory Bidunga added 13 points and a game-high eight rebounds. Blake Harper had 16 points to lead Howard. Takeaways Howard: The Bison will take away plenty from the contest, mostly measured in guaranteed money they received from Kansas. Kansas: The Jayhawks won their 52nd consecutive home opener, dating back to the final 10 years of Ted Owens’ career, through five years under Larry Brown, 15 under Roy Williams and 22 straight under Bill Self. Key moment After falling behind 4-3 early, the Jayhawks used a 12-3 run to eliminate any thoughts of a Howard victory. Howard went almost nine minutes without a field goal, missing 10 straight shot attempts as Kansas methodically pulled away. Key stat Howard shot just 24.1 percent (7 for 29) in the first half. Up Next Howard visits Missouri on Friday, while Kansas hosts No. 9 North Carolina. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2024-11-09 - Kansas: 92 vs North Carolina: 89

LAWRENCE, Kan. -- — Hunter Dickinson had 20 points for top-ranked Kansas, which blew a 20-point first-half lead against No. 9 North Carolina before holding on for a 92-89 victory when the Tar Heels’ Elliot Cadeau missed a 3-pointer as time expired Friday night. Zeke Mayo had 21 points and KJ Adams Jr had 14 for the Jayhawks (2-0), who led 49-29 in the first half but trailed 87-83 with 3:28 to go. Dickinson and Mayo responded with a series of baskets to tie the game at 89, and Dickinson’s basket with 1:15 to go and free throw with 12 seconds remaining made it a three-point game. The Tar Heels (1-1) raced up the floor, but Cadeau’s 3 from the wing never had a chance. Seth Trimble scored 19 points to lead North Carolina. RJ Davis had 16 points and Cadeau finished with 12. It was just the 13th matchup of the Tar Heels and Jayhawks, and the first since Kansas rallied from a 16-point deficit to win the 2022 national championship. The only other time they have met on campus was in 1960, when Larry Brown — who would later coach the Jayhawks to the 1988 title — helped the Tar Heels win in Allen Fieldhouse. Kansas made a repeat seem unlikely when it built a 20-point first-half lead. But the Tar Heels trimmed the deficit in the second half, and Jae'Lyn Withers' 3-pointer gave them an 80-79 lead with 7:06 to go. The two bluebloods wrestled it away several other times before Kansas finally put the game away. Takeaways North Carolina stayed alive by getting to the basket and drawing fouls, ultimately going 28 of 31 from the line. Kansas avoided what would have been the biggest blown-lead loss in school history while giving coach Bill Self his 590th win at the school, matching Phog Allen's record. Key moment Dickinson's basket inside with 1:15 left gave Kansas the lead, and the All-American center's free throw forced North Carolina into needing a 3-pointer to tie the game. Key stat 20 — The lead that Kansas had in the first half. And that the Tar Heels overcame in the second. Up next North Carolina plays American next Friday night. The Jayhawks play Michigan State on Tuesday night in Atlanta. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 all season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2024-11-12 - Kansas: 77 vs Michigan State: 69

ATLANTA -- — Hunter Dickinson scored 28 points and Bill Self became the winningest coach in Kansas history as the top-ranked Jayhawks pulled away from Michigan State for a 77-69 victory in the Champions Classic on Tuesday night. Spartans forward Jaxon Kohler hit a 3-pointer to tie the game at 52 with just under nine minutes remaining. KJ Adams Jr. hit a pair of free throws to put Kansas (3-0) ahead to stay. Self improved to 591-143 in his 22nd season coaching the Jayhawks, pushing him past Phog Allen's mark of 590-219 in 39 seasons on the Kansas sideline. Frankie Fidler led Michigan State (2-1) with 15 points. The Jayhawks posted their second straight win over one of the nation's prominent programs, following up a 92-89 win over No. 10 North Carolina. Takeaways Kansas: After missing 15 straight shots from the field, Kansas ripped off a 14-2 run that turned an 18-16 deficit into a 30-20 lead. Michigan State: The Spartans couldn't overcome a tough shooting night, especially from beyond the arc. They made just 3 of 24 from 3-point range. Key moment Dajuan Harris Jr. gave the Jayhawks some breathing room when he laid one in off a fast break, drew a foul and completed the three-point play for a 68-59 lead with 4:25 to go. After tumbling to the court, Harris remained on his back for a few seconds, clapping furiously. He finished with 11 points and six assists. Key stats The 7-foot-2 Dickinson made 13 of 21 shots from the field, including his only 3-point attempt, and grabbed 12 rebounds. He also had three steals and a block at the defensive end. Up next Kansas returns home Saturday to face Oakland. Michigan State hosts Bowling Green on Saturday. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. 2024-11-16 - Kansas: 78 vs Oakland: 57

LAWRENCE, Kan. -- — AJ Storr had a season-high 16 points off the bench and three starters also reached double figures as No. 1 Kansas easily handled Oakland 78-57 on Saturday. KJ Adams scored 10 of his 12 points in the first half, Rylan Griffen added 11 and Hunter Dickinson finished with 10. Dickinson led the Jayhawks with nine rebounds. Kansas (4-0) pulled away methodically in the first half, leading by 22 at halftime. The Grizzlies never got closer than 18 in the second half. Kansas played the final 4:32 with only reserves in the game. Allen Mukeba led Oakland (1-3) with 19 points, and Tuburu Naivalurua added 12. Oakland struggled from 3-point range, shooting 6 of 23 (27%), and was woeful at the free-throw line (3 for 12). Takeaways Oakland: The Grizzlies were no match for Kansas inside during the first half, when the game was decided. They were outrebounded 20-12 and outscored 26-14 in the paint. Kansas: The Jayhawks have too much depth for a mid-major program like Oakland to overcome. The Jayhawks got points from 11 players. They had 36 bench points, compared to 17 for Oakland. Key moments Dickinson hit a floater in the lane at the 4:37 mark of the first half to give Kansas a 34-17 cushion. Griffen made a baseline 3 just before the buzzer, and the Jayhawks took a 46-24 lead into the locker room. Key stats DaJuan Harris scored only two points in 23 minutes, but he had six assists and just one turnover. He was tenacious on defense, with four steals — including three in the first few minutes of the second half when Kansas eliminated any thoughts of an Oakland comeback. Up next Oakland returns home to face Eastern Michigan on Thursday. Kansas hosts UNC-Wilmington on Wednesday. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. 2024-11-20 - Kansas: 84 vs UNC Wilmington: 66

LAWRENCE, Kan. -- — Hunter Dickinson had 15 points and 15 rebounds, Dajuan Harris Jr. scored 16 points, and No. 1 Kansas shrugged off a sluggish start to beat UNC Wilmington 84-66 on Tuesday night and give Jayhawks coach Bill Self his 800th career win. David Coit added 13 points and Zeke Mayo had 10 for the Jayhawks (5-0), who led 43-38 at halftime before going on a 12-2 run to start the second half. They stretched the lead to 20 and coasted to their 18th straight nonconference home win. The Jayhawks next face No. 12 Duke in the Vegas Showdown on Tuesday. Khamari McGriff had 18 points and Noah Ross had 10 with nine boards for UNC Wilmington (4-1), which was picked to finish third in the Colonial Athletic Association after winning 21 games last season. The Seahawks weren't intimidated by the 372nd straight sellout at Allen Fieldhouse. They beat Kentucky at Rupp Arena just last season. And while Kansas started the game with energy, UNC Wilmington matched it for the first 20 minutes. It wasn't until Harris led the Jayhawks' early second-half charge that they put the game away. Takeaways UNC Wilmington got just seven points from Donovan Newby. He had 20 in a recent win over USC Upstate. Kansas lost freshman Flory Bidunga to an injury in the first half. He did not put any weight on his right leg as he was helped to the bench. He did not return. Bidunga's loss would be a big blow to the Jayhawks' interior depth. Key moment Kansas roared out of halftime on the run that ultimately decided the game. Key stats The Jayhawks won despite shooting 6 of 25 from 3-point range. 2024-11-27 - Duke: 72 vs Kansas: 75

LAS VEGAS -- — Dajuan Harris scored 14 points and top-ranked Kansas withstood the ejection of star center Hunter Dickinson to beat No. 11 Duke 75-72 in the Vegas Showdown on Tuesday night. Dickinson, who entered the game averaging 17.8 points and 10.4 rebounds, received a fragrant-2 foul and was ejected for kicking the Blue Devils’ Maliq Brown in the head midway through the second half. Highly touted Duke freshman Cooper Flagg took advantage of Dickinson's absence, and the Blue Devils kept it close all the way to the buzzer. Zeke Mayo added 12 points for Kansas (6-0), and Dickinson and AJ Storr each scored 11. Tyrese Proctor led Duke (4-2) with 15 points, Flagg scored 13, Kon Knueppel had 11 and Sion James finished with 10. Mayo put Kansas ahead for good when he made a jumper with 1:57 left for a 73-71 lead. Flagg hit a free throw for Duke and Rylan Griffen answered with two foul shots with 2 seconds left. Kansas has won four of the past five meetings with the Blue Devils and six of eight. Nine of the past 10 meetings have been decided by single digits. Takeaways Kansas: Overcoming the loss of Dickinson could serve the Jayhawks well later in the season. Duke: Flagg had six points when Dickinson went out, but then on four trips to the lane had two dunks, a layup and a free throw. Key moment Knueppel had a 3-point try rim out at the buzzer that would have forced overtime. Key stat Duke shot 50% from the field and 42.3% from 3-point range. 2024-12-05 - Creighton: 76 vs Kansas: 63

OMAHA, Neb. -- — Pop Isaacs helped unranked Creighton upset No. 1 Kansas 76-63 on Wednesday night, scoring a season-high 27 points and matching his career high with six 3-pointers. Kansas cut a 13-point deficit to one early in the second half, but Isaacs hit back-to-back 3s to rebuild the lead as the Bluejays (6-3) pulled away for their second straight victory over a top-ranked opponent. They knocked off Connecticut 85-66 in Omaha in February. The Jayhawks (7-1) lost a regular-season game against an unranked nonconference opponent for the first time in three years. Creighton had been in 16 straight Associated Press polls before dropping out this week following losses in three of its previous four games. Students rushed the court at the final buzzer as flames shot out of the top of the goal standards. Isaacs’ shooting display overshadowed what was supposed to be the featured matchup between two of the nation’s best big men, the 7-foot-1 Ryan Kalkbrenner and the Jayhawks’ 7-2 Hunter Dickinson. Kalkbrenner, who had missed the Bluejays' previous game because of a lower-body injury, and Steven Ashworth each scored 17 points. The Jayhawks struggled offensively and never led. Dajuan Harris had 15 points and AJ Storr and Zeke Mayo added 12 apiece for Kansas. Takeaways Kansas: The Jayhawks could never find a rhythm offensively. Dickinson had difficulty getting touches and took only four shots, making two. Creighton: When the Bluejays make their 3-pointers, they’re tough to beat. They came into the game shooting 32% from distance but were 12 of 29 against the Jayhawks. Key moment Issacs' back-to-back 3s early in the second half stemmed Kansas' comeback attempt, putting the Bluejays up 49-40. Key stat Greg McDermott, the Bluejays' career coaching wins leader and a former coach at Iowa State, won for the first time in his 11 games against Kansas. Up next Kansas: At Missouri on Sunday. KANSAS CITY, Mo. -- — Zeke Mayo hit five 3s and scored 26 points, Hunter Dickinson had 21 points and 14 rebounds, and No. 10 Kansas bounced back from consecutive losses with a 75-60 rout of NC State on Saturday. Dajuan Harris Jr. added 15 points and six assists for the Jayhawks (8-2), who scored the first 15 points of the game but didn't have it in hand until midway through the second half, when Dickinson scored eight consecutive points to bury the Wolfpack. Kansas won its 20th consecutive nonconference home game and avoided its first three-game skid since the 2022-23 season. Ben Middlebrooks had 14 points and Brandon Huntley-Hatfield finished with 12 for the Wolfpack (7-4), who have lost their last 13 games to Kansas since winning their first matchup at Allen Fieldhouse on Dec. 20, 1958. Takeaways NC State was able to get the Kansas big men into foul trouble, and that allowed Middlebrooks to have success. But the Wolfpack didn't get enough production from the perimeter, where Dontrez Styles and Marcus Hill struggled. Kansas proved it could survive foul trouble in the paint. Dickinson had three fouls and KJ Adams Jr. and Flory Bidunga four apiece with 12 minutes left. But the Jayhawks' guards, and Mayo in particular, were able to take over the game. Key moment The Jayhawks led 48-41 with 13:10 left when Mayo rattled in a 3-pointer from the corner. He added a free throw moments later, then a blow-by layup, giving Kansas a 54-41 lead with 12 minutes to go. Key stat 5 — Harris hit a layup with 18:14 left to give him 1,001 points for his career. He's the fifth member of the team to surpass that plateau, joining Mayo, Dickinson, David Coit and Shakeel Moore. Up next NC State plays Rider on Dec. 22. Kansas plays Brown the same day. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 all season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2024-12-31 - Kansas: 61 vs West Virginia: 62

LAWRENCE, Kan. -- — Javon Small hit the go-ahead free throw with 1.8 seconds remaining, and short-handed West Virginia held on after blowing an 18-point second-half lead to beat seventh-ranked Kansas 62-61 in an intense Big 12 opener for both teams Tuesday. Eduardo Andre had 15 points and Small finished with 13 for the Mountaineers (10-2, 1-0), who built a 38-20 lead despite missing two of their three leading scorers to injuries, only to watch Kansas (9-3, 0-1) use a 15-2 run to get back in the game. Zeke Mayo, who led the Jayhawks with 27 points, converted a three-point play to tie the game 61-all with 16 seconds left. Small was fouled by Kansas freshman Flory Bidunga at the other end and made the second of two free throws, and KJ Adams missed a contested shot as time expired that would have sent the game to overtime. It was the first conference-opening loss for Kansas since Jan. 8, 1991, and the first win for the Mountaineers in 12 tries in Allen Fieldhouse. They had lost six of their last seven games to the Jayhawks. Takeaways West Virginia played its fourth game without star forward Tucker DeVries and also was missing big man Amani Hansberry to an ankle injury. But the Mountaineers committed just six turnovers while never getting rattled by the noise in the Phog. Kansas missed 15 of its first 19 shots, digging a hole that it spend the entire game trying to escape. Mayo gave the Jayhawks a chance, going 13 for 13 at the foul line, including several of them in the closing minutes. Key moment Small struggled from the field, going 0 for 6 from the 3-point arc. But he also had 11 rebounds and six assists, and he made the free throw that mattered with 1.8 seconds to go. Key stat Kansas went 19 of 21 from the foul line. West Virginia only attempted six free throws, making four — including the winner. Up next West Virginia plays Oklahoma State on Saturday. profile_summary: Kansas enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 7-seed with a 21-13 record — a résumé that reflects a team of genuine talent that never fully put it together for a sustained stretch. Against ranked opponents, the Jayhawks went 6-9, with notable wins over #9 North Carolina, #11 Duke, #11 Michigan State, #8 Iowa State, and #24 Arizona, but damaging losses to Creighton (unranked at the time), Missouri (unranked), #2 Iowa State, #7 Houston (twice), #10 Texas Tech, and others. In the final five games of available summaries — a 96-64 demolition of Oklahoma State, a gutsy 71-64 road win at Colorado behind Hunter Dickinson's 32 points, a 73-78 home loss to Texas Tech that featured another Kansas collapse after tying the game late, a 59-65 road loss at #3 Houston in a competitive but ultimately losing effort, an 83-76 home win over #24 Arizona fueled by Dickinson's career-high-matching 33 points and five Mayo threes, and a Big 12 Tournament quarterfinal loss to Arizona 88-77 — Kansas looks like a team that is dangerous and maddening in equal measure: capable of beating anyone on a given night, yet persistently unable to impose its will consistently. The Jayhawks are defined by the Hunter Dickinson-Zeke Mayo tandem; Dickinson is posting double-doubles at will (15 on the season), with a peak that includes back-to-back elite performances of 32 and 33 points to close the regular season, while Mayo provides perimeter firepower and clutch shot-making, most recently erupting for 20 points on five threes against Arizona. KJ Adams Jr. offers a reliable third option when healthy, though his partially separated shoulder mid-season created real interior depth concerns alongside freshman Flory Bidunga's injury absences. Kansas plays an identity-shifting style — at its best, it wins with a dominant interior presence, sharp ball movement (14 assists against one first-half turnover versus Arizona), and lockdown second-half defense; at its worst, it hemorrhages turnovers (22 against Missouri, 20 forced by Houston), collapses under full-court pressure (the historic 21-point blown lead at Baylor), and disappears offensively for long stretches. The Jayhawks are a markedly better team at home — winning 42 consecutive home finales and posting dominant results in Allen Fieldhouse — but have been inconsistent and frequently outworked on the road, losing at Creighton, Missouri, Iowa State, Utah, and BYU by a combined margin that suggests genuine road fragility. In a neutral-site tournament environment, the early-season Champions Classic wins over North Carolina and Michigan State indicate this group can elevate for big moments, though the Big 12 Tournament exit to Arizona at a neutral site introduces doubt. The bottom line: Kansas is a genuinely dangerous 7-seed — Dickinson at his peak is an elite-level force, Mayo can get hot from three at any moment, and this team has the résumé wins to prove it can compete with anyone — but the chronic inconsistency, turnover issues, collapse-prone tendencies, and road struggles make a run beyond the Sweet 16 a tall order. **Realistic tournament ceiling: Sweet 16**, with a credible upset threat in the first two rounds and the talent to surprise, but too prone to self-destruction to project deeper with confidence.

2024-11-07 - Arkansas: 76 vs Lipscomb: 60

FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. -- — John Calipari won his debut as Arkansas coach when the 16th-ranked Razorbacks held off a second-half rally by Lipscomb and pulled away for a 76-60 victory Wednesday night. Freshman guard Boogie Fland scored 17 points and Florida Atlantic transfer Johnell Davis added 15 for Arkansas. Calipari, who left Southeastern Conference rival Kentucky after last season, had previously been booed incessantly whenever stepping foot in Bud Walton Arena. That all changed when Eric Musselman, who coached Arkansas to three Sweet 16s in five seasons, departed last spring and Calipari bolted from the bluegrass of Kentucky for the foothills of the Ozarks. His new team looked a lot like his old ones. Lipscomb (1-1), the Atlantic Sun preseason favorite, put a scare into the Razorbacks (1-0) with a second-half run to pull within four points with just under seven minutes to play. Arkansas had led by 15 in the second half. Zvonimir Ivisic, one of seven players to make their Razorbacks debut Wednesday, hit a 3-pointer, a layup and two free throws in the span of a minute to stop the Bisons. Ivisic finished with 12 points. Jacob Ognacevic led Lipscomb with 16. Takeaways Lipscomb: The Bisons put up enough of a fight to suggest their projection as A-Sun champions is not farfetched. Arkansas: The Razorbacks might be as deep as any team in the country and the statistical totals backed that up. Calipari & Co. will need time to coalesce, but the team looks to be as dangerous as expected. Key moment Arkansas closed the first half on a 10-2 run to build a 39-28 lead at halftime. Key stats Arkansas outscored the Bisons 23-5 on fast-break points and 54-24 in the paint. The Razorbacks shot 68% inside the 3-point line, offsetting a 4-of-19 performance from beyond the arc. Up next Lipscomb hosts Wofford on Saturday. Arkansas gets its first power-conference challenge of the season Saturday when the Razorbacks travel to Dallas for a neutral-site game against No. 8 Baylor, which is coming off a 101-63 loss at No. 6 Gonzaga. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. 2025-03-12 - Arkansas: 72 vs South Carolina: 68

NASHVILLE, Tenn. -- — Trevon Brazile had 16 points, seven rebounds and four blocks, Johnell Davis scored six key points in the final 40 seconds and No. 9 seed Arkansas nearly blew a 20-point lead before holding off No. 16 seed South Carolina 72-68 on Wednesday to begin the SEC Tournament. Arkansas (20-12) will play a second-round game against No. 8 seed Ole Miss on Thursday. The then-13th ranked Rebels won the only regular-season meeting 73-66 on Jan. 8. Arkansas led by as many as 20 points early in the second half and it was 59-41 with 14:18 left. But the Razorback missed their next 12 shots over 11-plus minutes as South Carolina pulled within 61-60 following a 19-2 run that was capped by Collin Murray-Boyles’ jumper from the free-throw line. D.J. Wagner finally ended Arkansas' field-goal drought with 2:37 left on a 3-pointer following an offensive rebound to make it 64-60, and Brazile added a tip-in shot on the next possession. Arkansas’ first miss from the free-throw line in 14 attempts came with 14 seconds left and South Carolina quickly went the other way for a layup by Jacobi Wright to cut the deficit to 70-66. After a timeout, Arkansas turned it over near midcourt when Murray-Boyles jumped to deflect a pass and Cam Scott threw down a dunk with 3.2 left for a two-point game. Davis secured the inbounds pass and sealed it with two free throws at 2.5. Davis and Jonas Aidoo each scored 14 points for Arkansas. Wagner had 13 points and six assists. Murray-Boyles led South Carolina (12-20) with 20 points and 12 rebounds. Jamarii Thomas added 16 points and Wright had 13. Aidoo scored a game-high 14 points in the first half and Arkansas closed on an 11-0 run to build a 47-30 at the break. Arkansas avenged a 72-53 loss to South Carolina on March 1. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 all season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2025-03-13 - Ole Miss: 83 vs Arkansas: 80

NASHVILLE, Tenn. -- — Sean Pedulla sank a long 3-pointer with 1.3 seconds left after two missed two free throws at the other end to give No. 8 seed Mississippi an 83-80 victory over ninth-seeded Arkansas on Thursday in the second round of the SEC Tournament. Arkansas forward Trevon Brazile was at the free-throw line with 7.4 seconds left after he was fouled going for an offensive rebound. He missed both free throws and Dre Davis grabbed the defensive rebound. Davis passed it ahead to Pedulla, who dribbled up the court for a shot well behind the arc for a go-ahead 3-pointer. Billy Richmond III had a decent look from midcourt at the buzzer that bounced hard off the backboard and rim. It was Pedulla's only made 3-pointer in seven tries. Arkansas finished 21 of 32 at the free-throw line. Ole Miss (22-10) advances to play top-seeded Auburn in the quarterfinals on Friday. Malik Dia led Ole Miss with 19 points and eight rebounds and Jaylen Murray added 17. Pedulla was 4 of 12 from the field for 10 points. Jonas Aidoo had 17 points and eight rebounds for Arkansas (20-13) before picking up his fifth foul with 4:44 remaining. Brazile had 15 points and 11 rebounds, Richmond also scored 15 and Karter Knox 14. Arkansas trailed 42-27 with 1:25 left in the first half before taking over during a 34-11 run for a 61-53 lead with 9:35 remaining in the second. Knox and Richmond combined to make six straight free throws to put Arkansas ahead 78-77 with 1:23 left. Pedulla had an open look from 3-point range that didn’t drop but he got another chance after Dia grabbed an offensive rebound. Then Pedulla had it stolen by Arkansas guard Johnell Davis, who called a timeout with 50.5 left. D.J. Wagner sank a shot on the left side of the lane while fading away to put Arkansas ahead 80-77 with 29.6 left and Dre Davis tied it at 20.7 with a three-point play. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. profile_summary: Arkansas enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 10-seed with a 22-14 record — a résumé built on remarkable resilience and genuine big-game upside, but undercut by chronic inconsistency and a brutal 0-5 start to SEC play. Against ranked opponents, the Razorbacks went 5-10, with signature wins over #12 Kentucky (89-79 in Lexington), #15 Missouri (92-85), #8 Texas (78-70 on the road), and #14 Michigan (89-87 at Madison Square Garden) — victories that collectively validate their tournament credentials. However, blowout losses to #1 Tennessee (76-52), #23 Ole Miss (73-66 at home), and South Carolina (72-53 in a historically ugly first half) reveal a team capable of going completely flat without warning. Their final five games tell a story of streaky survival: a gutsy 93-92 home thriller over Mississippi State, a dominant 90-77 road win at Vanderbilt, a 72-53 demolition at the hands of South Carolina in which they didn't reach 15 first-half points, and then a narrow SEC Tournament win over South Carolina before bowing out on Sean Pedulla's buzzer-beating 3-pointer against Ole Miss — missing two free throws in the final seconds that would have closed the game. Stylistically, Arkansas is a team of explosive offensive runs and dangerous collapses: they can reel off 18-0 stretches one moment and go scoreless for 11-plus minutes the next, making them both exciting and terrifying to watch. The offensive engine runs through Adou Thiero (15.6 PPG, 55% shooter), who is nursing a knee injury that cost him the last three regular-season games and whose availability is the single biggest question mark entering the tournament, along with the dynamic duo of Johnell Davis — who delivered a season-high 24 points at Texas — and Zvonimir Ivisic, the 7-foot-2 sophomore who erupted for 27 against Alabama and 25 against LSU. Boogie Fland provides playmaking and clutch shot-making (the Miami comeback, the Michigan rally), while D.J. Wagner, Karter Knox, and Trevon Brazile give Arkansas the kind of depth that can overwhelm mid-major opponents. The Razorbacks play with unmistakable fight — they came back from 15 down against Georgia, erased a 14-point deficit against Texas in overtime, and rallied from 15 down against Michigan — but they are equally prone to jaw-dropping disengagement, as evidenced by allowing 21-6 opening runs against Illinois and 18-0 Missouri bursts. Location matters: Arkansas is measurably better at home (where they swept Texas, beat Missouri, and closed strong) and on neutral sites (the Michigan win, the Miami road finish), but have been consistently vulnerable on the road in hostile SEC venues. This is a dangerous, high-ceiling 10-seed with multiple ranked wins, a physically imposing frontcourt, and the offensive firepower to beat anyone on a given night — but Thiero's health, their free-throw unreliability in crunch time (Brazile's two missed FTs against Ole Miss being the defining image of this team's tournament fate), and their well-documented tendency to disappear for extended stretches make a Sweet 16 run the realistic ceiling, with a first-round upset entirely plausible and a second-round exit the most likely outcome.

Texas (19-14) came in as the SEC's No. 13 seed with the Longhorns needing victories to play their way into the NCAA Tournament. They will face No. 4 seed and eighth-ranked Tennessee on Friday. Johnson finished with 20 points. Tramon Mark had 15, Kadin Shedrick added 14 and Jordan Pope had 13 for Texas. Mark's short jumper hit off the rim just before the buzzer to force overtime and a thrilling finish. Wade Taylor IV led the Aggies (22-10) with 29 points and was 17 for 18 at the free throw line, becoming the SEC's career tournament scoring leader. Manny Obaseki had 17 before fouling out. Aderss Garcia added 13 and Henry Coleman III had 10 points and 13 rebounds. Takeaways Texas: The Longhorns came to Nashville having lost four of their last five trying to stay on the tournament bubble and likely needing wins to save coach Rodney Terry’s job. This should help now they've won two of their last three. Texas A&M: The Aggies are an SEC-best 7-3 over the past three SEC tourneys, reaching the 2022 and 2023 finals. They lost in the semifinals last year. Five Aggies have played nine or more SEC tournament games, led by Hayden Hefner in his fifth year. Key moment Shedrick's dunk with 4.6 seconds left in the first overtime forced another five minutes of play for Texas. Key stat Texas A&M missed seven of their last eight shots in the second overtime. Up next The Longhorns lost to Tennessee by four in January. The Aggies now wait for their NCAA Tournament slot. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. profile_summary:
Texas A&M enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 4-seed with a 23-11 record — a résumé built on elite defense, dominant rebounding, and enough star power to beat anyone on a given night, but also carrying the scars of a late-season collapse that raises legitimate durability questions. Against ranked opponents, the Aggies went an impressive 9-8, with signature wins over No. 1 Auburn (83-72 at home), No. 11 Purdue (70-66 in Indianapolis), No. 17 Oklahoma on the road in a stunning 18-point comeback, No. 15 Missouri on a buzzer-beater Wade Taylor IV 3-pointer, and No. 21 Creighton at a neutral site — a collection of victories that confirms this team can compete at the highest level. However, they also dropped games to No. 5 Alabama, No. 6 Kentucky, No. 6 Tennessee, and No. 3 Florida, with the four-game losing skid from late February through early March — losses to Mississippi State, Tennessee, Vanderbilt, and Florida by a combined 53 points — exposing real vulnerabilities in offensive consistency, particularly from three-point range and at the free-throw line. Their final five games told the full story of this team's Jekyll-and-Hyde nature: a stunning upset of top-ranked Auburn (83-72), a wire-to-wire road win at LSU (66-52) to close the regular season on a high note, and then a gut-punch SEC Tournament exit at the hands of 13-seed Texas, who erased a 22-point second-half deficit in double overtime — a collapse that encapsulates this team's most troubling tendency.

Stylistically, Texas A&M wins through relentless rebounding — they lead the nation in offensive rebounds and routinely post 20-plus second-chance point advantages — suffocating defense that has held every opponent below their season scoring average, and clutch individual performances from their two-headed offensive engine. Wade Taylor IV, the program's all-time leading scorer who battled through a knee injury that cost him three SEC games in January, is the unquestioned heartbeat of this offense; when healthy and locked in, he is capable of 29-point tournament performances as he showed in the SEC Tournament loss to Texas, going 17-of-18 from the line. Zhuric Phelps, the SMU transfer, is arguably the team's most dynamic offensive option off the bench, having dropped a career-high 34 points in a road comeback win at Oklahoma and adding 19 points in the Auburn upset. Role players like Henry Coleman III, Pharrel Payne, Andersson Garcia, and Manny Obaseki provide genuine depth, with Coleman shooting 77.7% in the Players Era Festival and Obaseki delivering a tournament-winning corner 3 at Ole Miss. The concern, however, is that this team shoots a paltry three-point percentage — worst in the SEC — and has repeatedly gone cold at the worst moments, including missing their final 11 shots against Oregon in November and going 4-of-24 from three in a win over Oklahoma where they survived on rebounding alone. They play with genuine toughness and resilience — the Oklahoma comeback from 18 down without Taylor was one of the season's most impressive performances nationally — but the Texas collapse in the SEC Tournament, where they blew a 22-point lead in regulation and then missed seven of their last eight shots in the second overtime, is impossible to ignore. At home, they went 12-1 and are a different team entirely; on the road and at neutral sites, they are 7-8 and prone to offensive droughts that their defense cannot always compensate for. Texas A&M is a legitimate Elite Eight threat with the tools to make a Final Four run — their rebounding edge, defensive identity, and star power give them a viable path against almost anyone — but their three-point shooting fragility, late-game collapse history, and the psychological shadow of their SEC Tournament implosion make a national title run unrealistic. **Realistic ceiling: Elite Eight**, with a Sweet 16 exit being the most probable outcome if their offense goes cold at the wrong moment.

profile_summary: Yale enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 13-seed with a 22-8 record, a résumé built almost entirely on Ivy League dominance but tested — and found wanting — against high-major competition. The Bulldogs went 1-3 against Power conference opponents in the non-conference slate, losing to UIC (91-79), Purdue (92-84), Minnesota (59-56), and Rhode Island (84-78), while falling in a heartbreaker to UTEP (75-74) at a neutral site — a loss that exposes a team that can compete with better competition but has not yet demonstrated the ability to close out quality opponents. Against ranked competition, Yale's lone notable data point is a competitive showing at then-No. 13 Purdue, where they lost by eight despite winning the paint 50-24, a game that revealed both their interior toughness and their fatal perimeter limitations (8-of-26 from three against the Boilermakers). Their record against ranked or high-major opponents is effectively 0-5, a sobering reality for a team otherwise riding a wave of Ivy League momentum. Yale did own the nation's longest active winning streak at 13 games at one point, going a perfect 13-0 in Ivy play before dropping a late regular-season game at Harvard (74-69) — a loss that briefly raised questions before the Bulldogs rebounded to win the Ivy League Tournament, edging Princeton 59-57 on a Poulakidas three-pointer with 62 seconds left and defeating Cornell 90-84 in the championship. Their final five games — wins over Brown (70-61), Princeton (59-57), and Cornell (90-84), sandwiched around a loss at Harvard — reflect a team that is capable but vulnerable to pressure moments, winning two of those three games by margins of two and six points respectively, never quite pulling away comfortably. Yale is a high-scoring, multi-creator offense — John Poulakidas (the engine, capable of 23-32 point explosions), Nick Townsend (a reliable double-double threat inside), Bez Mbeng (a triple-double-capable playmaker), and Casey Simmons (a secondary scorer who has stepped up when needed) give them legitimate offensive depth — but their three-point shooting is wildly inconsistent, ranging from historic (Poulakidas going 6-of-7 from deep vs. Fairfield) to alarming (8-of-26 vs. Purdue, 1-of-4 vs. Dartmouth). The Bulldogs play with genuine energy and resilience — they have twice rallied or held on in nail-biters in the Ivy Tournament — but they have also shown a tendency to go cold from the perimeter at the worst moments, and their composure late in games against quality opponents (the Harvard and Minnesota losses, the UTEP near-miss) suggests a team that competes hard but lacks the elite execution needed to consistently finish. Yale plays better at home (where they rolled through the Ivy schedule) and has been inconsistent on the road and at neutral sites, going 0-3 in true road or neutral losses of consequence. **Verdict**: Yale is a dangerous but limited 13-seed — a team capable of making the first round uncomfortable for a 4-seed with their offensive firepower and battle-tested Ivy Tournament experience, but realistically a **first-round exit**. Their non-conference record against quality opposition (0-5) and chronic perimeter inconsistency make a second-round run highly unlikely against the caliber of opponent they will face in the bracket.

name: Missouri
summaries:
2024-11-05 - Memphis: 83 vs Missouri: 75

MEMPHIS, Tenn. -- — PJ Haggerty scored 22 of his 25 points in the second half when Memphis took over en route to an 83-75 win over Missouri in the season opener for both teams on Monday night. The Tigers trailed by 10 at halftime but shot 58% in the second half, while going 17-20 from the foul line. Mizzou made just 15 of 23 at the line. Tyrese Hunter and Moussa Cisse added 14 points apiece, nine each in the second half, and Colby Rogers scored 10. Anthony Robinson II led Missouri with 16 points, while Tamar Bates and Trent Pierce both had 13 and Aidan Shaw 10. Memphis only returned 8% of of its scoring after losing 14 players off of last year's roster and brought in 11 transfers, including Haggerty from Tulsa, Hunter from Texas, Cisse from Mississippi and Rogers from Wichita State. SMU transfer Tyrek Smith announced before the game he would be transferring without playing a game. Haggerty had five points to start a 16-2 run that turned an 11-point deficit into a 58-55 lead midway through the second half. He had 10 points in the surge. and another nine points in an 11-3 run that stretched the lead to 71-62 with 3:46 to play. Memphis has won seven straight season openers and 22 straight home openers. profile_summary: Missouri enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 6-seed with a 22-12 record — a résumé that reflects genuine quality and marquee wins, though significant late-season turbulence clouds their outlook. Against ranked opponents, the Tigers went an impressive 7-7, with standout victories over No. 1 Kansas (76-67), No. 5 Florida on the road (83-82), No. 4 Alabama at home (110-98), and No. 14 Mississippi State on the road (88-61) — a collection of wins that would make any program proud. However, Missouri's final five games tell a sobering story: losses at Arkansas (92-85), at Oklahoma (96-84), and at home to Kentucky (91-83) — surrendering an average of 94.7 points per game over that three-game skid — were followed by an SEC Tournament win over Mississippi State (85-73) and a 95-81 quarterfinal loss to Florida in which leading scorer Mark Mitchell sat out with a knee injury. That injury to Mitchell is arguably the most critical variable entering the bracket; he is listed as available for tournament play but carries a health question mark after being held out in Nashville. Missouri plays a high-octane offensive style capable of erupting for 100-plus points — as demonstrated in the Alabama blowout — and relies heavily on 3-point shooting, going 12-0 this season when making at least eight threes, but that same perimeter dependence became a liability in losses to Texas (4-of-20 from deep) and Tennessee. The Tigers are powered by a veteran core: Tamar Bates (multiple 20-plus point performances), Caleb Grill (a graduate student who delivered 22 points at Florida and 28 in overtime at Vanderbilt), and Mitchell (career-high 31 against Alabama), while Anthony Robinson II and Tony Perkins provide reliable secondary production. Missouri was a dominant 18-1 at home, demonstrating elite comfort in Columbia, but struggled to replicate that energy on the road, losing six road games outright and showing a worrying tendency to surrender leads and allow opponents to shoot efficiently against them in hostile environments — the Oklahoma rematch, in which the Sooners shot 69% in the first half of a game Missouri won by 24 points just weeks earlier, is a cautionary tale. The Tigers are scrappy and resilient when engaged, evidenced by the comeback win over Cal (erasing a 16-point deficit) and the gutsy Florida road win on Grill's late free throws, but they are also collapse-prone and defensively porous in stretches, allowing three straight opponents to score 85-plus to close the regular season. On neutral sites, their limited sample — the SEC Tournament — showed they can compete (beating Mississippi State) but also exposed their vulnerability without Mitchell against a top-tier Florida team. Missouri's tournament ceiling is a Sweet 16 run if Mitchell is healthy and their three-point shooting is clicking: they have more than enough star power, big-game experience, and offensive firepower to knock off a higher seed or two, but their defensive inconsistency, late-season losing streak, and road struggles make a run deeper than the Elite Eight highly unlikely against the elite competition that awaits.
