2025-03-09 - Drake: 63 vs Bradley: 48
profile_summary: Drake enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as an 11-seed with a remarkable 31-4 record — a résumé that demands respect despite the mid-major label. The Bulldogs won the Missouri Valley Conference outright for the first time since 2007-08 and set a program record for wins in a single season. Their most impressive non-conference scalps came at the Charleston Classic, where they defeated ACC opponent Miami 80-69 and beat Vanderbilt 81-70 to win the tournament title, plus a dramatic overtime win at Kansas State 73-70 in which Bennett Stirtz hit the game-winner with 3.4 seconds left — genuine quality wins that demonstrate this team can compete against high-major opposition. Their four losses came against UIC (on the road), Murray State, Bradley (twice, including a late-season home upset), suggesting occasional vulnerability against physical, well-coached mid-majors who can match their intensity, though Drake avenged all four of those losses. Entering the NCAA Tournament, Drake is playing as well as any team in the country at the mid-major level: their final five games produced wins over Northern Iowa (64-58 OT), Evansville (65-61), Missouri State (68-60 OT), and then back-to-back dominant MVC Tournament victories over Southern Illinois (70-53) and Belmont (57-50) before dismantling Bradley 63-48 in the championship — a statement win against the team that handed them two of their four losses. That conference tournament run showed a team that can win grinding defensive battles as comfortably as they can win shootouts, and the Bradley blowout in the final was a clear message of peak form at exactly the right time. Drake's identity is multidimensional but anchored by Bennett Stirtz, the MVC Player of the Year, who has been spectacular down the stretch — posting 26 points and 10 rebounds in the Northern Iowa overtime win, 24 points in the Belmont semifinal, and consistently delivering in clutch moments all season long. Stirtz is the engine: a relentless creator who scores, distributes, rebounds, and steals, capable of 30-point outbursts as easily as 14-point workhorse efforts. Around him, Mitch Mascari is a dangerous floor-spacing shooter who hit eight threes against Kansas State, Daniel Abreu has been a reliable secondary scorer and rebounder, and Tavion Banks provides a physical, high-efficiency punch off the bench. The team's composure in overtime situations — winning five extra-period games across the season — speaks to a mature, resilient group that does not panic when games get tight. Defensively, Drake entered the year ranked fourth nationally in scoring defense, and that identity has held: opponents routinely struggle to crack 60 against them, and the Bulldogs rarely get blown out. On neutral sites specifically, Drake is outstanding — the Charleston Classic title, the MVC Tournament title, and the Kansas City overtime win collectively show a team that thrives away from home on the biggest stages, which is the exact environment the NCAA Tournament provides. The realistic ceiling for this Drake team is the Sweet 16, with a legitimate path to the Elite Eight if the bracket sets up favorably: they are disciplined, deep, battle-tested, led by a legitimate star in Stirtz, and playing their best basketball right now — a dangerous 11-seed capable of pulling off multiple upsets, but likely lacking the raw athleticism to sustain a Final Four run against blue-blood programs.

name: UCLA
summaries:
2024-11-05 - UCLA: 85 vs Rider: 50

LOS ANGELES -- — Tyler Bilodeau scored 18 points in his UCLA debut after transferring from Oregon State, and the 22nd-ranked Bruins routed Rider 85-50 on Monday night in their season opener. Dylan Andrews added 14 points and six assists. Kobe Johnson, who transferred from crosstown-rival USC, had 12 points and eight rebounds. T.J. Weeks Jr. led Rider with 15 points, hitting a game-high four 3-pointers. The Bruins led all the way, running off 10 straight points to end the first half ahead 41-23. Bilodeau got hot to start the second half, scoring 10 points in the first five minutes to extend UCLA’s lead to 53-32. UCLA got six 3-pointers from five different players in the second half. Andrews' 3 pushed the lead to 78-46. Takeaways Rider: The Broncs stayed within single digits in the opening minutes, but couldn't keep up with the Bruins' talent level. UCLA: The Bruins added nine new players — six transfers and three freshmen. Eleven players saw action and all but two of them scored. Eric Dailey Jr. out of Oklahoma State had a strong first half and finished with nine points and eight rebounds to go with four fouls. Key moment UCLA's 7-foot-3 center Aday Mara and Rider's 7-2 Alaaeddine Boutayeb went against each other at times. Boutayeb, who is from Morocco, finished with 14 points and two rebounds. Mara from Spain had five points and two rebounds. Key stat UCLA dominated nearly every statistical category. But the Broncs were better in one area: offensive rebounds (18-15). Up next The Broncs stay out West to face San Diego on Wednesday in the second of seven straight road games to begin the season. The Bruins travel to suburban Las Vegas for a neutral-court game against New Mexico on Friday. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2024-11-09 - UCLA: 64 vs New Mexico: 72

HENDERSON, Nev. -- — Donovan Dent had 17 points and eight assists, Nelly Junior Joseph added 16 points and 12 rebounds for his 45th career double-double, and New Mexico beat No. 22 UCLA 72-64 on Friday night in the Las Vegas Hoopfest. It was New Mexico's first win against a ranked team in nonconference play since beating current UCLA coach Mick Cronin while he was at Cincinnati during the 2012-13 season. CJ Noland added 13 points for the Lobos (2-0). Junior Joseph was one of three New Mexico players with a double-double in a season-opening victory over Nicholls on Monday. Tyler Bilodeau, a transfer from Oregon State, had 23 points and 15 rebounds for UCLA (1-1), which opened its season with an 85-50 win over Rider on Monday. New Mexico held the Bruins to 1-for-9 shooting from the field over the first seven minutes of the second half to help extend its 11-point halftime lead to 49-33. New Mexico's 11th steal led to Tru Washington's fast-break dunk for a 58-43 cushion. The Lobos led by at least eight the rest of the way. Takeaways New Mexico stayed hot in Nevada. The game was played at Lee’s Family Forum in Henderson, just minutes from where the Lobos beat San Diego State 68-61 in the championship game of the Mountain West Conference Tournament last season at the Thomas & Mack Center in Las Vegas. Key moment Dent slipped on the court with 7:52 remaining on an inbounds pass with the Lobos leading 62-48. He went to the locker room and UCLA took advantage by switching to a pressure defense while New Mexico's star point guard was out. Dent returned at the 5:39 mark with a wrap on his left leg and scored on his first offensive possession to restore a double-digit lead at 68-57. Key stat New Mexico turned good defense into offense by scoring 21 points off 21 UCLA turnovers. Up next UCLA returns home to face Boston University on Monday. New Mexico hosts Texas A&M-Corpus Christi on Tuesday. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP collegebasketball: and

The Bruins used a 22-3 run over the end of the first half and start of the second to take a 50-22 lead. Six different players scored, including Kobe Johnson who had four points in the spurt. profile_summary:
UCLA enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 7-seed with a 23-11 record — a résumé that reflects genuine Big Ten competitiveness but also troubling inconsistency at the worst possible times. Against ranked opponents, the Bruins went an impressive 7-5, with signature wins over then-No. 12 Oregon (on a Dylan Andrews buzzer-bank), then-No. 14 Gonzaga (a clutch late-game surge), then-No. 18 Wisconsin (twice), then-No. 16 Oregon (a dominant 26-point blowout), and then-No. 9 Michigan State (on an Eric Dailey Jr. go-ahead bucket with 7 seconds left) — but losses to Michigan (19 points), Maryland (18 points), and Nebraska at home highlight a team that can be exposed when road-weary or defensively vulnerable. Their final five games tell a complicated story: a 90-63 blowout of USC to close the regular season was followed by a 16-point demolition at the hands of Wisconsin in the Big Ten Tournament, leaving the Bruins going 3-2 over that stretch with a 4-4 record across their final eight games — hardly the momentum a bubble-adjacent team wants entering March. UCLA is a schizophrenic team stylistically: capable of wire-to-wire domination at home (finishing 15-2 at Pauley Pavilion) and genuinely clutch in close games (8-3 in games decided by five or fewer points), but alarmingly collapse-prone on the road and dangerously susceptible to hot three-point shooting, as Wisconsin exposed them twice — most recently shooting 19-of-whatever from deep for an 86-70 rout.

The Bruins' identity runs through Eric Dailey Jr., who has emerged as the team's most reliable playmaker down the stretch, posting a career-high 25 points against USC and consistently delivering in big moments, while Tyler Bilodeau remains the offensive fulcrum with a team-leading scoring average and key contributions in multiple ranked wins — though his ankle injury in late January is worth monitoring. Sebastian Mack off the bench provides elite scoring punch, Aday Mara has developed into a legitimate interior force (7-of-7 from the field in the Wisconsin regular-season win), and Skyy Clark provides clutch free-throw execution and three-point efficiency. The team's early-season defensive identity — ranking No. 1 nationally in scoring defense at one point, holding opponents to 55 points per game — has eroded as Big Ten play wore on, and their three-point defense in particular is a glaring vulnerability that any tournament opponent with perimeter shooters will target immediately. UCLA is undeniably a better team at home, and their neutral-site record (3-3) is mixed — they knocked off Gonzaga in Inglewood but lost to North Carolina at MSG and were dismantled in Indianapolis — raising real concerns about replicating their best basketball in a tournament setting. Mick Cronin's team has the veteran clutch gene and ranked-win credibility to be a dangerous 7-seed capable of knocking off a 2-seed in an upset, but the Big Ten Tournament exit, persistent road struggles (6-8 away from home), defensive breakdowns against elite perimeter teams, and late-season inconsistency all cap this team's realistic ceiling at the **Sweet 16** — a dangerous, experienced squad that can beat anyone on a given night, but lacks the sustained elite-level execution required for a Final Four run.

profile_summary:
Utah State enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 10-seed with a 26-8 record — a résumé that reflects a genuinely good Mountain West program capable of beating quality opponents, but one that has shown real vulnerability down the stretch. The Aggies made national noise early, rattling off a 10-0 start that included a notable neutral-site win over Iowa in the Hall of Fame Classic, where Mason Falslev dropped 25 points and 12 rebounds to close out the Hawkeyes 77-69. Against ranked and quality competition, Utah State showed flashes of legitimacy — they knocked off Saint Mary's on the road in December and handled San Diego State twice — but repeated losses to New Mexico (63-82 at home, 79-82 on the road) and a late-season beatdown at Colorado State (66-93) revealed that this team can get physically overwhelmed by elite-level opponents. In the Mountain West Tournament, they dispatched UNLV comfortably in the quarterfinals before being blown out early by Colorado State in the semis, trailing 49-30 at halftime and never recovering. Recent form is the central concern heading into the bracket: over their final five games, Utah State went 2-3, with the two wins coming against Air Force (87-47) and UNLV (70-58), while the losses came against San Diego State's road version, Boise State (65-82), Colorado State twice, and the MW semis — a skid that shows a team fading at precisely the wrong moment.

Stylistically, Utah State is at their best in high-scoring, multi-threat offensive environments where Ian Martinez can take over clutch situations — his 17 consecutive points to close out Nevada and his 4-point play with seven seconds left to beat Boise State 81-79 are emblematic of a team capable of dramatic, willed victories. Martinez is clearly the engine, capable of 30-point performances (Fresno State), but also capable of going cold (2-for-10 against St. Bonaventure) at critical moments. Falslev is a legitimate two-way weapon — his 27-point, 6-rebound, 5-steal effort in the MW semifinal loss showed he can perform on big stages even in defeat — and role players like Dexter Akanno and Karson Templin provide enough depth to keep opponents honest. The Aggies are resilient and capable of clutch comebacks, but they are also prone to getting physically dominated inside and defensively exposed when opponents attack the paint, as UNLV demonstrated by outscoring them 36-20 in the paint in their first meeting. Utah State plays noticeably better at home (strong against Montana, Wyoming, Boise State, Colorado State in the first meeting) and has shown enough on neutral sites to not be dismissed, but their road record features some ugly performances. As a 10-seed, they are dangerous enough to steal a first-round game — Martinez's shot-making ability alone makes them a threat in a single-elimination setting — but the late-season defensive lapses, susceptibility to dominant big men, and repeated struggles against top-half Mountain West competition suggest a Sweet 16 run is a ceiling, not an expectation. **Realistic tournament ceiling: Round of 32, with a puncher's chance at the Sweet 16 if Martinez gets hot at the right moment.**

NASSAU, Bahamas -- — Jeremy Roach made a 3-pointer at the buzzer, and No. 13. Baylor rallied from five points down in the final 18 seconds of the second overtime to beat No. 22 St. John's 99-98 on Thursday night at the Baha Mar Championship. 2025-03-15 - St. John's: 82 vs Creighton: 66

NEW YORK -- — Regular-season champs. A tournament title. Pride in the program fully restored. The pied piper of college basketball rebuilds, Rick Pitino has St. John's back atop the Big East. And this time, the nets were coming down. RJ Luis Jr. scored all but two of his 29 points after halftime and No. 6 St. John's made 14 straight shots from the field in the second half to beat Creighton 82-66 on Saturday night for its first Big East Tournament title in 25 years. “Wow, this is incredible just to come from last year to this year and to see the transformation,” Luis said. “Coach P is the mastermind behind all of this. I mean, it’s truly special.” Zuby Ejiofor added 20 points and Kadary Richmond had 12 points and 12 rebounds for the top-seeded Red Storm (30-4), who reached 30 wins for the third time in program history before a roaring hometown crowd at sold-out Madison Square Garden. They earned the conference's automatic bid to the NCAA Tournament for their first trip since 2019, making the 72-year-old Pitino the first coach to take six schools to the Big Dance. The others were Boston University, Providence, Kentucky, Louisville and Iona. “Great win for the city. Great win for our university. You hear it all along that it’s New York’s team, and it truly is,” the Hall of Fame coach said. “As a New Yorker myself, I’m very, very proud that St. John’s has gotten to this level.” Pitino, in his second season with the Johnnies, also became the first coach to win the Big East Tournament at two schools. He’s won three times in his last four seasons in the league, after guiding Louisville to championships in 2009, 2012 and 2013. “I saved the best for last,” Pitino announced to loud cheers from the crowd of 19,812, pausing to remove falling confetti from his lips during a postgame interview on the court. Luis, the Big East Player of the Year, also grabbed 10 rebounds and was selected the tournament's Most Outstanding Player. He was draped in a Dominican Republic flag as fans chanted “MVP! MVP!” after the game. “Just still trying to soak it in, and it’s just crazy how much you can speak things into existence and just watch it all come together,” Luis said. “This has by far been the most emotional, happiest week of my 22 years of existence.” Ejiofor and Richmond made the All-Tournament team. “The three of them have been unstoppable,” Pitino said. Ryan Kalkbrenner scored 15 points for second-seeded Creighton (24-10), which fell to 0-5 in Big East championship games since joining the conference for the 2013-14 season. “It's hard to get to this game, let’s be honest,” coach Greg McDermott said. “We’ve been fortunate to be here quite a few times. Unfortunately, we haven’t been able to finish the job.” When the resurgent Johnnies clinched their first outright regular-season conference championship in 40 years with a victory over Seton Hall at The Garden on March 1, they had already decided not to cut down the nets to celebrate. More work to do. But on this night, players and staff climbed the ladder and snipped their souvenirs. It was the fourth Big East Tournament title for the Johnnies, who made the championship game for the first time since winning the 2000 trophy under Mike Jarvis. The previous two came in the 1980s under Hall of Fame coach Lou Carnesecca, who died Nov. 30 about five weeks shy of his 100th birthday. “To finally get over the hump, it’s really an unbelievable feeling,” Ejiofor said. “I’m so happy to be a part of history.” And after the Red Storm cut down the nets, a message appeared on the giant video screen above center court: “For Looie." “I’m thinking he would be so proud of this team,” said Pitino, who has quickly revived St. John's into a national power again late in his illustrious but checkered career. “Humility is a big part of my life right now. It wasn’t always that way,” he added. “I don’t believe in redemption. I believe in humility.” The drought between Big East Tournament titles for the Johnnies was the longest for any team in league history. “St. John’s didn’t get built by the NIL. St. John’s got built with character of the players," Pitino said. Luis was whistled for his second foul with 7:19 left before halftime and sat out the rest of the half. After falling behind by eight early, St. John’s finally took its first lead at 43-41 with 11:55 remaining when backup big man Vince Iwuchukwu scored left-handed in the post over the 7-foot-1 Kalkbrenner, the four-time Big East Defensive Player of the Year. That came 33 seconds after Ejiofor converted a tying three-point play that began a streak of 14 consecutive made field goals in 7:12 for the Red Storm, giving them a 70-55 lead. They connected on 17 of their final 19 field goal attempts to finish at 72% in the second period (23 for 32). Quite an offensive display for a team that entered the game shooting 45% from floor. “We definitely fed off the crowd, the energy, the atmosphere," Luis said. “It was ridiculous. It was very loud.” By the numbers St. John’s has won nine straight games, and 19 of 20 since the new year. The team finished 21-0 on its home courts, including 12-0 at MSG — the program’s most wins at The Garden since compiling 13 in 1958-59. The last time the Johnnies finished unbeaten at home was the 1931-32 season. Creighton injury Bluejays reserve Fedor Zugic injured his right ankle with 11:23 left in the first half and had to be helped off the court to the locker room. He didn’t return. Key stat Creighton, which entered shooting 74% on free throws, missed six of its first eight from the line and finished 8 for 16. Up next Creighton: Headed to its fifth straight NCAA Tournament when the brackets are revealed Sunday. St. John’s: Hasn’t won an NCAA Tournament game in 25 years. Pitino and the streaking Red Storm seem likely to receive a No. 2 seed Sunday. “We still have a lot to prove. We’re not done,” Ejiofor said. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 all season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and
profile_summary:
St. John's enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 2-seed with a 31-5 record and one of the most compelling resurgence stories in recent college basketball history — Big East regular-season champions, Big East Tournament champions, and winners of nine straight entering March Madness. Against ranked opponents, the Red Storm went an impressive 7-5, with marquee wins over No. 11 Marquette (twice), No. 19 UConn (twice), and No. 24 Creighton, while their losses came in genuinely competitive situations: a heartbreaking 99-98 double-overtime defeat to No. 13 Baylor on a buzzer-beater, a one-point loss at No. 24 Creighton on New Year's Eve, and a 73-71 defeat at Villanova when Tyler Perkins hit a go-ahead three with eight seconds left. Their final five games tell a story of a team absolutely peaking at the right moment: a buzzer-beating overtime win at Marquette (86-84) on Zuby Ejiofor's game-winner, followed by a Big East Tournament run in which they blew out Butler 78-57, erased a 15-point deficit to beat Marquette again 79-63, and then shot 72% in the second half to dismantle Creighton 82-66 in the championship game — RJ Luis Jr. dropping 29 points and winning tournament MVP. This team plays with layered, adaptable offensive firepower — capable of grinding out defensive victories, engineering dramatic comebacks (a 19-2 second-half run to beat Georgetown, a 16-point deficit erased against Xavier in overtime), and going on prolonged scoring runs (14 consecutive made field goals in the Big East title game) — and they are equally dangerous in close games and blowouts.

The engine of this team is a three-headed star group that would be the envy of any program in the country. Luis, the Big East Player of the Year, is logging double-doubles at a remarkable clip and delivering in the biggest moments — his 29-point, 10-rebound performance in the conference title game and 28-point, 11-rebound effort in overtime at Marquette demonstrate a player who elevates as the stakes rise. Ejiofor is perhaps the most dangerous complementary star in the country right now, setting a Big East Tournament record with 33 points against Marquette and delivering the buzzer-beater to win in Milwaukee; his physicality inside gives St. John's a matchup problem against virtually any opponent. Kadary Richmond posted the program's first triple-double this century (10 points, 12 rebounds, 11 assists) in that Marquette overtime win and is a force as a playmaker and rebounder at the guard position. The only meaningful health concern is point guard Deivon Smith, who has battled a shoulder injury and missed several games down the stretch, though he has returned and provides important ball-handling depth. Locationally, St. John's finished a perfect 21-0 at home — including 12-0 at Madison Square Garden — but also demonstrated genuine road and neutral-site toughness, winning at Georgetown, UConn, DePaul, and Butler, and going 3-1 on neutral courts including three straight Big East Tournament wins at MSG. This is a confident, battle-tested, deeply talented team with elite coaching, a proven ability to rally from double-digit deficits, and a roster built for March. Their realistic ceiling is the Final Four, with a credible case for the national championship game — the only question is whether Smith's health and a tendency to occasionally sleepwalk early (they trailed by 15 in both their Big East Tournament semifinal and final) could be exploited by a sufficiently physical elite opponent before they find their rhythm.

profile_summary:
Omaha enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 15-seed with a 22-13 record, but that record requires significant context. The Mavericks went a brutal 2-9 against non-conference competition before finding their footing, dropping games to Minnesota (68-64), UNLV (80-69), Northern Iowa (78-58), and No. 3 Iowa State (83-51) — a blowout in which Marquel Sutton, their leading scorer, was held to just three points. Against ranked opponents, Omaha went 0-1 in games with meaningful detail, and their overall non-conference body of work includes losses to mid-major programs like Southern Utah, Alabama State, and Akron, raising real questions about their ceiling beyond the Summit League. That said, once conference play began, the Mavericks were dominant: they claimed the outright Summit League regular-season title at 13-3, rode a nine-game winning streak at one point, and closed the year by blowing out South Dakota 100-75 in the conference tournament semifinal behind Tony Osburn's stunning 9-for-11 performance from three (30 points). Their final five games produced wins by margins of 23, 12, 8, 25, and 43 points — an exceptionally hot stretch — and they enter the tournament with genuine momentum.

Omaha's identity is built around a two-headed scoring attack in Sutton and JJ White, with Osburn providing elite three-point shooting as a third option. Sutton is a force — capable of 36-point, 12-rebound performances like his February outing against South Dakota — while White has been sensational in key moments, including a buzzer-beating three against North Dakota and a career-high 35 points at Oral Roberts. Osburn's 8-for-9 three-point explosion in the conference semifinal may be the most impressive single-game shooting performance of any team in the Summit League this year. The Mavericks are capable of winning wire-to-wire — they led 55-26 at halftime in that semifinal — but have also shown they can win in clutch moments and grind out close games. Their 9-3 stretch in Summit League road and neutral-site games suggests they aren't purely a home team, and their conference tournament play on a neutral floor in Sioux Falls has been commanding. However, the sample of meaningful competition remains thin: Omaha's best wins came against a Summit League field that produced no Top-25 teams, and their one true measuring-stick game against Iowa State was a 32-point dismantling. As a 15-seed, their realistic tournament ceiling is a first-round upset if the matchup presents a vulnerable 2-seed susceptible to three-point shooting and star-driven offense — Osburn and Sutton are legitimate enough to keep any game competitive in the first ten minutes — but a second-round run is a significant stretch given their inability to compete with high-major competition all season. **Verdict: likely first-round exit, with the tools to make any 2-seed uncomfortable for a half.**

2024-11-05 - Michigan: 101 vs Cleveland State: 53

ANN ARBOR, Mich. -- — Danny Wolf scored 19 points and grabbed 13 rebounds, Tre Donaldson added 16 points and seven assists and Michigan never trailed Monday night in its 101-53 season-opening win over Cleveland State in coach Dusty May's debut for the Wolverines. May — who set a program record for wins (126) in his six-year run at Florida Atlantic and led the Owls to their first Final Four appearance in 2023 — took over after the Wolverines went 8-24 under former Michigan star Juwan Howard last season. Wolf — a 7-foot transfer from Yale and a unanimous all-Ivy League first-team selection last season —also had three steals and three blocks. Will Tschetter had 15 points on 7-of-9 shooting, freshman L.J. Cason added 14 points and Roddy Gayle Jr., a transfer from Ohio State, scored 13 for Michigan. Donaldson, an Auburn transfer, scored six points before Tschetter made a layup and then hit a 3-pointer just 33 seconds apart to give the Wolverines a 13-4 lead about 5 minutes into the game. Seven different Michigan players scored during an 18-2 run that made it 45-21 with 2:31 left in the first half and the Vikings trailed by at least 23 points the rest of the way. Dylan Arnett scored seven points and grabbed 10 rebounds for Cleveland State. Michigan shot 68% (39 of 57) from the field and hit 10 of 18 (59%) from 3-point range. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. ------ AP college basketball: and

2024-11-10 - Wake Forest: 72 vs Michigan: 70

GREENSBORO, N,C, -- — Tre'von Spillers dunked off the fast break and Hunter Sallis converted three of four free throws in the final nine seconds to allow Wake Forest to hold off Michigan 72-70 at First Horizon Coliseum on Sunday afternoon. The game was the first meeting between the schools in 24 years to the day and was the first of a two-game, neutral-site series dubbed the Deacon-Wolverine Challenge. Next year the game will be played in Detroit. Wake Forest won the only other meeting in an ACC/Big Ten Challenge game Nov. 10, 2000. Spillers hit two free throws with 10 minutes left to tie the game at 57-57 and the Deacons took the lead a minute later and maintained it the rest of the way. Michigan struggled from the floor. Vladislav Goldin hit back-to-back layups to get the Wolverines within 63-61, but after Sallis knocked down a jumper, Danny Wolf's layup with 3:48 left was the Wolverines' last field goal. Neither team scored over the next three minutes and traded turnovers before Spillers came up with a steal, drove into the lane on the break and threw down the game's final field goal with 38 seconds left. Michigan made seven straight free throws until Rubin Jones intentionally missed with 1.7 seconds left, but the Wolverines could not come down with the rebound. Sallis finished with 18 points to lead Wake Forest (3-0), knocking down 6 of 13 from the field and 6 of 7 from the line. Spillers added 16 points and Juke Harris contributed 11 points and five rebounds off the bench. Efton Reid III pulled down 10 rebounds. Roddy Gayle Jr. paced Michigan (1-1) with 11 points, hitting 4 of 4 from the line, and Tre Donaldson added 10 points and grabbed nine rebounds. LJ Cason chipped in 10 points and four assists off the bench. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

Wolf gave Michigan a 53-43 lead with 12 minutes left but the Wolverines only made two field goals over the next six minutes to have their lead trimmed to 63-60 with 6:16 remaining. TCU didn’t make its next field goal until the 2:19 mark when Trazarien White converted a fast-break layup to make it 72-64. Michigan secured two offensive rebounds on its next possession, ending in Vladislav Goldin’s layup for a 10-point lead. Auburn transfer Tre Donaldson also scored 14 points for Michigan (2-1). Sam Walters added 10 points. White scored 16 points and Brendan Wenzel added 15 for TCU (3-1). Frankie Collins, who played for the Wolverines during his freshman year (2021-22), returned to Ann Arbor and finished with seven points. Michigan led 34-31 at halftime despite having more turnovers (16) than made shots (12). Donaldson made a half-court shot at the end of the first half but it came just after the buzzer and didn't count. The Wolverines finished with 21 turnovers. The only other meeting in the series came in 1962, won by Michigan 82-60. UP NEXT Michigan continues a three-game homestand against Miami (Ohio) on Monday. Danny Wolf had 17 points and 11 rebounds for Michigan (20-5, 12-2), which held a one-game lead over Michigan State in the Big Ten Conference standings. Nimari Burnett added 11 points as the Wolverines won their sixth straight game. Devin Royal had 26 points and five rebounds for Ohio State (15-11, 7-8). Bruce Thornton added 17 points for the Buckeyes but missed a chance to tie the game on a shot in the lane in the final three seconds. John Mobley Jr. added 16 points. Takeaways Michigan: The Wolverines defeated No. 7 Purdue 75-73 at home earlier in the week and should move up several spots when the new AP poll is released Monday. Roddy Gayle Jr., who played the last two years at Ohio State, was booed throughout the game. Gayle gave Michigan the lead for good on a bank shot to make it 82-80. He finished with nine points and eight rebounds. Ohio State: The Buckeyes missed out on a coveted Quad 1 win in a game that featured 11 ties and 16 lead changes. The good news is there are five games left and none of their opponents currently is ranked. Ohio State had little answer for Michigan’s pair of 7-footers, Goldin and Wolf. The loss spoiled OSU’s first sellout crowd of the season at 18,018-seat Value City Arena. Key moment After Gayle’s go-ahead basket, Michigan got a defensive stop and then expanded its lead on Goldin’s third-chance rebound basket that made it 84-80 with 52 seconds left. 2025-02-25 - Nebraska: 46 vs Michigan: 49

LINCOLN, Neb. -- — Roddy Gayle Jr. scored 12 points and Tre Donaldson made two free throws with four seconds left to give No. 15 Michigan a 49-46 win over Nebraska on Monday night, the fewest points the Wolverines have scored in a victory in 17 years. It marked the third time in 11 years that a team won a Big Ten game with fewer than 50 points. Michigan (21-6, 13-3) shot a season-low 30%, and Nebraska's 26% shooting was its worst mark since it made 21.1% in a home loss to Maryland in 2019. The game alternated between a mix of great defense and abysmal shooting. Nebraska (17-11, 7-10) was 1 of 7 on layups, Michigan was 3 of 12. Michigan's previous low point total in a win came in a 49-43 victory over Illinois on Feb. 23, 2008. Donaldson finished with 11 points and Danny Wolf added 10 points and 10 rebounds for the Wolverines. Brice Williams led Nebraska with 26 points. Nine teammates combined for 20. Takeaways Michigan: The Wolverines have posted their lowest point totals of the season in back-to-back games, but they continue to control their destiny in the Big Ten race. They pulled even with Michigan State atop the standings. Nebraska: The Cornhuskers have lost two straight and need to find offense from someone other than Williams. He was 9 of 21 from the field; his teammates were a combined 7 of 41. Key moment Michigan scored on three straight possessions to take a six-point lead with 4:25 left, with Wolf making a 3-pointer and a jumper and L.J. Cason a 3 for his only basket and a 45-39 lead. Key stat Williams scored Nebraska's first 13 points and 18 of its 21 in the first half. Connor Essegian was the only other Nebraska player to make a field goal in the half. 2025-03-15 - Maryland: 80 vs Michigan: 81

INDIANAPOLIS -- — Tre Donaldson drove the length of the court and scored on a layup with 0.4 seconds left to give No. 22 Michigan an 81-80 victory over No. 11 Maryland in the Big Ten Tournament semifinals Saturday. Donaldson finished with 12 points and nine assists, but the heavy lifting was done by Vladislav Goldin, who had 25 points and 10 rebounds, and Danny Wolf Jr. with 21 points and 14 rebounds. The Wolverines (24-9) will face No. 18 Wisconsin in Sunday's championship game in Indianapolis. Donaldson's remarkable drive rekindled images of Tyus Edney in 1995 and Danny Ainge in 1981, who made similar plays to add their stories to the March Madness book. This time, Maryland tried to preserve the lead without fouling. Derik Queen finished with a career high 31 points to lead the Terrapins (25-8) who entered the game on a nine-game winning streak. Selton Miguel added 16 points. Maryland has never reached the tourney's title game. Takeaways Michigan: The tandem of Wolf and Goldin — and the heroic play by Donaldson — were good enough to carry the Wolverines in the semifinals. But if they have another game with 19 turnovers, their dreams could end. Maryland: The Terrapins have relied heavily, perhaps too heavily, on points from their starters. But the bigger problem was not to front Donaldson on the drive, forcing him to burn precious time. Key moment Donaldson's full sprint from near his own baseline straight to the rim. Key stat Michigan's 47-18 rebounding edge was so dominant Wolf nearly outrebounded Maryland by himself. Up next The Wolverines are chasing their first tourney title since winning it back-to-back in 2017 and 2018. Maryland heads home to await the selection committee's bracket reveal. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and
2025-03-16 - Michigan: 59 vs Wisconsin: 53
profile_summary:
Michigan enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 5-seed with a 27-10 record — a résumé built on genuine Big Ten competitiveness, elite frontcourt production, and a knack for winning games they have no business winning late. Against ranked opponents, the Wolverines went an impressive 9-8, with signature wins over then-No. 11 Wisconsin on the road, No. 22 Xavier at a neutral site, No. 15 UCLA in Westwood (Michigan's first win at Pauley Pavilion since 2002), No. 7 Purdue at home (75-73), No. 8 Michigan State (86-83 on the road), and back-to-back ranked wins in the Big Ten Tournament over No. 20 Purdue and No. 11 Maryland — the latter on Tre Donaldson's full-court layup with 0.4 seconds remaining. Their losses to ranked competition — including a blowout at Purdue (91-64), a 13-point regular-season home loss to Michigan State (75-62), and a 20-point drubbing at the hands of Illinois — reveal a team that can be physically overwhelmed and exploited through turnovers when not at its best. Heading into the tournament, Michigan's last five games tell a volatile but ultimately encouraging story: a three-game losing skid (losses to Michigan State by 13, Maryland by 6, and Michigan State again by 17) was snapped emphatically in the Big Ten Tournament with wins over Purdue (86-68), Maryland (81-80), and Wisconsin (59-53) — three games in three days that represent the best sustained stretch of clutch basketball this team has played all season. That tournament run demonstrated everything Michigan is capable of: dominant interior play from 7-foot-1 Vladislav Goldin and 7-foot Danny Wolf, opportunistic guard play from Donaldson, and an ability to win both grind-it-out defensive battles and high-wire finishes.

Michigan's identity is built around one of the most physically imposing frontcourts in the country. Goldin (career-high 36 against UCLA, 25 in the Big Ten semis) and Wolf (11 double-doubles, averaging elite two-way production including six blocks against USC) form a twin-tower combination that creates matchup nightmares — 38 points in the paint against Xavier, a 47-18 rebounding edge over Maryland in the Big Ten semis, and 11 blocks against Wisconsin in December are not flukes but rather consistent outputs from two players who alter games at both ends. Donaldson is the engine of the offense, capable of scoring 20 and distributing equally, and his full-court layup to beat Maryland may be the most important play of his season. Nimari Burnett provides shooting punch off the bench (5-of-7 from three against Western Kentucky; buzzer-beater against Rutgers), and Roddy Gayle Jr. has stepped up repeatedly in pressure moments. The concern, however, is real: Michigan has committed 22 turnovers in a game, shot 30% from the floor at Nebraska, and gone 4-of-28 from three against Oklahoma — volatility that a sharp tournament opponent will try to exploit. The Wolverines are 13-1 at home this season but have been tested on the road and neutral sites, going 6-4 in such settings against quality competition, which suggests the neutral-site tournament environment neither dramatically helps nor hurts them. Their tournament ceiling is the Elite Eight: this team has the star power, size, toughness, and big-game pedigree to advance past the first weekend, but their turnover issues, three-point inconsistency, and demonstrated vulnerability against elite pressure defense make a Final Four run a stretch. A motivated, well-coached opponent that can generate turnovers and contest the paint will expose Michigan's limitations — but in a bracket where any two or three games might not feature that kind of opponent, the Wolverines are absolutely capable of making noise into the second weekend.

profile_summary:
UC San Diego enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 12-seed with a 30-5 record and the Big West Conference regular season and tournament titles in hand — a résumé that is genuinely impressive for a program in its first year of postseason eligibility after transitioning to Division I. The Tritons' most notable quality win came in December, when they knocked off Utah State on the road 75-73 — at the time a team riding a 10-game winning streak — with Tyler McGhie delivering 15 clutch second-half points to seal a two-point road victory that stands as UCSD's clearest statement against legitimate high-major-adjacent competition. Beyond that, their schedule was heavily Big West-centric, and while they dominated that conference (18-2), evidence against truly elite opponents is thin: their only ranked-caliber road test was a narrow loss to San Diego State to open the season and a one-point escape at Utah State. Against the rest of their schedule, however, they have been ruthlessly efficient — blowing out Cal State Fullerton 100-55, rolling past Hawaii 83-44, and cruising past La Verne 109-33, suggesting a team that feasts on inferior competition but hasn't faced the kind of athleticism and depth typical of a 5-seed in March.

Entering the tournament, UCSD is playing as well as any team in the country within its own sphere: the Tritons have won 14 consecutive games, capped by a dominant Big West Tournament run that included a 69-51 semifinal dismantling of UC Santa Barbara — after trailing at halftime — and a 75-61 championship win over UC Irvine. Their style of play is built around an elite offensive engine fueled by two legitimate scorers in Aniwaniwa Tait-Jones and Tyler McGhie, who have been devastating in tandem all season. Tait-Jones is their engine — posting multiple 20-plus and even 32-point performances down the stretch, adding rebounds, assists, and defensive activity — while McGhie is a lethal perimeter threat who shot 7-for-10 from three against San Diego in December and consistently carries the offense in clutch moments. Hayden Gray serves as a steady tertiary option, and Nordin Kapic provides a reliable interior presence. The team has demonstrated genuine resilience — coming back from a halftime deficit to beat both Hawaii and UC Santa Barbara in the conference tournament — and rarely looks rattled. Their two conference losses to UC Irvine and UC Riverside were revealing, however: the Riverside loss came in a game where Barrington Hargress went off for 40 points, exposing some vulnerability against elite individual scorers, and the Irvine loss showed they can be contained on the road. UCSD is 7-3 in true road and neutral-site games, with quality neutral wins over Toledo, James Madison, and La Salle at the Boardwalk Battle early in the season, suggesting they are comfortable outside their own building. This is a confident, well-coached team on a historic run for their program — but their lack of consistent exposure to high-major competition and susceptibility to hot individual scorers makes a deep run a tall order. **Realistic ceiling: Round of 32.** UCSD is dangerous enough to knock off a 5-seed — particularly given their offensive firepower and current momentum — but the talent and experience gap against a Power Conference program in the Round of 32 is likely too steep for a program still cutting its teeth on the national stage.

name: Texas Tech
summaries:
2024-11-06 - Texas Tech: 94 vs Bethune-Cookman: 61

LUBBOCK, Texas -- — Kerwin Walton scored 21 points and JT Toppin scored 19 and Texas Tech all but wrapped it up at halftime beating Bethune-Cookman 94-61 on Tuesday night in a season opener for both teams. Chance McMillian and Darrion Williams each scored 17 points and Kevin Overton 10. The Red Raiders shot 36 of 63 (57%) including 16 of 30 (53%) from 3-point range. Reggie Ward Jr. scored 15 points and Brayon Freeman 12 for the Wildcats. Ward Jr.'s layup with 4:50 left in the first half brought Bethune-Cookman within 33-28. But the Wildcats failed to score again and Texas Tech scored the next 17 points and went to halftime up 50-28. Williams, Devan Cambridge, McMillian and Walton each made 3-pointers during the 17-0 run. Texas Tech started its 100th year of basketball. The Red Raiders basketball program played its first-ever game on Jan. 25, 1925. Prior to Tuesday night’s contest, Texas Tech and the Wildcats had only faced each other once on the court. The Red Raiders won, 79-44 on Nov. 9, 2019. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP collegebasketball: and

Darrion Williams just missed a double-double scoring eight points and grabbing 10 rebounds. Reserve Jon Sanders II led the Demons (1-1) with 18 points. After tying a program record with 16-made 3-pointers in its season opener against Bethune-Cookman in Tuesday's home opener, Texas Tech cooled considerably shooting 6 of 19 from beyond the arc. Walton's 3-pointer with 13:26 remaining in the first half gave the Red Raiders a 21-9 lead. Toppin converted a three-point play with 7:29 before halftime to make it 29-17 and Texas Tech led by double digits for the rest of the game. Texas Tech led 42-28 at halftime and the lead reached 20 points (83-63) with 1:33 remaining on Overton's jumper. 2025-03-15 - Texas Tech: 80 vs Arizona: 86

Kevin Overton had 20 points and Christian Anderson scored 19 for the Red Raiders (25-8), who played without Chance McMillian and Darrion Williams because of injuries, and then watched star forward JT Toppin throw up in the arena tunnel. Toppin made it through the game, but the All-Big 12 forward managed just 11 points in 25 minutes. Compounding problems short-handed Texas Tech, point guard Elijah Hawkins picked up his fourth foul with 14:56 to go, leaving coach Grant McCasland with precious few options on his bench in the second half. The Red Raiders trailed by as much as 14 before nevertheless mounting a comeback, closing to 78-74 on two free throws by Anderson with 2:40 to go. Veesaar answered with back-to-back baskets and Arizona held on from there. Takeaways Arizona: The Wildcats were 8 of 16 from beyond the 3-point arc and shot 51% from the field overall. Texas Tech: The Red Raiders couldn't overcome the fact that their three leading scorers were ill or absent. profile_summary:
Texas Tech enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 3-seed with a 28-9 record, having earned the program's first-ever 15-win Big 12 season and a double-bye into the conference tournament quarterfinals — a résumé that reflects genuine, sustained excellence in one of college basketball's toughest leagues. Against ranked opponents, the Red Raiders went an impressive 8-6, with signature wins over #6 Houston (82-81 OT on the road), #3 Iowa State, #20 Arizona (at home), and Kansas in Allen Fieldhouse — a venue where Texas Tech was previously 1-21 all-time. Those victories demonstrate the Red Raiders are capable of beating anyone on any given night. However, their losses against ranked teams — including home defeats to UCF (unranked at the time but a Quality 1 result), Texas A&M, and a road loss to Arizona — reveal a team that can be had when it is not shooting well or playing shorthanded. Over their final five games, Texas Tech went 3-2: a dominant 91-75 win over Colorado, an 85-57 blowout of Arizona State, a tight 76-74 Big 12 quarterfinal win over Baylor in which they shot 19.4% in the second half, and then an 86-80 loss to Arizona in the Big 12 semifinals — a game played without Chance McMillian and Darrion Williams due to injury, and with star forward JT Toppin visibly ill and limited to 11 points. That injury cloud is the defining storyline entering March.

Texas Tech's identity is built around three-point volume, frontcourt dominance, and clutch resilience. The Red Raiders average 10.1 threes per game and hit double digits in 19 games this season, a program record, led by McMillian — the Big 12's top 3-point shooter at 45.4% — when he is healthy. Toppin is the engine of everything, a 6-foot-9 transfer from New Mexico who recorded 14 double-doubles this season, dropped a career-high 41 points against Arizona State, and carried the team to multiple wins through sheer force; when he is locked in, this team has an elite ceiling. Freshman Christian Anderson has emerged as a genuine third scoring option, scoring 21 in two separate games down the stretch. The team is at its best when it plays with composure and handles adversity — it refused to lose consecutive games all season, bounced back from an early ejection of coach Grant McCasland in Houston and still won in overtime, and rallied from double-digit deficits multiple times. At home, Texas Tech was a dominant 15-3; on the road and neutral sites they were a respectable 13-6, with the wins at Allen Fieldhouse and Houston standing as two of the most impressive results in the Big 12 this year. The concern entering the tournament is health: if McMillian and Williams are not available or are compromised, the Red Raiders are asking Toppin to carry an enormous load against elite defenses with a short bench — a vulnerability Arizona exposed mercilessly in Kansas City. A healthy Texas Tech is a legitimate Elite Eight threat with Final Four upside; a shorthanded one is a dangerous but beatable 3-seed. **Realistic ceiling: Elite Eight**, with a first-or-second-round exit possible if the injury situation does not stabilize.

profile_summary:
UNC Wilmington enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 14-seed with a 27-8 record, a strong résumé within the Colonial Athletic Association that is tempered by limited success against elite competition. The Seahawks' most notable non-conference measuring stick came in a 84-66 road loss at No. 1 Kansas in November — a game where they kept it close through halftime before a 12-2 Jayhawks run broke things open in the second half. Beyond that marquee matchup, UNCW dropped road games to Colgate (72-59) and Howard (88-83), the latter coming after blowing a second-half lead, and fell to Towson in overtime in their CAA opener. Against lower-tier competition, however, the Seahawks have been dominant, routinely building double-digit halftime leads and winning wire-to-wire. Their conference tournament run further illustrates their ceiling: they handled Hampton comfortably in the quarterfinals (79-65), then survived Charleston 68-67 in the semifinals on a pair of Bo Montgomery free throws with three seconds left — a gut-check moment that speaks to their competitive character.

Entering the tournament, UNCW's final five games (Hampton road loss, William & Mary win, Campbell win, a missing game summary, and the two CAA tournament wins) show a team that stumbled on the road down the stretch — losing at Hampton 83-70 and getting blown out by Elon 81-70 at home — before steadying itself in Washington. The Seahawks are a balanced, multi-contributor offense led by Donovan Newby, who can erupt for 30-plus points on any given night (30 vs. Hofstra, 24 vs. Charleston in the semis) and is at his best at the free-throw line. Khamari McGriff is a reliable and efficient interior scorer off the bench, Harlan Obioha provides a physical frontcourt presence with shot-blocking ability, and Bo Montgomery contributes consistent two-way energy. Sean Moore's 23-point, 15-rebound double-double in a double-overtime win at Drexel stands out as a signature performance. The Seahawks tend to play with composure in close games — the Charleston semifinal comeback and the Drexel thriller both demonstrate resilience — but they are demonstrably vulnerable to hot three-point shooting, as Elon's TK Simpkins (32 points, 8-of-10 from three) single-handedly dismantled them in February. They are also a clear home team, going wire-to-wire against nearly everyone at Trask Coliseum while showing a tendency to be sluggish in road environments. As a 14-seed, they face steep odds, but they are not a pushover: they play with grit, have a genuine go-to scorer in Newby, and have demonstrated the ability to win close games. Their realistic tournament ceiling is a first-round upset — they have the offensive firepower and late-game poise to steal a game from a 3-seed on a neutral floor — but advancing to the Sweet 16 would require overcoming significant talent deficits that their non-conference schedule exposed all season.

name: Mississippi State
summaries:
2024-11-05 - Mississippi State: 95 vs West Georgia: 60

STARKVILLE, Miss. -- — Josh Hubbard scored 26 points and Claudell Harris Jr. added 20 Monday night to help Mississippi State beat West Georgia 95-60 in the season opener for both teams. Hubbard — and All-Southeastern Conference second-team selection — and Harris each hit six of Mississippi State's 14 3-pointers. The Bulldogs made 36 of 65 (55%) from the field, shot 47% from behind the arc and scored 31 points off 20 West Georgia turnovers. Kanye Clary stole a pass and then fed KeShawn Murphy for a dunk 13 seconds into the game that made it 2-0 and Mississippi State never trailed. Hubbard hit two 3-pointers in a 12-2 run capped when he threw down a dunk that made it 14-4. Tamaury Releford scored the final nine points in a 12-0 spurt that trimmed West Georgia's deficit to 24-21 about five minutes later but Harris made four 3-pointers — the last coming with 3 seconds left — to give the Bulldogs an 11-point halftime lead. Shelton Williams-Dryden scored in the paint to open the scoring in the second half and make it 40-31 but Hubbard answered with a 3-pointer with and Mississippi State led by double figures the rest of the way. Releford led the Wolves with 16 points and Kolten Griffin scored 13. Williams-Dryden finished with 10 rebounds to go with nine points. Harris, who transferred from Boston College after two seasons at Charleston Southern, came into this season with 1,318 career points. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. ------ AP college basketball: and

2024-11-09 - Mississippi State: 101 vs Georgia State: 66

STARKVILLE, Miss. -- — Josh Hubbard scored 15 points, Riley Kugel added 14 and Mississippi State beat Georgia State 101-66 on Friday night. Mississippi State shot over 60% for a majority of the game before missing eight straight shots to finish 42 of 72 (58%). The Bulldogs were coming off a 95-60 victory over West Georgia after shooting 55%, including 14 made 3-pointers for their most 3s in a game since the 2018-19 season. Michael Nwoko scored the opening points against Georgia State and Mississippi State never trailed. The Bulldogs went ahead by double figures during a 15-1 run midway through the first half. Kugel's dunk with 3:34 left put Mississippi State ahead by 43 points. Kanye Clary had 11 points, and RJ Melendez and Claudell Harris Jr. each scored 10 for Mississippi State (2-0). Toneari Lane scored 15 points and Cesare Edwards added 13 for Georgia State (1-1). Zarique Nutter scored 11 and Nick McMullen 10. Hubbard was among 50 players chosen to the John R. Wooden Award preseason watch list announced Thursday. Hubbard’s 17.1 points per game are fourth-most among SEC returning players. Mississippi State has had a player recognized on the Wooden Award preseason watch list during three of the last four seasons, which include Iverson Molinar (2021-22) and Tolu Smith III (2023-24). State hopes to secure three straight NCAA Tournament trips for the third time in program history this season. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. 2024-11-17 - Mississippi State: 78 vs Utah: 73

SOUTHAVEN, Miss. -- — Josh Hubbard scored 23 points, Cameron Matthews made several key free throws down the stretch and Mississippi State rallied in the second half to defeat Utah 78-73 on Sunday in the Mid-South Showdown. KeShawn Murphy scored 18 points, Matthews 12, with 8 of 10 from the line, and Ryan Kugel scored 12 for the Bulldogs. Murphy had 14 rebounds. Matthews made two free throws on back-to-back possessions to put the Bulldogs up 75-71 in the final minute. After a Utes miss, their defensive pressure forced Mississippi State to call timeout twice. Utah then fouled Matthews again. He made one of two, then Kugel got an offensive rebound and made a pair of free throws to put the game out of reach. Ezra Ausar led Utah with 15 points. Mason Madsen scored 14, Keanu Dawes 13 and Miro Little 10. Dawes had 12 rebounds. Hubbard scored 11 points and Murphy had seven as the Bulldogs stormed back from an 11-point halftime deficit to lead 50-44 with 13 1/2 minutes remaining. The Utes regrouped and went ahead by four before a string of seven lead changes in the next three minutes. Utah controlled the first half, building an 11-point lead at the intermission. The Utes outscored the Bulldogs 24-11 over the second 10 minutes of the half, with Dawes scoring seven points and Little capping the run with two 3-pointers. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. 2024-11-29 - UNLV: 58 vs Mississippi State: 80

TEMPE, Ariz. -- — KeShawn Murphy had 14 points and 13 rebounds, Josh Hubbard scored 11 and No. 25 Mississippi State overpowered UNLV 80-58 on Thursday night in the Arizona Tip-Off. The Bulldogs (6-0) used a pair of runs to build a 13-point halftime lead and blew it wide open early in the second half to move into the championship game Friday night against Butler. Mississippi State had a 46-29 rebounding advantage and scored 30 second-chance points off 19 offensive rebounds. Jailen Bedford had 13 points and Jalen Hill added 11 to lead the Runnin’ Rebels (4-2). The Bulldogs dominated after the opening six minutes, using runs of 7-0 and 12-2 to build a 39-21 lead. UNLV used a 6-0 spurt to cut it to 45-32 at halftime. The Runnin' Rebels shot better overall in the first half at 14 of 25, but the Bulldogs went 7 for 14 from 3-point range and had 16 second-chance points off nine offensive rebounds. Mississippi State went on an 11-0 run to go up 62-36 and didn't allow UNLV to trim the lead under 20 the rest of the way. Takeaways UNLV: The Runnin' Rebels were no match for Mississippi State inside and had a hard time getting big man Jeremiah Cherry going. The 6-foot-11, 280-pound forward finished with eight points on 4-of-5 shooting and had two rebounds against constant double-teams. Mississippi State: The Bulldogs were relentless on the offensive glass and it paid off, particularly in the first half. Murphy led the way with four offensive rebounds. Key moment Mississippi State hit five straight shots while building its big early lead, but the defense keyed it, holding UNLV scoreless for a stretch of 3:18. Key stat Mississippi State showed off its depth, outscoring UNLV 48-13 off the bench. Up next Mississippi State will face Butler in the championship game Friday night. UNLV plays Northwestern. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2024-11-30 - Mississippi State: 77 vs Butler: 87

TEMPE, Ariz. -- — Jahmyl Telfort scored 24 points, Pierre Brooks II added 22 and Butler knocked off No. 25 Mississippi State 87-77 to win the Arizona Tip-Off on Friday night. Butler (6-1) survived with a 61-59 win against Northwestern in the semifinals after blowing a 15-point lead and nearly coughed up an 11-point lead on Friday night after Riley Kugel and Josh Hubbard brought Mississippi State back. Kugel had 10 points in the first three minutes of the second half, and Hubbard followed with 13 quick points as Mississippi State (6-1) used an 8-0 run to pull within 70-68. Brooks hit a 3-pointer and, after Telford hit a floater, scored on a runner to stretch the lead to 81-70 with 2 1/2 minutes left. Mississippi State got no closer than eight after that. Hubbard and Kugel each had 22 points. Takeaways Butler: The Bulldogs were superb on offense as they shot 53% from the floor and made 12 of 22 from 3-point range to pick up their biggest win of the season. Mississippi State: Everything that went right in the Bulldogs' first game in the desert flipped against Butler. Mississippi State shot 7 for 27 from 3 and had numerous defensive breakdowns to lose its first game of the season. Key moment Brooks' two baskets after Mississippi State cut the lead to two gave Butler the momentum back, and the Bulldogs stretched the lead from there. Key stat Mississippi State scored 30 second-chance points on 19 offensive rebounds in an 80-58 win over UNLV in the semifinals. profile_summary:
Mississippi State enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as an 8-seed with a 21-13 record — a résumé built on a spectacular nonconference run that gradually eroded under the weight of one of college basketball's toughest schedules. The Bulldogs went 12-1 before SEC play, notching quality nonconference wins over Memphis on the road, SMU away, and a dominant 90-57 dismantling of then-No. 18 Pittsburgh at home, and they reached as high as No. 14 in the AP Poll. Against ranked opponents this season, Mississippi State went a modest 5-9: notable wins include upsets of No. 21 Ole Miss (twice, including an overtime thriller), No. 7 Texas A&M by 16 points at home (prompting a court storm), and No. 21 Memphis on the road, while the losses include blowout defeats to No. 1 Auburn (88-66), No. 6 Alabama (111-73), No. 6 Tennessee (68-56), and No. 20 Missouri (88-61 at home) — a pattern that reveals a team that can steal a marquee win but frequently gets overwhelmed by truly elite opposition. The final five games tell a complicated story: Mississippi State beat LSU by 12 in the SEC Tournament opener, lost to Missouri 85-73 in the second round, and heading into Nashville had gone 1-3 — blowing a lead late at Arkansas in a 93-92 heartbreaker, losing at home to Texas in overtime 87-82 despite a furious second-half rally, and getting obliterated at Alabama 111-73 in a game that was never close. That stretch reflects the team's defining tension: they are scrappy, resilient comeback artists who refuse to quit (see their 12-0 run to briefly lead Arkansas late, or Kugel's buzzer-tying layup to force OT against Texas), but they are also prone to catastrophic defensive meltdowns — particularly against teams that shoot threes at volume, as Oklahoma (52.7% overall), Alabama (49% from three), and Missouri (55% from three) all torched them from deep in consecutive February-March losses.

Josh Hubbard is the unquestioned engine of this offense — a preseason Wooden Award watch list honoree who erupted for a career-high 38 points against Alabama and has been virtually the only reliable creator in crunch time — but his inconsistency is a real concern: he shot just 2-for-12 in the blowout loss to Auburn and 4-for-18 (with 14 points) against SMU, showing a tendency to struggle when opponents key on him. KeShawn Murphy gives this team a legitimate interior presence, posting double-doubles regularly and providing 18 points and 11 rebounds in the Alabama loss, while Claudell Harris Jr. is a dangerous spot-up shooter off the bench who can turn a game with a flurry of threes. The bench overall is a genuine strength — Mississippi State outscored UNLV 48-13 off the bench in the Arizona Tip-Off and posted a 32-5 bench scoring edge in a road win at Georgia — but the team's identity shifts dangerously when Hubbard goes cold and no one steps into the vacuum. Locationally, the Bulldogs have been better away from Starkville than their home record suggests, going 2-4 in SEC home games while picking up road wins at Memphis, SMU, Vanderbilt, Ole Miss, and Georgia, though they also suffered their worst beatings (Auburn, Alabama) away from home; neutral-site performance is mixed — they won the Arizona Tip-Off semifinal impressively, lost the championship to Butler, and split two SEC Tournament games. As an 8-seed, Mississippi State carries real danger for a 1-seed — they play with fight, have experienced tournament-level moments, can erupt offensively on a good shooting night, and feature a player in Hubbard capable of a 30-point performance on any given night — but their three-point defense is alarmingly porous at the worst possible time, their overall record is just 21-13, and the evidence of second-half collapses and blowout losses against elite competition is hard to dismiss. The realistic ceiling for this team is the Round of 32: dangerous enough to upset a 1-seed in a shootout if Hubbard is locked in and the three-point defense holds, but too defensively inconsistent and too

Braden Huff added 14 points for the Bulldogs, who got their 19th consecutive season-opening victory. It was Gonzaga's biggest margin of victory over a top-10 opponent in school history, over a team it lost to in the 2021 National Championship game in Indianapolis and the 2022 Peacock Classic in Sioux Falls, South Dakota. Norchad Omier had 15 points and nine rebounds to lead the Bears. Robert Wright added 12 points and Josh Ojianwuna had 10. The Bulldogs went on a 24-4 run in the second half to run away with the win. It was the first time Baylor lost by more than 30 points under coach Scott Drew. Takeaways Baylor: The Bears missed their first five shots and were 36.2% from the field in the first half. Drew’s squad couldn’t turn things around, ending the game at 37.1%, including 14.3% on 3-pointers. Gonzaga: The Bulldogs shot 57.1% from the field and 41.9% on 3s while topping 100 points against a nationally-ranked opponent for the first time since its 100-90 victory over Alabama on Dec. 17, 2022. Key Stat Gonzaga outrebounded Baylor 45-32. The Bulldogs were particularly aggressive on the offensive boards, where they grabbed 16 rebounds to set up 17 second-chance points. Key Moment Khalif Battle made three consecutive 3-pointers to put Gonzaga ahead by more than 30 points with just over six minutes to play. profile_summary:
Baylor enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 9-seed with a 20-15 record — a résumé that reflects a team talented enough to compete with anyone, but too inconsistent to be trusted over a sustained tournament run. Against ranked opponents, the Bears went 5-13, with notable wins over No. 22 St. John's (a double-overtime buzzer-beater by Jeremy Roach), No. 11 Kansas (rallying from 21 down in one of the most stunning comebacks of the season), and No. 16 Arkansas, while suffering blowout losses to Gonzaga (101-63), Tennessee (77-62), and Iowa State (74-55) that exposed genuine structural vulnerabilities. Their final five games tell a mixed story: a gutty 71-61 win over Oklahoma State, a narrow 61-58 road victory at TCU, a 65-61 home loss to Houston despite leading at halftime, a 70-56 Big 12 Tournament win over Kansas State, and a heartbreaking 76-74 quarterfinal exit to Texas Tech — the second time Tech beat them this season. The Bears are not a team that dominates wire-to-wire; they are a streaky, comeback-fueled squad that can look elite in the second half and completely disengaged in opening halves, having trailed by 21 to Kansas, 20 to BYU, and 23 to Arizona before either rallying or folding.

Norchad Omier is unquestionably Baylor's engine — the fifth-year forward posted 29 points and 15 rebounds in the Big 12 Tournament loss to Texas Tech and finished the season with 87 career double-doubles, second-most in NCAA history behind Tom Gola, making him one of the most dominant interior presences in the country. Freshman VJ Edgecombe has been explosive (28 points against BYU, 24 against Arizona, career-high 30 against Kansas State) but was hampered by a lower-body injury in February, and his availability and conditioning entering the tournament is a legitimate concern. Jeremy Roach provides veteran shot-creation and clutch moments — his buzzer-beater against St. John's and his late-game scoring against TCU are evidence — but he has been inconsistent shooting and also dealt with concussion protocol, missing four games. Robert Wright III has emerged as a crucial tertiary scorer and playmaker, setting a Baylor freshman assist record. Location matters enormously for this team: the Bears were 12-2 at home, a dominant force in Waco, but 0-4 against ranked opponents in true road games, including losses at Iowa State, Arizona, Houston, and UConn. Their neutral-site record is genuinely respectable — a near-miss against Tennessee, a thriller win over St. John's — suggesting the tournament environment won't rattle them. Still, foul trouble remains a recurring issue (Omier's four-foul game against Texas Tech was decisive), depth is thin with Houston outscoring Baylor's bench 24-1 in one game, and the Bears' inability to build first-half leads consistently is a pattern that will be ruthlessly exploited by prepared tournament opponents. Baylor is a dangerous, volatile 9-seed capable of a first-round upset, but their realistic ceiling is the Round of 32 — a team more likely to be someone else's bracket-buster story than to make a deep run themselves.

Alabama: The Crimson Tide survived a game against Arkansas State, which is coached by former Nate Oats assistant Bryan Hodgson. Alabama could find itself in more close games given the difficulty of its schedule, which features games against No. 14 Purdue, No. 4 Houston and No. 25 Rutgers before Thanksgiving. In a game where the teams were only separated by one percentage point in field-goal percentage and two percentage points in 3-point percentage, the extra eight attempts for Alabama made a difference. WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind. -- — Trey Kaufman-Renn scored a career-high 26 points and grabbed eight rebounds, and freshman C.J. Cox scored nine of his 11 points during a game-turning 13-0 run midway through the second half to help No. 13 Purdue get past No. 2 Alabama 87-78 on Friday night. The Boilermakers (4-0) have won 21 consecutive home games and 25 straight in November. They have not lost a regular-season nonconference game since December 2020. Braden Smith had 17 points and 10 assists as he moved into third place on Purdue's career assists list with 483. Fletcher Loyer also scored 17. But the Crimson Tide learned lessons that will help them in the long run. Purdue: The Boilermakers might have turned the corner. After three straight rocky performances, coach Matt Painter’s squad delivered its best game yet. If Purdue continues playing this way, it could be the Big Ten contender everyone expects. Key moment After Alabama took its largest lead at 65-59, Kaufman-Renn answered with a basket and Cox made three straight 3-pointers to fuel a 13-0 run that gave the Boilermakers a 72-65 advantage with 8:17 to play. The only other time it played a non-Big Ten team ranked in the top two came in the arena’s first game — a 73-71 loss to No. 1 UCLA in December 1967. Alabama: The Crimson Tide are two wins from their third tournament title in five seasons under coach Nate Oats. They improved to 3-17 against Kentucky in this event and 2-6 in the quarterfinals. They also added to the program record for most wins over AP Top 25 opponents with the 11th this season. Key moment The Crimson Tide extinguished any thoughts of a comeback starting the second half on a 12-6 run to force a Kentucky timeout after Dioubate's 3 with 16:31 left. Alabama led by 30 late. Key stat Alabama had a 29-6 scoring edge off turnovers. Up next Butler has time to heal for the NCAA Tournament for Kentucky. Alabama has a chance to avenge a 99-94 loss to the Gators on March 5 on the Tide's home court. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. 2025-03-15 - Florida: 104 vs Alabama: 82

NASHVILLE, Tenn. -- — Walter Clayton Jr. scored 22 points, and No. 4 Florida pulled away from No. 5 Alabama for a 104-82 victory in the Southeastern Conference Tournament semifinals on Saturday. Alijah Martin and Will Richard each had 16 points for the Gators (29-4) in their fifth consecutive win. Next up for Florida is Sunday's SEC championship game against No. 8 Tennessee, which beat No. 3 Auburn 70-65 in the first semifinal. The second-seeded Gators led the Crimson Tide 47-45 after a first half that featured 10 lead changes. But Clayton and company really turned up their play down the stretch. Chris Youngblood had 14 points for third-seeded Alabama (25-8). Clifford Omoruyi and Mouhamed Dioubate each had 12. Clayton went 6 for 11 from 3-point range. The senior guard added six assists. Takeaways Alabama: The loss derailed the Crimson Tide’s hope of winning the program's third SEC tournament title in the last five seasons. With 10 wins over AP Top 25 opponents this season, a program record for most in a single season, Alabama has a strong case for a good seed in the NCAA Tournament. Florida: The Gators were impressive in the defensive end, holding the high-scoring Crimson Tide to just 82 points. Entering Saturday, Alabama had scored 90 points or more in 18 games this season, the most in Division I. Key moment Richard hit a 3-pointer with 9:24 remaining in the second half to give Florida a 21-point lead and put the game out of reach for Alabama. Key stat After a tightly contested first half, Florida outscored the Crimson Tide 57-37 over the final 20 minutes. Up next Florida and Tennessee split the two-game season series, with both teams winning on their home courts. The Crimson Tide wait to learn the team's first opponent in the NCAA tourney. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and
profile_summary:
Alabama enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 2-seed with a 28-9 record — a résumé built on elite scheduling, remarkable depth, and a program-record 10 wins over AP Top 25 opponents. The Crimson Tide went roughly 10-7 against ranked opponents this season, with signature wins over then-No. 6 Houston (85-80 OT), then-No. 10 Texas A&M (94-88), then-No. 8 Kentucky (102-97), then-No. 25 Illinois (100-87), and a stunning buzzer-beating road win over then-No. 1 Auburn (93-91 OT) to close the regular season — the latter punctuated by Mark Sears' off-balance game-winning floater at the horn. Their losses against quality competition are equally instructive: back-to-back regular season defeats to No. 1 Auburn (94-85) and No. 15 Missouri (110-98) revealed vulnerability to elite offenses and turnover-induced collapses, and the SEC Tournament semifinal blowout loss to Florida (104-82) exposed a troubling inability to sustain momentum over 40 minutes against the nation's best. Over their final five games, Alabama went 3-2: a dominant 99-70 demolition of Kentucky in the SEC quarterfinals, a buzzer-beating OT road win at Auburn, and a regular season home win over Kentucky (96-83), sandwiched around demoralizing losses to Florida (99-94 at home) and Tennessee (79-76 on a half-court buzzer-beater). That inconsistency — oscillating between breathtaking highs and deflating lows within the same week — defines Alabama entering March.

Alabama plays an explosive, high-tempo offensive style that regularly cracks 100 points, scoring 90 or more in 18 games this season (most in Division I), and relies heavily on attacking the free-throw line — drawing 41 attempts against Houston and 44 against Arkansas State — while also capable of erupting from three, as evidenced by going 22-of-45 from deep in a 111-73 demolition of Mississippi State. The engine of everything is senior guard Mark Sears, who posted 35 points at Missouri, 30 against Florida and Kentucky, 27 against Creighton and Texas A&M, and delivered the game-winning shot at Auburn — a legitimate All-American whose clutch gene is undeniable. Supporting him is a deep and versatile rotation featuring Grant Nelson (a double-double threat who scored 25 at Kentucky and 23 at North Dakota), freshman Labaron Philon (a dynamic playmaker averaging major minutes), Aden Holloway (five 3-pointers against Kentucky in the SEC tourney), Chris Youngblood (27 points and 7-for-11 from three vs. Mississippi State), and Clifford Omoruyi anchoring the interior. However, Alabama's Achilles heel is turnovers — they committed 21 against Ole Miss (a home loss), 19 against Kent State, 15 against Oregon, and 10 in the first half alone at Missouri — and those lapses directly translate to points allowed and momentum shifts. On the glass, Alabama is typically dominant, outrebounding opponents by significant margins, but Florida exposed them with a 50-35 rebounding edge in the SEC semis, a concerning outlier. Neutral-site data is mixed — they went 2-1 in the Players Era Festival (wins over Houston and Rutgers, loss to Oregon on a putback dunk with 4.4 seconds left) and won a SEC quarterfinal comfortably before collapsing against Florida — suggesting they are capable but not invulnerable in tournament environments. This Alabama team is a legitimate Elite Eight contender and a credible Final Four threat: Sears is playing at an All-American level, the depth and offensive firepower are elite, and wins over Houston, Texas A&M, Kentucky, and Auburn in overtime on the road demonstrate big-game DNA — but the chronic turnover issues, the blowout SEC semifinal loss to Florida, and a pattern of second-half defensive breakdowns against top offenses make a national title run a stretch. **Realistic ceiling: Elite Eight, with a puncher's chance at the Final Four if Sears stays locked in and turnovers are contained.**

2024-11-05 - West Virginia: 87 vs Robert Morris: 59

MORGANTOWN, W.Va. -- — Tucker DeVries scored 18 points, Javon Small added 15 and West Virginia routed Robert Morris 87-59 on Monday in the debut of new Mountaineers coach Darian DeVries. Darian Devries was hired in March after six seasons at Drake, replacing interim coach Josh Eilert. Tucker DeVries is a two-time Missouri Valley Conference player of the year who transferred from Drake to continue playing for his father. He scored the opening eight points of the game against Robert Morris and West Virginia led 30-2 after eight minutes, including a 21-0 run. Tucker DeVries led all first-half scorers with 14 points after making 4 of 7 3-pointers. West Virginia went ahead 46-26 at the break after making nine 3-pointers, while holding Robert Morris to 11-of-34 shooting (32%) overall. Toby Okani had 13 points, Jonathan Powell added 11 and freshman KJ Tenner scored 10 for West Virginia, which has won the last 14 matchups with RMU. Amani Hansberry grabbed 12 rebounds to go with nine points. Josh Omojafo led Robert Morris with 13 points, going 7 of 7 from the free-throw line. West Virginia guard Jayden Stone, who had three games of at least 30 points last season at Detroit Mercy, missed the game with an upper body injury. He is listed as day-to-day. SHOT CLOCK The second half was delayed due to a shot-clock malfunction above the West Virginia basket. A temporary shot clock was set up at ground level near the photographers along the baseline. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here.
