profile_summary:
Robert Morris enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 15-seed with a 26-9 record and Horizon League regular-season and conference tournament champions — an impressive résumé for a mid-major, though one built almost entirely against modest competition. The Colonials' most revealing result against quality opposition came in Game 1, a brutal 87-59 dismantling at West Virginia in which they trailed 30-2 after eight minutes and shot 32% in the first half — a performance that exposed real limitations against high-major athleticism and defensive intensity. Their conference schedule told a more favorable story: Robert Morris went 15-5 in Horizon League play, rattling off seven straight wins to close the regular season and adding three more in the conference tournament, including wins over Oakland (79-76) and Youngstown State (89-78), to capture the automatic bid. The final five games were dominant — wins over Wright State (83-62), Oakland (79-76), Youngstown State (89-78), and earlier blowouts of IU Indianapolis (106-53) and Green Bay (94-85) — with the Colonials winning by an average of roughly 16 points per game in that stretch, signaling a team playing its best basketball at exactly the right time. Robert Morris wins in a variety of ways: they grind out clutch victories in close games — Kam Woods' go-ahead jumper with two seconds left at Youngstown State, a game-winning basket by Woods against Towson, and a triple-overtime survival against Northern Kentucky all illustrate a team that competes hard and late — but they can also pull away convincingly when the talent gap is wide enough.

The engine of this team is a genuinely talented trio. Alvaro Folgueiras is a force — he dropped 35 points and 10 rebounds at Northern Kentucky, put up 27 and 16 against Saint Francis, and posted a 21-point, 19-rebound effort in triple overtime against Northern Kentucky, demonstrating elite production as both a scorer and rebounder for this level. Amarion Dickerson is a high-motor two-way player who delivered 27 points and 15 rebounds in that triple-OT thriller and has been consistently productive with multiple 20-plus-point performances down the stretch. Kam Woods is the team's best creator, capable of takeover moments — 29 points at Oakland, 22 in the conference tournament — and he is as clutch as anyone on the roster, evidenced by multiple game-winning plays. Josh Omojafo provides reliable scoring off ball-movement and is an elite free-throw attacker. Depth beyond those four is a legitimate concern, with role players like Ryan Prather Jr. and DJ Smith contributing but not consistently threatening. Locationally, Robert Morris has been notably stronger at home (where they rarely lost after mid-January) but showed they can win on the road with victories at Northern Kentucky, Youngstown State, Milwaukee, and Cleveland State late in the year — a good sign for a neutral-site tournament. However, there are no ranked wins on this résumé, and the West Virginia blowout remains the starkest data point about how this team holds up against elite opposition. Robert Morris is a legitimate threat to make some noise as a 15-seed — their clutch-game experience, three-headed star power, and scorching late-season form make them more dangerous than a typical 15 — but the talent ceiling against a high-major 2-seed is almost certainly prohibitive. **Realistic tournament ceiling: First-round exit, with a puncher's chance at an upset if Folgueiras and Woods are at their peak.**

MORGANTOWN, W.Va. -- — Javon Small scored 12 of his 27 points in the final two minutes to lead West Virginia to a 64-57 win over No. 2 Iowa State on Saturday night, ending the Cyclones' national-best 12-game winning streak. West Virginia fans stormed the court and joined the players in singing John Denver’s “Take Me Home, Country Roads” on a day in which the school celebrated the life of NBA great Jerry West, who died last June at age 86. Curtis Jones scored 18 points to lead Iowa State (15-2, 5-1). Keshon Gilbert added 13 points and Josh Jefferson had 10 points and 10 rebounds. Takeaways Iowa State: The Cyclones committed 14 turnovers, attempted just seven free throws and appeared to be outhustled for loose balls all over the court. West Virginia: The Mountaineers maintained a physical defensive intensity throughout the game and held the Cyclones to their lowest point total of the season and 28 points below their average. Key moment Small, the Big 12's leading scorer, took over down the stretch. After Joseph Yesufu hit a layup with 2:02 left to give West Virginia the lead for good, 51-49, Small made a three-point play and hit two more free throws 20 seconds apart for a seven-point lead. His 3-pointer with 41 seconds left put West Virginia ahead 59-51. Key stat Iowa State made just one of 17 3-point attempts. TEMPE, Ariz. -- — Curtis Jones scored 33 points, Keshon Gilbert had seven of his 12 during a key run and No. 3 Iowa State pulled away late for a 76-61 win over Arizona State on Saturday. The Cyclones (17-2, 7-1 Big 12) bounced back from a loss to West Virginia with a 108-83 blowout of UCF on Tuesday, but found a lot less offensive freedom early against the scrappy Sun Devils. Iowa State took nearly four minutes to score its first points and trailed 40-33 at halftime. The Cyclones went back and forth with the Sun Devils (11-8, 2-6) in the second half until ratcheting up their defense in a game-closing 19-3 run. Gilbert scored seven straight points early in the run. Iowa State's Joshua Jefferson had 13 points and 10 rebounds. 2025-01-28 - Arizona: 86 vs Iowa State: 75

TUCSON, Ariz. -- — Caleb Love hit a tying heave from beyond halfcourt at the end of regulation and made two more 3-pointers in overtime, finishing with 22 points and lifting Arizona to an 86-75 win over No. 3 Iowa State on Monday night. The Cyclones (17-3, 7-2 Big 12) appeared to be in control when Joshua Jefferson hit one of two free throws with 2.2 seconds remaining, but they left too much time on the clock. Love, who was 1 for 10 on 3s at that point, took a couple of dribbles and banked in his shot from behind the midcourt logo, sending a roar through McKale Center. Love then hit two corner 3s in overtime and Carter Bryant added another to cap Arizona’s first win over a top-5 opponent as an unranked team since beating No. 3 UCLA in 1979. Tobe Awaka finished with 17 points and 12 rebounds for the Wildcats (14-6, 8-1). Tamin Lipsey scored 18 points and Keshon Gilbert added 17 to lead the Cyclones. Iowa State led by seven in the first half before Arizona answered with the biggest run against the Cyclones this year, scoring 16 straight points to go up 34-25. Lipsey, who had 14 first-half points, pulled the Cyclones within 34-30 at halftime on a corner 3. Takeaways Iowa State: The Cyclones have had a knack for pulling out close wins, but fell flat after Love's heave. Arizona: Love loves the big moments and had a massive one on a poor shooting night to give Arizona a memorable win. Key moment Love's incredible shot at the buzzer is one Arizona fans — maybe Iowa State's, too — won't forget for a long time. Key stat Iowa State shot 1 of 6 and had three turnovers in overtime. Jizzle James led the No. 13 seed Bearcats (18-15) with 17 points, but he missed his final six shots, which helped allow Iowa State finish the game on an 11-0 run. Josh Reed added 10 points and Day Day Thomas finished with nine. The Cyclones overcame 17 turnovers by dominating the glass, outrebounding the Bearcats 41-23. That led to a 36-16 advantage in points in the paint, where Cincinnati's 7-foot Aziz Bandaogo and 6-foot-8 Dillon Mitchell combined for just four points. Takeaways Cincinnati got 18 points and 15 rebounds from Mitchell in an 87-68 first-round victory over Oklahoma State. But the inability of him and Bandaogo to score against the 6-11 Jackson and 6-9 Jefferson was crucial to the outcome. Iowa State committed 18 turnovers against the Bearcats in a regular-season win. The Cyclones will need to hold onto the ball much better if they want to win a seventh Big 12 Tournament title. 2025-03-13 - BYU: 96 vs Iowa State: 92

KANSAS CITY, Mo. -- — Richie Saunders scored 23 points, hitting a crucial 3-pointer with less than a minute to go, and No. 17 BYU overcame a big game from Curtis Jones in a 96-92 victory over No. 12 Iowa State in the quarterfinals of the Big 12 Tournament on Thursday. Fousseyni Traore added 15 points and Trevin Knell had 14 for the fourth-seeded Cougars (24-8), who went 18 of 36 from beyond the arc to set a tournament record for made 3-pointers, and advanced to play No. 2 Houston or Colorado in the semifinals. Jones hit seven 3s of his own and scored 31 points, and Milan Momcilovic had 18 for the short-handed Cyclones (24-9), who had won their last four games at the Big 12 tourney, including their run to the championship a year ago. No. 5 seed Iowa State played without Keshon Gilbert, their second-leading scorer and top distributor, and point guard Tamin Lipsey, who had started all 101 games he had played in his career. Gilbert tried to play through a muscle strain against Cincinnati but went only 11 minutes, while Lipsey strained his groin in the closing minutes of the second-round win. BYU was without Kanon Catchings, who missed his third consecutive game after hurting his knee against West Virginia. The Cougars and Cyclones nevertheless picked up where they left off last week, when BYU ruined senior day at Iowa State in a double-overtime thriller. They raced up and down the floor, combined to hit 20 first-half 3-pointers, and Jones poured in 22 points — and hit eight straight shots at one point — to help the Cyclones to a 53-49 lead at the break. The Cougars still trailed 72-64 with 12 1/2 minutes to go when they went on an 11-0 run, and Mihailo Boskovic's 3-pointer gave them a 75-72 lead. Iowa State tied the game again moments later but was never able to regain the lead. BYU finished it off in the final minute from the foul line, where it was 18 of 21 for the game. Takeaways Iowa State was cautious with its two star guards in the hopes that they can be healthy for the NCAA Tournament. Gilbert was ruled out early and watched in street clothes while Lipsey tried to warm up but never entered the game. BYU committed 29 turnovers when it beat Iowa State last week. It had only 10 in the quarterfinal rematch. Key moment Saunders hit his third 3-pointer with 49.1 seconds left to give BYU a 92-88 lead. Momcilovic missed at the other end, and the Cougars were able to control the game the rest of the way. Key stats The teams combined for 31 3-pointers, which also set a Big 12 Tournament record. Up next BYU plays Friday night for a spot in the championship game. ------ This story has been corrected to show the final score was 96-92. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 all season. profile_summary:
Iowa State enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 3-seed with a 25-10 record — a résumé built on genuine Big 12 quality but undermined by a turbulent second half and a brutal injury situation heading into March. Against ranked opponents, the Cyclones went an impressive 7-5, with notable wins over then-No. 5 Marquette (81-70), then-No. 9 Kansas (74-57 at home and 79-69 in Boulder), No. 25 Baylor (74-55), and No. 22 Arizona (84-67), but suffered losses to Auburn, West Virginia, Kansas, Kansas State, Houston, Oklahoma State, Arizona, and BYU — a mixed bag that reveals a team capable of beating anyone on a given night while also being susceptible to opponents who force turnovers and impose physicality. Over their final five games, Iowa State went 3-2: a statement 84-67 home win over Arizona, a deflating double-overtime home loss to BYU 88-85 on Senior Day, a wire-to-wire 73-57 win at Kansas State, a solid 76-56 Big 12 Tournament win over Cincinnati, and then a 96-92 quarterfinal exit at the hands of BYU — producing a pattern of inconsistency and a concerning inability to close out BYU in two separate high-scoring shootouts. The Cyclones' identity is multifaceted: they can grind defensively — leading the country in scoring defense early in the season — but they also run and gun, with six players capable of scoring 20-plus on any night and a team-wide tendency to generate steals and force turnovers at an elite rate (16 steals in the UCF win, 18 in the BYU regular-season loss). However, they are alarmingly turnover-prone themselves, committing 18 or more turnovers in multiple losses and surrendering damaging transition points as a result.

The player availability situation is the defining concern entering the tournament: second-leading scorer and primary distributor Keshon Gilbert (muscle strain) played only 11 minutes in the Big 12 Tournament before being ruled out, and starting point guard Tamin Lipsey — who had started all 101 games of his career — strained his groin and never entered the quarterfinal against BYU. Curtis Jones, who leads the team at just over 17 points per game, has been brilliant at times — scoring 31 in the BYU quarterfinal loss and 33 against Arizona State — but his supporting cast without Gilbert and Lipsey is clearly diminished. Joshua Jefferson (career-high 30 vs. UCF), Milan Momcilovic (returned from a hand injury to provide 17-18 points in recent games), and Dishon Jackson (15 rebounds vs. Cincinnati) give Iowa State legitimate frontcourt depth, and the Cyclones are 14-1 at home but only 5-5 on the road — a split that matters less in a neutral-site tournament though it signals fragility away from Ames. The team has shown genuine resilience — coming back from 13 down at Texas Tech, 13 down at Iowa — but they have also been blown out at home by Kansas State (80-61) and at Kansas (69-52) when their offense and turnover margin collapsed simultaneously. If Gilbert and Lipsey are healthy, Iowa State is a legitimate Sweet 16 or Elite Eight threat with the firepower and defensive IQ to beat anyone in the bracket; if either remains compromised, the Cyclones are a dangerous but flawed 3-seed whose realistic ceiling is the Sweet 16, with a first or second-round upset loss entirely plausible against a team that can pressure the ball and exploit their turnover issues.

Calipari, who left Southeastern Conference rival Kentucky after last season, had previously been booed incessantly whenever stepping foot in Bud Walton Arena. That all changed when Eric Musselman, who coached Arkansas to three Sweet 16s in five seasons, departed last spring and Calipari bolted from the bluegrass of Kentucky for the foothills of the Ozarks. His new team looked a lot like his old ones. Lipscomb (1-1), the Atlantic Sun preseason favorite, put a scare into the Razorbacks (1-0) with a second-half run to pull within four points with just under seven minutes to play. Arkansas had led by 15 in the second half. Zvonimir Ivisic, one of seven players to make their Razorbacks debut Wednesday, hit a 3-pointer, a layup and two free throws in the span of a minute to stop the Bisons. Ivisic finished with 12 points. Jacob Ognacevic led Lipscomb with 16. Takeaways Lipscomb: The Bisons put up enough of a fight to suggest their projection as A-Sun champions is not farfetched. profile_summary:
Lipscomb enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 14-seed with a 25-10 record, having claimed the Atlantic Sun Conference regular season title and punched their ticket through the conference tournament. The résumé, however, carries significant asterisks when viewed through a national lens. Against Power Conference opponents, the Bisons went 0-3 — losing to #9 Kentucky by 29 (97-68), to Arkansas by 16 (76-60), and to Western Kentucky by five — with only the Arkansas game featuring a competitive second half before the Razorbacks pulled away. Those performances reveal a genuine gap between Lipscomb and high-major competition, which will matter enormously against a 3-seed opponent in the first round. Within the Atlantic Sun, however, Lipscomb was dominant and legitimate, finishing 14-4 in conference play and winning the conference tournament, including a 84-66 quarterfinal rout of Central Arkansas behind Joe Anderson's 28 points and a 76-65 final over North Alabama. Their final five game summaries — wins over Austin Peay (95-78), Central Arkansas in the regular season finale (78-60), Central Arkansas in the A-Sun tournament (84-66), the A-Sun tournament semifinal (result implied), and a 76-65 win over North Alabama in the tournament final — show a team playing its best basketball at exactly the right time, riding a four-game winning streak with commanding margins and balanced scoring contributions.

Lipscomb's identity is built almost entirely around Jacob Ognacevic, one of the more dangerous mid-major scorers in the country. The senior forward has posted a stunning string of performances throughout the year — 30 points against Duquesne, 32 against Middle Tennessee, 32 against Bellarmine, 31 against Austin Peay, 30 against Stetson, 28 against Austin Peay again, and 20-plus in the conference tournament — and enters the tournament as a genuine first-round concern for any opponent's scouting staff. Will Pruitt and Gyasi Powell provide credible secondary scoring, and Joe Anderson adds defensive activity (seven steals against Jacksonville alone) and perimeter shooting that makes the offense multidimensional. Stylistically, Lipscomb wins through offensive volume and Ognacevic's individual brilliance rather than elite defense or lockdown schemes; they are capable of high-scoring shootouts and have shown the ability to build comfortable leads, but they have also been susceptible to teams that can match their pace and exploit their defensive limitations — evidenced by losses to Eastern Kentucky (twice), North Alabama, and Middle Tennessee within conference play. Location-wise, the Bisons are functional on the road and at neutral sites, going through their conference tournament on their home floor in Nashville and generally performing well there, but their worst blowout losses (Kentucky, Arkansas) came away from home. As a 14-seed, Lipscomb is a dangerous first-round opponent — Ognacevic alone gives any 3-seed a genuine problem to solve — but the ceiling here is realistically a first-round upset followed by a second-round exit; the quality-competition losses are too lopsided and the defensive profile too soft to project this team advancing to the Sweet 16.

2024-11-05 - Memphis: 83 vs Missouri: 75

MEMPHIS, Tenn. -- — PJ Haggerty scored 22 of his 25 points in the second half when Memphis took over en route to an 83-75 win over Missouri in the season opener for both teams on Monday night. The Tigers trailed by 10 at halftime but shot 58% in the second half, while going 17-20 from the foul line. Mizzou made just 15 of 23 at the line. Tyrese Hunter and Moussa Cisse added 14 points apiece, nine each in the second half, and Colby Rogers scored 10. Anthony Robinson II led Missouri with 16 points, while Tamar Bates and Trent Pierce both had 13 and Aidan Shaw 10. Memphis only returned 8% of of its scoring after losing 14 players off of last year's roster and brought in 11 transfers, including Haggerty from Tulsa, Hunter from Texas, Cisse from Mississippi and Rogers from Wichita State. SMU transfer Tyrek Smith announced before the game he would be transferring without playing a game. Haggerty had five points to start a 16-2 run that turned an 11-point deficit into a 58-55 lead midway through the second half. He had 10 points in the surge. and another nine points in an 11-3 run that stretched the lead to 71-62 with 3:46 to play. Memphis has won seven straight season openers and 22 straight home openers. Pierce and Robinson hit back-to-back 3-pointers as Missouri took a 29-19 lead. Pierce's second 3 pushed the lead to 36-22 five minutes before halftime, which ended with Missouri on top 42-32. Missouri shot 54.5% (18 of 33) and held Memphis to 34% (11 of 32) with eight turnovers in the first half. Pierce's second 3-pointer capped a run of 10 straight makes that set the lead at 14. Missouri's last true road opener was 21 years ago. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP collegebasketball: and

profile_summary:
Memphis enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 5-seed with an impressive 29-6 record, having won the outright American Athletic Conference regular-season title — their first conference championship since 2012-13 — and the AAC Tournament crown, knocking off Wichita State, Tulane, and UAB in consecutive games to close the season on a scorching run. Against quality competition, the Tigers built a genuinely compelling résumé: they own ranked wins over then-No. 2 UConn (99-97 OT in the Maui Invitational), then-No. 16 Clemson (87-82 OT on the road), No. 21 Virginia (64-62 on the road), and No. 16 Ole Miss (87-70 at home), going approximately 5-4 against ranked opponents with losses to No. 4 Auburn (90-76 in the Maui title game), unranked Arkansas State at home (85-72, a brutal upset), unranked Mississippi State at home (66-79), and No. 14 ranked Wichita State on the road in overtime (84-79). The home losses to Arkansas State and Mississippi State are genuine red flags — both came as ranked games in which Memphis was flat, shot poorly, and never seriously threatened, exposing a troubling vulnerability to being caught disengaged on their own floor. Their five most recent games, however, tell a different story entirely: wins of +3, +1, +12, +5, and +16 in a stretch capped by the AAC Tournament run, suggesting a team that has found its footing and is peaking at precisely the right moment.

Memphis is built around a dynamic backcourt duo in PJ Haggerty and Tyrese Hunter, supplemented by a versatile frontcourt anchor in Dain Dainja — a combination that gives them multiple avenues to win on any given night. Haggerty, one of the nation's top scorers at over 22 points per game, is a relentless attacker who draws fouls (Memphis went 40-for-29 in free throw attempts in the UConn OT win alone) and can manufacture points in clutch moments, as evidenced by his 21-point second-half eruptions at Virginia and against East Carolina. Hunter is a legitimate perimeter weapon — he went 7-of-10 from three against UConn and hit the go-ahead triple in overtime at Clemson — while Dainja has evolved into a dominant interior force, posting 22-point, 11-rebound performances and shooting 10-of-12 or better from the field in multiple outings. Colby Rogers provides a reliable third scoring option off three-point shooting, and Moussa Cisse brings rebounding and rim protection. The team's identity is that of a resilient, comeback-capable squad that wins with defensive pressure — forcing turnovers in bunches and converting them into transition points — but they are prone to sluggish starts, turnovers (a season-high 22 in the UTSA game), and inexplicable first-half collapses that put them in early holes. They have proven repeatedly they can claw back — erasing double-digit deficits against Missouri, San Francisco, Clemson, UAB, and Virginia — but their inability to consistently sustain focus for 40 minutes has cost them at home. On the road and at neutral sites, Memphis is actually a different animal: their only true road losses came in the Maui Invitational title game against an undefeated No. 4 Auburn team and in overtime at Wichita State, while they went a sterling 4-0 in true road games against ranked opponents including Clemson and Virginia. The UConn and Michigan State wins at Maui confirm that neutral-site tournament basketball suits their style. Memphis is a legitimate Elite Eight contender and a dark-horse Final Four threat: dangerous, experienced in high-pressure situations, equipped with star power that can carry them past elite competition, but just inconsistent enough in focus and turnover control to remain vulnerable to an upset if they come out flat.

profile_summary:
Colorado State enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 12-seed with a 26-10 record — a résumé built on Mountain West Conference dominance but punctuated by real vulnerabilities against elite competition. The Rams finished second in the MWC at 16-4 and won the conference tournament, defeating Nevada, Utah State, and Boise State in succession to punch their ticket to the Big Dance on a nine-game win streak. Against genuinely quality opponents, however, the picture is mixed: Colorado State lost to ranked Ole Miss by 15 on a neutral site, was blown out at Colorado (72-55) and at Utah State (93-85), fell to VCU and Washington, and was upset at home by UC Riverside — losses that reveal a team capable of being overwhelmed by superior athleticism and early-game pressure. Their only ranked win of note came against Utah State in the MWC Tournament semifinals, a dominant 83-72 performance that saw the Rams lead wire-to-wire after jumping ahead 49-30 at the half. The final five games tell an encouraging story: wins over Boise State (83-73), Nevada in the MWC quarterfinals (67-59), Utah State (83-72), and Boise State again in the conference title game (69-56), all controlled and decisive performances, capped by Nique Clifford's career-high 36-point outburst in the regular-season finale at Boise State.

Clifford is the unambiguous engine of this team — a do-everything forward who is posting massive lines night after night, regularly contributing 20-plus points, double-digit rebounds, and five-plus assists while providing shot-blocking and defensive versatility. His 26 points and 11 rebounds against Utah State in the semis and 25 points and 14 boards against Nevada in the quarterfinals demonstrate that he elevates in big moments, and he gives Colorado State a legitimately elite individual weapon. The supporting cast is functional but streaky: Jalen Lake provides perimeter shooting and big-shot capability (he hit the walk-off 3-pointer to beat Boise State in January), Kyan Evans can get hot from three, and Jaylen Crocker-Johnson and Rashaan Mbemba contribute energy and efficient scoring off the bench. The Rams are capable of wire-to-wire blowouts at home — they dominated teams like UNLV (84-62), Wyoming (88-53), and Fresno State (91-64) in Fort Collins — but on the road and at neutral sites against physical, well-coached opponents, they have shown a troubling tendency to fall into deep early holes they cannot escape. Stylistically, they play a pace-and-share offense that can ignite quickly, but they are also capable of going cold for long stretches, and their defense has been porous against elite guards. Location matters here: the Rams are noticeably more comfortable at home and have struggled consistently when forced to play in hostile road environments. Entering the tournament on a nine-game winning streak with Clifford playing the best basketball of his college career, Colorado State is a legitimate threat to pull off a first-round upset as a 12-seed — but their inability to stay competitive against high-major, athletically superior opponents in non-conference play makes a deep run unlikely. **Realistic ceiling: Round of 32, with a first-round upset well within reach — but a Sweet 16 appearance would require Clifford to carry an enormous load against a level of competition that has consistently exposed this roster's limitations.**

name: Duke
summaries:
2024-11-05 - Duke: 96 vs Maine: 62

DURHAM, N.C. -- — Star freshman Cooper Flagg had 18 points, seven rebounds and five assists in his college debut, and No. 7 Duke beat Maine 96-62 on Monday night in the season opener for both teams. The 6-foot-9, 205-pound Flagg — the nation’s top-ranked recruit and a preseason Associated Press All-American — made 6 of 15 shots and all six of his free throws. Fellow rookie Kon Knueppel powered the offense with 22 points and three 3-pointers for the Blue Devils (1-0), who shot 55.6% for the game. Quion Burns scored 15 points for the Black Bears (0-1), which shot just 6 for 24 (25%) after halftime as Duke pulled away. Takeaways Maine: The Black Bears were picked fourth in the America East, their highest projected finish since the 2010-11 season. They hung around in the first half (45.5% shooting) but everything was a struggle after the break. Duke: The Atlantic Coast Conference favorite had six players score in double figures, including returnees Caleb Foster (11) and Tyrese Proctor (10). Key moment Duke pulled away with an 11-0 run in the second half. Knueppel made a corner 3 off a feed from Flagg and Sion James scored twice in the paint to push the margin to 60-39 with 14:33 left. Key stat Knueppel, a 6-7 wing, had 15 points on 5-for-8 shooting with a pair of 3s by halftime. That included a 4-point play in transition that had him outscoring Maine 13-9 in those opening 7 1/2 minutes as Duke ran out to a double-digit lead. Up next The Blue Devils host Army on Friday in a home tuneup before facing No. 23 Kentucky in next week's Champions Classic in Atlanta. The Black Bears return home Wednesday to host Maine-Fort Kent, a United States Collegiate Athletic Association member. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2024-11-08 - Duke: 100 vs Army: 58

DURHAM, N.C. -- — Cooper Flagg had 13 points and 11 rebounds and No. 7 Duke rolled to a 100-58 victory over Army on Friday night. Khaman Maluach had 11 points and 14 boards for the Blue Devils (2-0). Kon Knueppel added 15 points, Tyrese Proctor tallied 14, Sion James had 12 and Caleb Foster scored 11 for Duke. For Army (1-1), Jalen Rucker scored 17 points, while Josh Scovens added 16 points and seven rebounds. Former Army and Duke coach Mike Krzyzewski, a West Point graduate and the all-time winningest coach in the history of Division I men's college basketball, sat courtside at Cameron Indoor Stadium with his wife Mickie. Takeaways Duke: Flagg only played 25 minutes and seemed to be battling cramps on the sideline in the second half, using a massage tool on his hamstrings and guzzling Gatorade. Against more marquee opponents, Duke will need the preseason AP All-American to be available for the entirety of the game. Army: The Black Knights allowed Duke to make 17 3-pointers, more than the Blue Devils made in any game last season. Key moment Flagg dunked a lob from Proctor to complete a fast-break alley-oop after James stole the ball from Army. Flagg's two-handed transition slam ignited a 29-7 Duke run over the next 13 minutes. Key stat Duke dominated on the glass and inside, outscoring the undersized Black Knights 36-18 in the paint and 17-7 on second-chance points. The Blue Devils outrebounded Army 50-32. Up next The Blue Devils face their first major conference opponent of the season Tuesday, taking on No. 23 Kentucky in Atlanta the same day the Black Knights return home to host Division III Mount Saint Mary. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. ATLANTA -- — Otega Oweh knocked down four free throws in the final 10.3 seconds and No. 19 Kentucky claimed the first big win of Mark Pope’s coaching tenure, knocking off No. 6 Duke 77-72 in the Champions Classic on Tuesday night. In the frenetic closing seconds, Duke (2-1) tied the game at 72 on Cooper Flagg’s lay-in with 1:14 remaining but never got off another shot. Flagg ruined a 26-point night by turning it over twice in the final minute to hand the victory to the Wildcats (3-0). Oweh had a steal that led to a pair of free throws, then snatched away an offensive rebound off a missed free throw by Lamont Butler, drawing another foul that set up two more free throws with 0.5 seconds left. Andrew Carr paced Kentucky with 17 points, while Oweh added 15. It was a huge win for Pope, a former Kentucky player who returned to his alma mater after the departure of long-time coach John Calipari. Takeawa ys Duke: The Blue Devils turned it over only seven times all night, but Flagg's miscues at the end cost them a chance to pull out the victory. Kentucky: The Wildcats showed plenty of balance. Only three players reached double figures but nine players registered on the scoresheet. Key moment With Duke trailing 74-72, Flagg stumbled as he dribbled into the corner and wound up putting his hand on the end line while trying to regain his balance, turning the ball over to the Wildcats with 5 seconds remaining. 2025-03-16 - Duke: 73 vs Louisville: 62
profile_summary: Duke enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as the consensus No. 1 overall seed with a 35-4 record and the ACC regular-season and tournament titles in hand — a résumé that places them among the most complete teams in the country. Against ranked opponents, the Blue Devils went an impressive 7-4, with marquee wins over then-No. 2 Auburn (84-78), No. 17 Arizona (69-55), No. 10 Clemson in the ACC Tournament final (73-62), and No. 13 Louisville (74-71 and 73-62) bracketing losses to No. 19 Kentucky (77-72), No. 1 Kansas (75-72), and No. 18 Clemson (77-71) in the regular season — three games decided by a combined nine points. Those losses reveal a vulnerability against elite, disciplined opponents in close-game situations, particularly when Cooper Flagg is hampered or commits late-game turnovers, as he did against Kentucky. The five most recent games (ACC Tournament quarterfinal through the title game and final regular-season stretch) tell a story of remarkable resilience: Duke beat Georgia Tech 78-70 without Flagg after he left with a foot injury, then outlasted North Carolina 74-71 in the semis — again without Flagg — before dispatching Louisville 73-62 in the championship. Those back-to-back wins without their best player are among the most encouraging data points of the season and speak to genuine depth. Flagg's status entering the tournament is the central health concern; he was listed as limited but available, and when healthy he has been transcendent, setting an ACC freshman scoring record with a 42-point performance against Notre Dame (11-of-14 shooting, 16-of-17 from the line) and posting 13 double-doubles across the season. He is surrounded by a legitimately dangerous supporting cast: Kon Knueppel (28 points in the ACC quarterfinal win without Flagg) is a high-efficiency freshman wing capable of taking over games, Tyrese Proctor provides veteran scoring punch, and 7-foot-2 freshman Khaman Maluach gives Duke a physically imposing interior presence. Defensively, Duke has been elite all season — ranked first in KenPom's adjusted defensive efficiency early in the year — and the Blue Devils held opponents to season lows in point totals with regularity, including a stunning 86-35 dismantling of Wofford and a 110-67 destruction of Illinois at Madison Square Garden, the most lopsided loss in Illini history. Duke is a wire-to-wire dominant team that can also grind: they came back from 14 down at Louisville, from 11 down at Boston College, and erased large deficits against NC State and North Carolina in the regular season finale, signaling composure and adaptability rather than a team that folds under pressure — though late-game turnover issues, specifically Flagg's costly miscues against Kentucky and Clemson, remain a real concern in tournament survival situations. Locationally, the Blue Devils were virtually unbeatable at home (14-0 in Cameron), solid on the road (going 8-2 away from Durham including impressive wins in Tucson and at Chapel Hill), and dangerous on neutral courts, winning the ACC Tournament in Charlotte while handling marquee neutral-site games in Las Vegas, New York, and Atlanta competitively. Injury monitoring will be critical — beyond Flagg's foot, Maliq Brown dislocated his shoulder and Tyrese Proctor missed time with a knee injury late in the season — but the Blue Devils have shown they can win without any one piece. **Duke is a legitimate national championship contender.** The combination of a historically great freshman class led by a generational talent in Flagg, elite defense, tournament-tested depth, and the resilience to win without their star player gives this team a ceiling that reaches the final weekend in San Antonio — and the evidence strongly suggests they will be there.

"Whether it's law of averages coming through or just a little resiliency ... or maybe it's just desperation by some seniors who don't want this thing to end.” The Bulldogs also got some measure of revenge for losing to the Gaels in last year's title game, which ended Gonzaga's run of four conference championships and 10 of 11. Gonzaga also extended its national record to 18 consecutive 25-win seasons. Saint Mary's (28-5) had its seven-game winning streak stopped. The Gaels also had won 17 of 18 games. “We've had a great year,” Saint Mary's coach Randy Bennett said. “We did not play well tonight.” Khalif Battle scored 14 points for the Zags, Graham Ike added 11 and Ryan Nembhard had 10. Mitchell Saxen led Saint Mary's with 20 points but scored only six after halftime. Two-time WCC Player of the Year Augustas Marciulionis finished with 12 points. Saint Mary’s was attempting to become the first team since San Diego in 1996-97 to beat Gonzaga three times in a season. But Gonzaga entered the game with the higher Kenpom rating, ninth to 22nd for the Gaels, and was a 3 1/2-point favorite at Sportsbook. “You've got to go through some hardships in order to win,” Battle said. “We've been practicing for this moment. I think we were prepared more than ever going into this tournament, so I'm happy we were able to hoist the trophy.” Takeaways Gonzaga: The Bulldogs committed just four turnovers while forcing 18 that included two shot-clock violations in the closing minutes. Saint Mary's: The Gaels are the first ranked team since No. 25 Texas A&M in 2011 to go at least 0 for 16 from 3-point range and commit 18 or more turnovers. Key moment Marciulionis' layup with 15:09 left brought Saint Mary's within a point, but the Gaels went the next 7:36 without a field goal as Gonzaga built a 48-42 lead. Key stats The teams combined to shoot 1 of 31 on 3-pointers, the third-worst combined percentage in any game over the past 20 years. Saint Mary's went 0 for 16. Up next Both teams will find out their NCAA Tournament seeds and destinations on Sunday. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 all season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and
profile_summary:
Saint Mary's enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 7-seed with a 29-6 record and the outright WCC regular-season title — a program-best 17-1 conference mark that speaks to genuine dominance within their league, even if questions linger about how they stack up against elite national competition. Against quality opponents, the Gaels went 1-2 in notable non-conference tests: a narrow 77-74 win over Nebraska in Sioux Falls and a road victory at Utah (72-63), but losses to Arizona State (64-68) and Boise State (65-67 in OT) revealed vulnerabilities against athletic, physical teams that can pressure them into mistakes. Their ranked wins are limited — Nebraska and Utah appear to be the most credible scalps — while the loss to Gonzaga in the WCC Tournament final (51-58) was damning: Saint Mary's went 0-for-16 from three, committed 18 turnovers, and went over seven minutes without a field goal in the second half, becoming the first ranked team since 2011 to combine those two statistics in a single game. Over their final five games (wins over LMU 58-55, Oregon State 74-64, and Pepperdine 74-59, followed by the Gonzaga WCC final loss), the Gaels were mostly grinding out victories rather than imposing their will — the LMU win required a Murauskas shot-clock-beating corner three with 30 seconds left, and they shot just 38% in that game — before the tournament finale exposed serious perimeter shooting fragility and turnover issues under elite defensive pressure.

Saint Mary's is built around two standout players: Augustas Marciulionis, the two-time WCC Player of the Year who regularly puts up 17-25 points with elite assist and steal numbers, and Paulius Murauskas, a versatile big who can erupt for 29-30 points on nights he's dialed in from three (his 6-for-10 three-point performance at Utah was exceptional), though his shot-making is inconsistent — he is just a 31% three-point shooter on the season. Mitchell Saxen provides a reliable interior presence (double-doubles throughout conference play), and Mikey Lewis offers valuable bench scoring, including a 5-for-7 three-point performance in the win at Gonzaga during the regular season. The Gaels win by controlling the glass (they outrebounded LMU 43-26, including 12-2 on the offensive boards), playing disciplined half-court offense, and grinding opponents into low-scoring games — they held 27 of 32 opponents under 70 points. However, they are collapse-prone in the right circumstances: the WCC final showed they can completely fall apart from the perimeter, and their turnover issues (18 in the Gonzaga loss) are a legitimate concern against high-pressure defenses they'll see in March. Location-wise, Saint Mary's is dominant at home (strong throughout WCC play), solid on the road (wins at Utah, Gonzaga in the regular season, Oregon State), but their neutral-site record is mixed — the Arizona State loss in Palm Springs and the Gonzaga WCC final loss in Las Vegas suggest they haven't consistently translated their regular-season dominance to neutral courts. Saint Mary's is a dangerous, well-coached team with enough star power and rebounding toughness to beat a higher seed — but their three-point shooting volatility, turnover vulnerability against elite defenses, and limited résumé against top-25 competition make a deep run unlikely. **Realistic tournament ceiling: Round of 32 to Sweet 16, with a first-round upset of a 10-seed well within reach, but a second-round matchup against a high-major athletic team likely ends their run.**

Biel hit from deep with 39 seconds left and Ward knocked down a jumper with 4 seconds to go to trail 40-38 at intermission. Edwards converted 8 of 9 from the line and finished with 17 points to lead Vanderbilt (2-0). McGlockton hit 6 of 9 from the line to add 14 points and pulled down 19 rebounds. Tyler Nickel added 11 points and eight rebounds. AJ Hoggard hit 7 of 10 from the line off the bench and added 11 points. Ward finished with 22 points and five assists to lead the Redhawks (0-2), who shot 28 of 63 overall from the floor (44.4%). profile_summary: Vanderbilt enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 10-seed with a 20-13 record — a résumé that vastly exceeded preseason expectations after the Commodores were picked to finish last in the SEC. Against ranked opponents, Vanderbilt went an impressive 5-6, with signature home wins over #6 Tennessee (76-75), #9 Kentucky (74-69), #24 Ole Miss (77-72), #12 Texas A&M (86-84 on the road), and #14 Missouri (97-93 in overtime) — a collection of upsets that gave first-year coach Mark Byington genuine tournament credibility. That said, the Commodores also absorbed blowout losses to #4 Alabama (103-87), #1 Auburn (80-68), #5 Florida (86-75), and #17 Kentucky (82-61), exposing a significant ceiling against truly elite competition. Recent form is a concern: over the final five games, Vanderbilt went 2-3, beating unranked Arkansas (loss, 90-77), ranked Missouri (win, 97-93 OT), ranked Texas A&M (win, 86-84), then losing at Georgia (79-68) and falling in the SEC Tournament's first round to 13-seed Texas (79-72) — a deflating exit that raises real questions about readiness. The Commodores play an uptempo, high-scoring style that thrives in chaotic, close games; their best wins have come down to final possessions, with clutch sequences like Nickel's buzzer-tying three against Missouri and McGlockton's game-winning and-one against South Carolina illustrating their scrappy, resilient identity. Jason Edwards is the unquestioned engine, capable of 20-30 point outbursts (24 vs. Tennessee, 26 vs. Drake), though he went scoreless against Mississippi State and needed 20 shots for 21 points at Oklahoma — his inconsistency is Vanderbilt's biggest wildcard. The Commodores are dramatically better at home (13-2 at Memorial Gym, which hosted back-to-back sellouts and two court-stormings) than on the road (roughly 4-9 away from Nashville), and their SEC Tournament first-round loss to a 13-seed Texas team on a neutral court is a troubling data point heading into a neutral-site event. Vanderbilt is a dangerous, unpredictable 10-seed with proven upsets on their résumé and the ability to win close, frenetic games — but their road/neutral-site struggles, second-half defensive collapses (opponents shoot 56% in second halves of conference games), and inability to sustain leads against elite defenses suggest a ceiling of the second round; a first-round upset is very much within reach, but a Sweet 16 run would require a level of road-game composure this team has rarely demonstrated.

profile_summary: Ole Miss enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 6-seed with a 24-12 record — a résumé built on genuine toughness in one of college basketball's deepest conferences, though not without its share of vulnerabilities. Against ranked opponents, the Rebels went approximately 5-9, with marquee wins over No. 4 Alabama (74-64 on the road), No. 14 Kentucky (98-84 at home), No. 4 Tennessee (78-76 at home), No. 23 Arkansas (73-66 on the road), and No. 13 BYU (96-85 in overtime at a neutral site), while absorbing losses to No. 1 Auburn twice, No. 1 Auburn in the SEC Tournament, No. 13 Purdue (78-80 on a buzzer putback), No. 13 Texas A&M (62-63 at the buzzer), and No. 22 Missouri, among others — a pattern that reveals a team capable of beating elite opponents but prone to late-game collapses against the very best. Their final five games tell a nuanced story: a dramatic 78-76 home win over No. 4 Tennessee on Brakefield's layup with 7 seconds left, a 19-point blowout loss at No. 5 Florida, a thrilling 83-80 SEC Tournament win over Arkansas on Pedulla's buzzer three after two missed Razorback free throws, and a 62-57 quarterfinal loss to No. 1 Auburn — producing a 2-3 finish down the stretch that is neither a hot streak nor a full-blown slump, but rather a familiar Ole Miss pattern of beating good teams and struggling to sustain it against the elite. Stylistically, the Rebels are a perimeter-oriented, turnover-averse team — they led the nation in fewest turnovers per game at 8.8 — capable of explosive shooting nights (13-of-30 from three vs. Kentucky, six Murrell threes in the first half alone) but also susceptible to rebounding deficits that have burned them repeatedly; Mississippi State outrebounded them 51-29 in one meeting, Texas A&M had a 48-31 edge in another, and Auburn consistently dominated the glass, and those size mismatches are a structural weakness that tournament opponents will exploit. Sean Pedulla is the engine of this team — a clutch, high-volume guard who has delivered in multiple pressure moments including the go-ahead three vs. Oklahoma, the tournament-winner vs. Arkansas, and a 29-point performance against No. 1 Auburn — while Malik Dia has been arguably the Rebels' most complete player in SEC play, erupting for 21, 19, and 23 points in a three-game stretch against Arkansas, LSU, and Alabama respectively, and Jaemyn Brakefield has provided crucial secondary scoring and clutch buckets, including the game-winner against Tennessee. Matthew Murrell's availability has been a concern — he missed multiple games with a lower-body injury — though he has been active and productive in the tournament stretch. At home, Ole Miss was dominant for most of the season (wins over Kentucky, Tennessee, Texas, Auburn nearly), but road and neutral-site results are genuinely mixed: strong road wins at Arkansas and Alabama sit alongside blowout losses at Auburn and Florida and neutral-site defeats to Purdue and Missouri, suggesting the Rebels are a better team when the crowd is behind them. They carry a resilient, never-quite-broken identity — they are 5-0 in games decided by four points or fewer since late January — but that same habit of living in close games reflects an inconsistency that has cost them when the margin for error disappears. Ole Miss is a dangerous, tournament-tested 6-seed with real upset potential and the perimeter firepower to light up any opponent on a given night, but their rebounding deficiencies, road inconsistency, and 1-4 record against top-five teams this season cap their realistic ceiling at the **Sweet 16** — threatening enough to knock off a 3-seed, but likely short of the firepower and frontcourt depth needed to advance further.

2024-11-05 - Maryland: 79 vs Manhattan: 49

COLLEGE PARK, Md. -- — Derik Queen scored 22 points and grabbed 20 rebounds, Ja'Kobi Gillespie added 16 points and five assists and Maryland pulled away in the second half to beat Manhattan 79-49 Monday night in the season opener for both teams. Queen, a consensus five-star recruit and the second-highest ranked recruit in program history, is the first Division I freshman with at least 20 points and 20-plus rebounds in his debut since Michael Beasley did it for Kansas State against Sacramento State on Nov. 9, 2007. The 6-foot-10 Queen had 11 points and 12 rebounds by halftime as the Terrapins took a 31-28 lead into the break. Maryland made just 11 of 30 (36.7%) from the field, 2 of 11 (18.2%) from 3-point range, in the first half but outrebounded the Jaspers 24-13. The Terrapins used a 8-0 advantage on the offensive glass to outscore Manhattan 7-0 in second-chance points. Queen scored seven consecutive points to push Maryland's lead into double figures for the first time at 43-32 with 16:34 to play. Shaquil Bender answered with a layup and then a 3-pointer before Gillespie — who averaged 17.2 points, 4.2 assists, 3.8 rebounds, and 2.2 steals in 25 games for Belmont last season — scored the final five points in a 9-0 spurt that made it 52-37 with 14 minutes remaining. Maryland has won 48 consecutive home openers, the third longest active streak in the nation, dating to Nov. 27, 1976. Bender led the Jaspers with 12 points and Devin Dinkins scored 10. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2024-11-24 - Maryland: 76 vs Villanova: 75

NEWARK, N.J, -- — Derik Queen knocked down two free throws with 19 seconds left to complete a second-half Maryland comeback and the Terrapins beat Villanova 76-75 to win the Saatva Empire Classic on Sunday afternoon. Maryland shot 17 of 29 in the second half, knocking down 4 of 9 from long range to fuel its comeback. Eric Dixon hit four 3-pointers and scored 22 points in the first half as Villanova built a 12-point halftime lead, 40-28, but the Terrapins climbed back in the second half. 2025-03-15 - Maryland: 80 vs Michigan: 81

INDIANAPOLIS -- — Tre Donaldson drove the length of the court and scored on a layup with 0.4 seconds left to give No. 22 Michigan an 81-80 victory over No. 11 Maryland in the Big Ten Tournament semifinals Saturday. Donaldson finished with 12 points and nine assists, but the heavy lifting was done by Vladislav Goldin, who had 25 points and 10 rebounds, and Danny Wolf Jr. with 21 points and 14 rebounds. The Wolverines (24-9) will face No. 18 Wisconsin in Sunday's championship game in Indianapolis. Donaldson's remarkable drive rekindled images of Tyus Edney in 1995 and Danny Ainge in 1981, who made similar plays to add their stories to the March Madness book. This time, Maryland tried to preserve the lead without fouling. Derik Queen finished with a career high 31 points to lead the Terrapins (25-8) who entered the game on a nine-game winning streak. Selton Miguel added 16 points. Maryland has never reached the tourney's title game. Takeaways Michigan: The tandem of Wolf and Goldin — and the heroic play by Donaldson — were good enough to carry the Wolverines in the semifinals. But if they have another game with 19 turnovers, their dreams could end. Maryland: The Terrapins have relied heavily, perhaps too heavily, on points from their starters. But the bigger problem was not to front Donaldson on the drive, forcing him to burn precious time. Key moment Donaldson's full sprint from near his own baseline straight to the rim. Key stat Michigan's 47-18 rebounding edge was so dominant Wolf nearly outrebounded Maryland by himself. profile_summary:
Maryland enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 4-seed with a 27-9 record and one of the most balanced offensive attacks in the country, built around what the program has dubbed the "Crab Five" — a starting unit that has been dominant enough to outscore opponents on its own. Against ranked opponents, the Terrapins went an impressive 8-7, with statement wins over No. 17 Illinois (91-70 on the road), No. 22 UCLA (79-61), No. 17 Wisconsin (76-68), No. 18 Rutgers (90-81), and No. 15 Michigan (71-65 in Ann Arbor), plus a pair of ranked road wins late in the season that demonstrated genuine toughness. Their losses to ranked teams — No. 15 Marquette, No. 8 Purdue, No. 9 Oregon, No. 18 Ohio State (a stunning 17-point collapse), and No. 8 Michigan State twice, including a half-court buzzer-beater at home — reveal a team that can go toe-to-toe with elites but has a troubling habit of late-game meltdowns. In the Big Ten Tournament, Maryland demolished No. 24 Illinois 88-65 with just three turnovers before falling 81-80 to Michigan on a full-court layup with 0.4 seconds remaining — a brutal but emblematic ending for a team that keeps finding new and painful ways to lose close games.

Freshman center Derik Queen is the engine of this offense and has been sensational of late — posting a career-high 31 points in the Big Ten semifinal loss and averaging what amounts to a double-double threat every night, with elite footwork and free-throw drawing ability (9-for-11 shooting, 6-for-6 at the line against Nebraska). Ja'Kobi Gillespie is a steady, high-IQ transfer guard averaging around 15-18 points across the final stretch, while Rodney Rice provides explosive perimeter scoring — his 23-point, five-of-seven from three performance to win at Indiana exemplifies the kind of timely shooting this team can produce. Julian Reese is a reliable double-double big and Selton Miguel is one of the more underrated shooters in the Big Ten. The concern, however, is depth: the starting five scores the overwhelming majority of Maryland's points (85 of 88 against USC, 95 of 101 against Iowa), and when Queen and Reese go cold simultaneously — as they did shooting 4-of-18 combined against Michigan State — the offense has no reliable alternative. Location matters enormously for this team: Maryland was 16-1 at home but a pedestrian 3-5 in true road games before finishing 3-6, and their neutral-site résumé is mixed, though they did win the Empire Classic over Villanova on a clutch Queen free throw. The Terrapins play a high-octane, starting-five-dependent style that can blow teams out (108-37 over Canisius, 101-75 over Iowa) but is dangerously prone to second-half shooting collapses and turnover-induced breakdowns — they were held to 25% shooting in the second half at Ohio State and committed 16 turnovers in the Northwestern overtime loss. Maryland's realistic tournament ceiling is the Elite Eight: Queen's star power and the starting unit's offensive balance make them a genuine danger to any mid-seed opponent, and their ranked-win portfolio proves they can beat good teams, but their late-game fragility, bench-scoring vacuum, and history of catastrophic collapses against elite defenses make a Final Four run a long shot without significant improvement in closing out games.

2025-03-16 - Florida: 86 vs Tennessee: 77
profile_summary:
Florida enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 1-seed with a dominant 36-4 record and one of the most compelling résumés in the country. The Gators' record against ranked opponents is exceptional — notable wins include a 73-43 dismantling of then-No. 1 Tennessee at home in January, a stunning 90-81 road victory over No. 1 Auburn in February, a 99-94 road win over No. 7 Alabama, and a 83-66 neutral-site win over Arizona State, giving Florida multiple top-10 road and neutral-site wins that few teams in the nation can match. Their only losses came against Kentucky (106-100 on the road), Missouri (83-82 at home on a late free throw), Tennessee (64-44 on the road without a healthy Walter Clayton Jr.), and Georgia (88-83 in a stunning collapse after leading by 13). In the SEC Tournament, Florida closed the season by running through Missouri (95-81), Alabama (104-82), and Tennessee (86-77) in consecutive days — a statement stretch that underlined their depth, firepower, and ability to win the big game when it matters most. Their season-long 36-4 record, combined with a 15-1 home mark, a 29-2 two-year home record, and multiple signature road wins, places them firmly in the national title conversation.

Stylistically, Florida is a multi-dimensional offensive juggernaut with serious defensive teeth. The Gators consistently launch double-digit 3-point attempts and connect at a high rate — they hit 16 3s against Southern Illinois, 14 against Auburn, and 14 against Mississippi State — while also dominating on the glass, routinely posting significant offensive rebounding advantages that generate devastating second-chance points. Walter Clayton Jr., who carries a school-record streak of consecutive games with a 3-pointer (now at 53), is the engine: a 33-point performance against Kentucky and 22-point outings against Alabama and Tennessee in the SEC Tournament confirm he is a true NBA-caliber closer. Alijah Martin (32 points against Southern Illinois, 26 at Kentucky), Will Richard (30 points at Georgia, 25 against Texas A&M), and Alex Condon (27 points and 10 rebounds against Alabama) give Florida four legitimate scoring options who can go off on any given night. Thomas Haugh has emerged as perhaps the country's best sixth man, providing 16-20 point bursts off the bench in critical games. The primary concern entering the tournament is frontcourt depth — Condon suffered a low ankle sprain and missed four games, Sam Alexis has also battled an ankle injury, and Micah Handlogten is still rounding into form after a gruesome leg injury. Florida has also shown a willingness to let games get closer than they should, trailing by 26 at Georgia before nearly completing a comeback and needing a Will Richard buzzer layup to survive South Carolina — but they have shown composure and resilience in nearly every pressure situation this season, rarely panicking and often overwhelming opponents with sustained runs. This is a national championship-caliber team: deep, experienced, star-driven, battle-tested against elite competition, and playing their best basketball entering March. **Florida's realistic tournament ceiling is a national championship**.

profile_summary: Norfolk State enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 16-seed with a 24-11 record, earning an automatic bid after winning the MEAC Tournament on a buzzer-beater — Christian Ings' late heroics capping a 66-65 win over South Carolina State in the championship game. The Spartans' résumé against quality competition is honest: they were blown out by Baylor (94-69) and lost to a No. 1 Tennessee squad (67-52), were handled by Stanford (70-63) and fell to Hofstra and Northern Kentucky during a rough mid-season stretch, going 0-5 against that group of high-major and upper-mid-major opponents. Their five losses in the final stretch of the regular season — including overtime defeats at South Carolina State and North Carolina Central — revealed a vulnerability on the road and in high-stakes moments, though they ultimately righted the ship by winning the MEAC title outright. Brian Moore Jr. is the engine of this team, posting a 33-point performance at High Point, a buzzer-beating three to beat North Carolina Central in February, and consistent 18-27 point outputs down the stretch; when he is locked in, Norfolk State's offense has real teeth. Christian Ings and Jalen Myers provide reliable secondary scoring, and the Spartans are capable of erupting offensively — posting 96, 105, and 92 points in blowout MEAC wins — but their style fluctuates wildly between high-scoring shootouts, clutch escapes, and flat, scoreless stretches, as evidenced by a nearly 7-minute scoring drought against Tennessee. Their final five games were a rollercoaster: a close overtime loss at South Carolina State, a heartbreaking overtime loss at North Carolina Central, a regular-season-ending road win at Howard to clinch a share of the MEAC title, and then consecutive tournament wins over Morgan State (58-55) and South Carolina State (66-65) — the latter on a last-second margin, suggesting a team that finds ways to win without always dominating. Norfolk State is scrappy and resilient, but not a team that imposes its will on opponents; they are better at home (strong MEAC record) and have struggled consistently on the road and against power-conference opponents. As a 16-seed, they are a likely first-round exit — Moore is a legitimate mid-major star capable of a big individual performance, but there is no credible evidence this group can sustain competitiveness against a 1-seed for 40 minutes, and their tendency to go cold offensively and surrender large runs against elite defenses is disqualifying for an upset.

2024-11-05 - Kentucky: 103 vs Wright State: 62

LEXINGTON, Ky. -- — Otega Oweh scored 21 points, Koby Brea added 18 off the bench, and No. 23 Kentucky shot 60% to blow out Wright State 103-62 in Mark Pope's Wildcat debut on Monday night. Pope replaced John Calipari in April after the Hall of Famer left for Arkansas and revamped the roster with nine transfers. Oweh, an Oklahoma transfer, went 8 for 9 from the floor and made all three shots from deep. Brea made all four of his 3-pointers for Kentucky, which shot 11 of 24 from behind the arc. Lamont Butler shot 6 of 12 for 14 points while Amari Williams, who left Kentucky's final exhibition game with an injury, scored 12 points and grabbed 13 rebounds. Andrew Carr and Ansley Almonor each had 11 for the Wildcats. Brandon Noel had 20 points, Alex Huibregtse scored 16 and Solomon Callaghan added 15 for the Raiders, who shot just 35% from the field. Takeaways Wright State: The Raiders' only consistent offensive stretch didn't come until it strung together four consecutive baskets in the second half. Wright State had to work for opportunities against a Kentucky defense that challenged everything. Kentucky: The Wildcats were quick at both ends of the floor, attacking the glass defensively and spreading the ball around on the other end. The Wildcats owned the boards 41-32 and outscored the Raiders 56-26 in the paint and 37-21 in bench points. Key moment Pope walked into Rupp Arena to a crowd of 19,635 that was spread out around the arena he once called home. Key stat 30 — Kentucky's assists on 39 baskets. Up next Wright State hosts Ohio Christian on Wednesday night, while Kentucky hosts Bucknell on Saturday before facing Duke in the Champions Classic. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on AP Top 25 basketball throughout the season. 2024-11-09 - Kentucky: 100 vs Bucknell: 72

LEXINGTON, Ky -- — Koby Brea came off the bench to score 20 points, including six three-pointers, and Jaxson Robinson added 14 as No. 23 Kentucky overwhelmed Bucknell 100-72 Saturday. The Wildcats (2-0) were cold from three-point range early in the first half, but Brea and Kerr Krissa each hit threes within 30 seconds to open up a 20-7 Kentucky lead with 13:08 left in the first half. The Bison (2-1) were led by Ian Motta’s 18 points as the team shot just 39.7%. Josh Bascoe added 15 points. Amari Williams added 13 points, Andrew Carr had 11 and Otega Owens had 10 points for Kentucky. Williams also had 14 rebounds for his second straight double-double. Krissa had 12 assists. Takeaways Bucknell: The Bison were also cold at the start. They fell behind 22-9 in the first 10 minutes of the game, shooting just 3-of-12. Kentucky: It was another team effort, as 10 players scored. Despite the slow shooting start on 3-pointers, they did score 50 points in the paint and 22 points off 14 Bison turnovers. Key moment Kentucky seized control of the game early, putting together a 9-1 and 9-0 run enroute to a 31-11 lead with 8:55 lead in the first half. The closest Bucknell would get after that was 35-23 on a Motta jumper with 4:37 left in the first half. Key stat Kentucky Coach Mark Pope had emphasized rebounding after the Wildcats’ opening win, especially offensive rebounding. 2024-11-13 - Kentucky: 77 vs Duke: 72

ATLANTA -- — Otega Oweh knocked down four free throws in the final 10.3 seconds and No. 19 Kentucky claimed the first big win of Mark Pope’s coaching tenure, knocking off No. 6 Duke 77-72 in the Champions Classic on Tuesday night. In the frenetic closing seconds, Duke (2-1) tied the game at 72 on Cooper Flagg’s lay-in with 1:14 remaining but never got off another shot. Flagg ruined a 26-point night by turning it over twice in the final minute to hand the victory to the Wildcats (3-0). Oweh had a steal that led to a pair of free throws, then snatched away an offensive rebound off a missed free throw by Lamont Butler, drawing another foul that set up two more free throws with 0.5 seconds left. Andrew Carr paced Kentucky with 17 points, while Oweh added 15. It was a huge win for Pope, a former Kentucky player who returned to his alma mater after the departure of long-time coach John Calipari. Takeawa ys Duke: The Blue Devils turned it over only seven times all night, but Flagg's miscues at the end cost them a chance to pull out the victory. Kentucky: The Wildcats showed plenty of balance. Only three players reached double figures but nine players registered on the scoresheet. Key moment With Duke trailing 74-72, Flagg stumbled as he dribbled into the corner and wound up putting his hand on the end line while trying to regain his balance, turning the ball over to the Wildcats with 5 seconds remaining. Key stat Duke was just 4 of 23 from 3-point range, while the Wildcats made 10 of 25 beyond the arc. Up next Duke returns home to face Wofford on Saturday. LEXINGTON, Ky. -- — Lamont Butler returned from a two-game absence to shoot perfect from the field for a career-high 33 points, including six 3-pointers, and No. 5 Kentucky held off rival Louisville 93-85 on Saturday for Bluegrass supremacy. Kentucky (10-1) shot 58%, including 70% before halftime, but needed every basket to stay clear of the Cardinals (6-5). Butler, who made all 10 of his shot attempts, provided a boost with three consecutive 3-pointers coming out of the break and 14 of Kentucky’s first 16 points overall, including a layup for a 59-49 cushion. Louisville got it to 64-61, but Kentucky mounted several small spurts for double-digit leads that withstood several Cardinal rallies. Otega Oweh added eight key points down the stretch, including a three-point play to make it 89-79 with 43 seconds remaining. Kentucky won for the 10th time in 12 meetings. Chucky Hepburn scored 26 points and Terrence Edwards Jr. 23 for Louisville, which shot just 44.3% but made a season-best 14 3s. Takeaways Oklahoma: The Sooners will have to wait for their first win against Kentucky after dropping their second this season and fifth all-time to the Wildcats. Now the Wildcats keep chasing their first title here since 2018. Key moment Fears scored seven straight points capped by his layup to give the Sooners their first lead since 15:51. They trailed by as much as 77-65 with 4:31 left. profile_summary: Kentucky enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 3-seed with a 24-12 record — a résumé that reflects genuine big-game capability alongside persistent inconsistency and a brutal injury toll. Against ranked opponents, the Wildcats went an impressive 9-7, with marquee wins over then-No. 6 Duke (77-72 in the Champions Classic), No. 6 Florida (106-100), No. 8 Tennessee twice (78-73 on the road and 75-64 at home), No. 7 Gonzaga (90-89 in overtime after trailing by 18), and No. 14 Mississippi State (95-90), but they were swept by No. 4 Alabama in three meetings — including a humiliating 99-70 beatdown in the SEC Tournament quarterfinals — and lost to Ohio State, Clemson, Ole Miss, Georgia, Vanderbilt, Arkansas, and Texas at various points. Their final five games tell a tale of two teams: a 95-64 demolition of LSU, a gutty 91-83 road win at No. 15 Missouri, a dramatic 85-84 SEC Tournament thriller over Oklahoma on Otega Oweh's buzzer-beating baseline jumper, and then an utterly flat 99-70 collapse against Alabama in which they were outscored 29-6 off turnovers and trailed by 30 — a performance that encapsulates the ceiling problem this program cannot fully escape. Kentucky is at its best as a three-level offensive attack: they lead the country in three-point volume (surpassing 300 made threes on the season), rank among the nation's elite in paint scoring, and can generate points in transition, but they are maddeningly inconsistent from game to game, capable of shooting 60% in a blowout one night and going ice-cold for entire halves the next. Otega Oweh is the engine — he averages 16 points per game, scored a career-high 28 at Oklahoma and followed it with 27 in the SEC Tournament opener, and has demonstrated the clutch-gene repeatedly, including a banked floater to beat Oklahoma and four free throws to seal the Duke win — but his production is volatile, having scored just 4 points against Auburn and 2 against Alabama when defenses locked in. The injury situation is a serious concern: point guard Lamont Butler, who leads the team in assists and provides critical defensive ball pressure, has missed nine games with a shoulder injury and played only eight minutes in the SEC Tournament opener before reaggravating it; second-leading scorer and premier three-point shooter Jaxson Robinson underwent wrist surgery and is done for the season, and his absence has robbed Kentucky of their most reliable secondary scorer over the final stretch. Amari Williams provides a 20-10 presence at center and is one of the most versatile frontcourt players in the SEC, but Kentucky's backcourt depth behind Oweh drops off sharply to freshmen Travis Perry and Colin Chandler when Butler is unavailable. Locationally, Kentucky is stronger at home (notably beating Florida, Tennessee, and Louisville in Lexington) but has shown the ability to win on the road and at neutral sites — their comeback win over Gonzaga in Seattle and the clutch SEC Tournament performances against Oklahoma indicate they do not wilt on big stages, even if Alabama has thoroughly solved them this year. The team carries a scrappy, resilient identity — they erased 18-point second-half deficits, won on buzzer-beaters twice, and swept Tennessee despite the injury carnage — but they are equally prone to complete defensive and turnover collapses, as the Auburn and second Alabama losses demonstrated. **Verdict**: Kentucky is a dangerous, unpredictable 3-seed with a realistic ceiling of the Elite Eight — capable of beating any team in the country on a night when Oweh is locked in, the threes are falling, and Williams dominates the paint, but too injury-compromised, turnover-prone, and inconsistently defended to be trusted as a Final Four or national title contender. If Butler is healthy, they are a genuine threat to reach the second weekend; if he is not, first-round upsets are well within the range of possibilities.

profile_summary:
Troy enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 14-seed with a 23-11 record — a profile that reflects a legitimate Sun Belt Conference champion that has earned its bid but carries significant question marks against high-major competition. The Trojans went 0-3 against power conference opponents this season, suffering blowout losses to Arkansas (65-49), Oregon (82-61), and No. 15 Houston (62-42), where they were held to just 11 first-half points and shot 17% from the field. Those results reveal a team that struggles badly with elite athleticism and length — against Oregon, they shot a staggering 12% from three, missing 22 of 25 attempts, and against Houston they were simply overmatched in every phase. Within the Sun Belt, however, Troy was a legitimate force, eventually sharing the regular season title at 13-5 and winning the conference tournament outright, beating Old Dominion, James Madison (79-60), and Arkansas State (94-81) in succession in Pensacola. Their ranked wins/losses record stands at 0-1 against ranked opponents (the Houston loss), with no signature victories over quality competition to point to. The Trojans play a style centered on guard play and offensive volume — they are capable of putting up points in bunches, as evidenced by a 105-60 demolition of LaGrange and the 94-81 tournament championship win — but they are also prone to close-game vulnerability, dropping multiple one-possession games including a heartbreaker to Texas State (74-73 on a free throw with 1.1 seconds left) and late losses to South Alabama and Louisiana decided in the final seconds.

Heading into the tournament, Troy is playing its best basketball of the season, winning five straight including three conference tournament games by an average margin of roughly 17 points. Tayton Conerway is the engine of this offense and is performing at an elite level: he posted 22 points in the semifinal win over James Madison, 24 points in the regular-season finale at Texas State, and has repeatedly delivered in high-leverage moments, including a 32-point effort against Arkansas State and a 20-point clutch performance in a 58-57 road escape at Marshall. Myles Rigsby provides a second reliable scoring option — he scored 25 against Southern Miss and 20 in the tournament championship — while Thomas Dowd has emerged as a versatile third weapon, putting up 18 points and 12 rebounds against James Madison. The team is notably stronger at home (where they built their Sun Belt record) and has occasionally been shaky on the road, but their neutral-site conference tournament performance — three wins, none closer than 13 points — is genuinely encouraging. The concern is that their ceiling was fully exposed by Houston and Oregon: when facing elite defensive pressure and length, this offense collapses, and there is no evidence they can sustain a performance against a high-major-caliber 3-seed opponent. Troy is a dangerous, hot, and well-coached 14-seed capable of keeping a first-round game close and possibly stealing a win if Conerway goes off — but a second-round run is a significant ask for a team that was outscored 42-11 in a half against a Power Four opponent. **Realistic tournament ceiling: First-round upset threat, likely exit in Round 1 or, at best, Round 2.**

2024-11-05 - Marquette: 102 vs Stony Brook: 62

MILWAUKEE -- — Kam Jones scored 32 points while shooting 14 of 16 from the floor as No. 18 Marquette breezed to a 102-62 season-opening victory over Stony Brook on Monday night. Jones was 4 of 6 from 3-point range and finished two points off his career high. Jones had 34 points in back-to-back games against DePaul and Xavier last season. Chase Ross added a career-best 23 points and David Joplin scored 13. Marquette is chasing its fourth straight NCAA Tournament berth as it attempts to replace 2024 Associated Press All-America second-team guard Tyler Kolek and Oso Ighodaro, who were both selected in the second round of the NBA draft. Joe Octave scored 12 points and Ben Wight had 10 points and eight rebounds for Stony Brook. Takeaways Stony Brook: This Coastal Athletic Association program returns only one starter from a team that went 20-15 last season. Octave, a Holy Cross transfer, should be a major player for the Seawolves. He made three 3-pointers in the first four minutes. Marquette: The Golden Eagles don't really have a pure point guard on their roster while Sean Jones recovers from a torn anterior cruciate ligament, but they distributed the ball quite well. Marquette had 22 assists with just seven turnovers. Key moment This game went back and forth until Jones hit a 3-pointer off an assist from Ben Gold with 10:35 left in the first half to put Marquette ahead 21-19. Jones' shot marked the 10th and final lead change of the night. That basket began a 9-0 run, and Marquette led comfortably the rest of the way. Key stats Marquette shot 58.8% (40 of 68) from the floor. The Golden Eagles went just 9 of 31 from 3-point range, but they made 83.8% of their shots (31 of 37) from inside the arc. Up next Stony Brook plays at Central Michigan on Thursday, while Marquette hosts George Mason on Friday. The George Mason game will take place at the Al McGuire Center on Marquette's campus rather than at the Fiserv Forum in downtown Milwaukee, which serves as the Golden Eagles' typical home court. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. 2024-11-09 - Marquette: 82 vs George Mason: 63

MILWAUKEE -- — David Joplin had 27 points and 10 rebounds as No. 18 Marquette pulled away down the stretch to beat George Mason 82-63 on Friday night in front of a festive, all-student crowd. The game had a tense moment in the final minute as Marquette's Ben Gold drove to the basket and got fouled hard by Woody Newton. It appeared Newton's elbow hit Gold in the face. Players from both teams exchanged words and shoves. Newton and Marquette's Kam Jones both received technical fouls, with Newton's fifth foul knocking him out of the game. Jones had 24 points and eight assists for Marquette (2-0). Darius Maddox scored 20 for George Mason (1-1). The game took place on Marquette's campus in the 3,700-seat Al McGuire Center rather than at its usual home, the Fiserv Forum in downtown Milwaukee that seats more than 17,000. The crowd consisted entirely of students. Marquette fed off the students’ energy to take a 13-0 lead in the first 2½ minutes, but George Mason clawed its way back. Marquette trailed by five early in the second half, missed 14 straight shots and didn’t really gain separation until the final few minutes. Takeaways George Mason: The Patriots will have to take better care of the ball. They had 19 turnovers against Marquette. Through the first two games, George Mason has totaled 36 turnovers and 25 assists. Marquette: Outscored George Mason 16-2 over the last 4 1/2 minutes. Key moment Marquette took the lead for good at 52-51 when Chase Ross converted a steal into a dunk with 12:25 left. Key stats Marquette had 13 steals and a 22-8 edge in points off turnovers.
