2024-11-20 - Marquette: 76 vs Purdue: 58

MILWAUKEE -- — Kam Jones had 17 points, 13 rebounds and 10 assists as No. 15 Marquette defeated No. 6 Purdue 76-58 on Tuesday night to snap the Boilermakers’ 39-game regular-season nonconference winning streak. Purdue (4-1) hadn’t lost a regular-season nonconference game since falling 58-54 at Miami on Dec. 8, 2020, compiling the fourth-longest such streak in NCAA history. The record is held by Syracuse, which won 52 straight nonconference regular-season games from Dec. 17, 2008, through Dec. 17, 2012. Jones’ triple-double was the third in school history and first since Dwyane Wade had 29 points, 11 rebounds and 11 assists when Marquette beat Kentucky 83-69 in a 2003 regional final to earn its most recent Final Four appearance. Marquette’s only other triple-double came from Tony Miller against Wisconsin on Dec. 31, 1994. Stevie Mitchell scored a career-high 21 points for Marquette (5-0). Chase Ross had 12 and Ben Gold added 11. Trey Kaufman-Renn had 16 points, Fletcher Loyer 13 and Braden Smith 11 for Purdue. Takeaways Purdue: The string of nonconference regular-season wins wasn't the only Purdue streak to get snapped. The Boilermakers also had won an NCAA-best 25 straight November games. Marquette: Jones has been a productive scorer much of his career, but Tuesday's game showed how much he has developed as an all-around player. His 13 rebounds and 10 assists were both career highs. Key moment Purdue trailed 55-49 with eight minutes left before David Joplin scored four points during an 8-0 run for Marquette that made it a 14-point game with 4:51 remaining. The spurt culminated with Ross getting a steal and passing to Mitchell for a layup. Key stats After committing just three turnovers Friday in an 87-78 victory over then-No. 2 Alabama, Purdue had 15 on Tuesday. profile_summary: Marquette enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 7-seed with a 23-11 record — a résumé that reflects genuine Big East competitiveness but also persistent inconsistency against top-tier opposition. Against ranked opponents, the Golden Eagles went an estimated 6-10, with notable wins over #6 Purdue (76-58), #11 Wisconsin (88-74), #13 Maryland (78-74), and #22 Georgia early in the year, but absorbing losses to #6 Iowa State, #25 UConn (twice), #12 St. John's (three times), and #11 Creighton down the stretch. Their final five games paint a mixed picture: a blowout road win at Georgetown (76-61), a narrow road loss to UConn (72-66), an overtime home loss to St. John's (86-84), a gutsy Big East Tournament quarterfinal comeback win over Xavier (89-87), and then a 79-63 semifinal blowout loss to St. John's — a sequence that captures everything Marquette is: capable of thrilling resilience one night, then flat and overwhelmed the next. The Golden Eagles have gone just 4-6 since February 1st, a prolonged slump that raises serious questions about their momentum entering March. Structurally, Marquette wins through ball pressure and transition — they lead the Big East in steals, with Stevie Mitchell, Chase Ross, and Kam Jones all among the conference's top thieves — and when their defense generates turnovers (they forced 24 against Seton Hall, 22 against Providence), they are capable of dominant, wire-to-wire performances. However, their three-point shooting has been a chronic liability; they shot just 13.6% from deep against UConn in the regular-season finale and have hovered around 27-28% from beyond the arc over their last several games, making them dangerously one-dimensional when their interior paint advantage is neutralized. Kam Jones is the unquestioned engine — he has scored in double figures in 48 consecutive games, recorded a triple-double against Purdue, posted 32 points against St. John's in their overtime loss, and surpassed 2,000 career points in the Big East Tournament — but he has also gone cold at critical moments (6-for-21 against Iowa State, 5-for-13 against Xavier in the regular season), and the Golden Eagles lack a true playmaking point guard. The supporting cast of David Joplin, Chase Ross, and Mitchell provides enough secondary scoring to make Marquette dangerous on any given night, but their size disadvantage — exposed repeatedly by St. John's Zuby Ejiofor and UConn's Samson Johnson — is a structural problem that could doom them against long, athletic tournament opponents. Marquette is notably better at home (where they've been dominant) and more vulnerable on the road and at neutral sites against elite competition, though their comeback win over Xavier at Madison Square Garden shows they can rise to the moment. This is a team that carries real resilience and star power in Jones, but too much inconsistency, three-point volatility, and a soft underbelly against physical frontcourts to project deep. **Realistic ceiling: Round of 32 to Sweet 16** — dangerous enough to knock off a quality opponent in the first round, but too streaky and structurally flawed to advance past an elite eight-caliber program.

profile_summary: New Mexico enters the 2025 NCAA tournament as a 10-seed with a 27-8 record — a résumé built on Mountain West Conference dominance that belies a seeding that may undervalue them. The Lobos won the MWC regular season title outright at 17-3 and demonstrated legitimate big-game credibility early, knocking off then-No. 22 UCLA 72-64 in a neutral-site game in November, scoring 21 points off 21 Bruin turnovers in the process. Against ranked opponents, New Mexico went approximately 1-2, with that UCLA win as the signature victory and losses to No. 22 St. John's (85-71 at Madison Square Garden, where they were outrebounded 49-32) and implicitly to other quality competition — a mixed but not discouraging record against elite company. Their final five games tell a complicated story: wins over Air Force (92-71), Nevada (71-67 on the road to clinch the MWC title), and UNLV (81-67) were bracketed by a road loss at San Diego State (73-65) and a stunning semifinal upset loss to No. 5 seed Boise State (72-69) in the MWC Tournament — the same Boise State squad that had already beaten them 86-78 in February, suggesting a genuine matchup problem against the Broncos specifically rather than a systemic collapse. Entering the tournament, New Mexico is best described as a team with a defined identity and recurring vulnerabilities: they are capable of dominant wire-to-wire performances — blowing out Fresno State twice, Air Force twice, and Colorado State by 22 — but they also carry a troubling tendency to surrender large leads, as seen in the Arizona State loss (blew a 19-3 run advantage) and the Boise State MWC semifinal (trailed by nine at halftime after leading by six at the break). The engine of this team is unambiguously Donovan Dent, who posted 40 points against VCU, 34 against UNLV, 33 in the Nevada road clincher, and 30 against Arizona State — a legitimate alpha scorer who also distributes at an elite level, recording 11 assists against Nevada and consistently threading the needle as a playmaker; when Dent is locked in, New Mexico's offense operates at a genuinely high ceiling. Nelly Junior Joseph is a force in the frontcourt, delivering his 50th career double-double against Nevada and posting 19 points and 16 rebounds in the regular-season finale against UNLV, while Mustapha Amzil provides a volatile but sometimes brilliant third scoring option (career-high 28 against Arizona State, 40-point combined effort with Dent that night). New Mexico plays noticeably better at home — 14-1 in Mountain West play at The Pit — and while their neutral-site record includes that impressive UCLA win, road games at Boise State and San Diego State exposed defensive breakdowns and an inability to maintain leads when opponents heat up. The team carries a resilient, competitive energy — comeback wins over Nevada (overtime, buzzer-beater by Joseph), Utah State (twice), and UNLV on the road all demonstrate composure in close games — but Boise State's ability to beat them twice, including in a game where the Lobos led at halftime, raises legitimate questions about their capacity to compete when opponents execute sustained offensive pressure for 40 minutes. As a 10-seed, New Mexico is a genuine upset threat in the first round and a team that could absolutely advance to the Sweet 16 — Dent is good enough to carry them past most mid-major or bubble opponents, and Joseph gives them a frontcourt weapon few teams at this seed can match — but their pattern of late-game defensive lapses, their 0-2 record against Boise State (suggesting vulnerability to physical, well-coached opponents), and their failure to win the MWC Tournament all cap their realistic ceiling at the Sweet 16, with a more likely outcome of a second-round exit against a power-conference opponent equipped to exploit their defensive inconsistencies.

2024-11-05 - Arizona: 93 vs Canisius: 64

TUCSON, Ariz. -- — Caleb Love had 17 points and six assists, Jaden Bradley added 15 points and No. 10 Arizona opened coach Tommy Lloyd's fourth season with a 93-64 win over Canisius on Monday night. Arizona jumped on the Golden Griffins from the start, scoring the first 13 points during an opening 20-2 run on its way to a 52-30 halftime lead. The Wildcats never let the lead get under 18 after that early burst to win their 18th straight home opener. Arizona dominated inside, outscoring Canisius 48-12 in the paint while grabbing 18 more rebounds. KJ Lewis added 14 points for the Wildcats, who had 20 assists and nine turnovers — five before the starters came out. The Golden Griffins needed four minutes to score their first points and had trouble with Arizona's size all night, but still shot a respectable 43% from the floor in one of college basketball's toughest road environments. Paul McMillan IV led Canisius with 20 points. Takeaways Canisius: The Golden Griffins had some good moments, particularly on offense after the slow start, but dug themselves way too big an early hole to prevent getting blown out. Arizona: The Wildcats did what they're supposed to against an overmatched nonconference opponent at home and showed off the depth that has them eyeing a deep NCAA Tournament run. Key moment Love's return after testing the NBA waters was a huge boost to the Wildcats and earned him preseason All-America honors. He asserted himself right out of the gate, scoring seven points during Arizona's big opening run. Key stat Arizona had a massive size advantage with two 7-footers in its rotation and took advantage on the glass. The Wildcats grabbed 17 offensive rebounds, scoring 19 second-chance points. Up next Canisius hosts St. Bonaventure on Saturday. Arizona hosts Old Dominion on Saturday. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on AP Top 25 basketball throughout the season. Sign up here. The rematch had far less animosity, and the scrappy Sun Devils (13-17, 4-15) managed to keep it close late despite being down to five scholarship players after starting guard Adam Miller was injured in the first 28 seconds. Arizona wore down the Sun Devils, shooting 59% with a 52-30 advantage in the paint to earn a bye into the quarterfinals of the Big 12 Tournament. KJ Lewis added 21 points. Arizona had a hard time shaking the Sun Devils until Basheer Jihad (15 points) and Shawn Phillips (14) fouled out in the final 5:12, leaving Arizona State with four scholarship players. The Wildcats pulled away after Arizona State had cut the lead to three. Takeaways Arizona State: The Sun Devils shot 12 of 23 from 3-point range, but wore down against Arizona's depth. Arizona: The Wildcats earned a season sweep of their rivals to help Tommy Lloyd become the first Arizona coach to win at least 20 games in each of his first four seasons. No. 1 seed Houston plays No. 4 seed BYU in the other semifinal. Veesaar scored 10, leading Arizona to a 45-37 advantage at halftime. KJ Adams made two free throws to get the Jayhawks within 40-37, but Veesaar answered with a 3-pointer and Arizona stayed in front. Arizona played with a lead until Zeke Mayo hit back-to-back 3-pointers for Kansas to knot the score at 50 with 15:43 remaining. Harris hit a 3-pointer to give the Jayhawks their second lead at 56-54. Rylan Griffen hit a jumper with 8:44 left to put Kansas up for the last time at 63-61. Trey Townsend followed with a dunk and a three-point play and Arizona maintained a lead over the final 7:48. Towsend had 16 points and Love scored 11 with six assists. Mayo scored 20 to lead Kansas. Hunter Dickinson totaled 19 points and 12 rebounds. Harris hit four 3-pointers and scored 16. KANSAS CITY, Mo. -- — Caleb Love scored 27 points and Arizona took advantage of injuries that left Texas Tech short-handed for an 86-80 victory over the No. 9 Red Raiders in the Big 12 Tournament semifinals Friday night. KJ Lewis added 15 points and Henri Veesaar scored eight of his 10 in the closing minutes for the Wildcats (22-11), who advanced to the championship game against No. 2 Houston on Saturday night in their first season in their new league. Kevin Overton had 20 points and Christian Anderson scored 19 for the Red Raiders (25-8), who played without Chance McMillian and Darrion Williams because of injuries, and then watched star forward JT Toppin throw up in the arena tunnel. Toppin made it through the game, but the All-Big 12 forward managed just 11 points in 25 minutes. Compounding problems short-handed Texas Tech, point guard Elijah Hawkins picked up his fourth foul with 14:56 to go, leaving coach Grant McCasland with precious few options on his bench in the second half. The Red Raiders trailed by as much as 14 before nevertheless mounting a comeback, closing to 78-74 on two free throws by Anderson with 2:40 to go. Veesaar answered with back-to-back baskets and Arizona held on from there. Takeaways Arizona: The Wildcats were 8 of 16 from beyond the 3-point arc and shot 51% from the field overall. Texas Tech: The Red Raiders couldn't overcome the fact that their three leading scorers were ill or absent. McMillian missed the second half of its quarterfinal win with what the school called an “upper body strain,” while Williams was wearing a walking boot on his right foot after he appeared to aggravate an injury that has bothered him the last few weeks against the Bears. Key moment Veesaar was quiet until the closing minutes, when the 7-footer made a series of big baskets. Key stat The Red Raiders were missing a combined 28.5 points per game with McMillian and Williams unavailable. 2025-03-15 - Houston: 72 vs Arizona: 64
profile_summary:
Arizona enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 4-seed with a 24-13 record — a résumé that reflects genuine big-game capability alongside persistent inconsistency, particularly down the stretch. The Wildcats compiled a solid body of work in their inaugural Big 12 season, finishing 14-6 in conference play and reaching the Big 12 Tournament championship game before falling to Houston 72-64. Against ranked opponents, Arizona went an estimated 8-10, with notable wins over #3 Iowa State (86-75, including Caleb Love's legendary half-court buzzer-beater to force overtime), #21 West Virginia (75-56), #16 Cincinnati (72-67), #13 Texas Tech (82-73 in a rematch after an earlier blowout loss), and #9 Texas Tech again in the Big 12 semis (86-80). However, losses to Houston twice, Iowa State on the road, Kansas State, Wisconsin, Duke, Oklahoma, and BYU underscore a team that can be beaten by quality competition on any given night. Entering the tournament, Arizona has been decidedly inconsistent over its final five games: a dominant 113-100 win over rival Arizona State, a 76-83 road loss at Kansas in the regular season finale, then a Big 12 Tournament run that included wins over Kansas (88-77) and Texas Tech (86-80) before a 64-72 loss to Houston in the championship — a 3-2 stretch that is neither a hot streak nor a genuine slump, but a reminder that this team is capable of winning three straight against quality opponents while still falling short against the nation's elite.

Stylistically, Arizona is an up-tempo, high-scoring team that wins through offensive firepower, depth, and size — not defensive grinds. The Wildcats have scored over 80 points in the vast majority of their wins and can get hot from three (Love's six 3s against Utah, Dell'Orso's six against Colorado), dominate the paint with a pair of 7-footers in Tobe Awaka and Henri Veesaar, and pile up assists (28 in the TCU opener). The identity of this team runs almost entirely through preseason AP All-American Caleb Love, who is wildly streaky but capable of transcendent performances — his 33-point, five-3-pointer explosion against TCU, his 27-point games against Oklahoma State and Arizona State, and his miraculous halfcourt buzzer-beater to beat Iowa State show what a top-5 talent he can be; conversely, his 2-of-13 night against Wisconsin, 3-of-13 against Duke, and continued 3-point struggles in losses to Houston and Iowa State show how badly this offense can stall when he is cold. Jaden Bradley (21 points in the regular-season finale at Kansas), KJ Lewis (career-high 21 against West Virginia), and the emerging Henri Veesaar (19 points in the Big 12 quarterfinal win over Kansas) give Arizona legitimate secondary contributors, and Carter Bryant provides defensive energy and rebounding off the bench. Notably, Trey Townsend — a starter for the first 22 games — missed time with a concussion in February, a development worth monitoring for tournament availability and rotation continuity. Arizona is clearly a stronger home team (50-4 at McKale over three-plus seasons under Lloyd) and has been vulnerable on the road, though a 6-3 true road record and a productive neutral-site showing in the Big 12 Tournament suggest they are not a team that collapses away from home either. The Wildcats carry an energy that oscillates between resilient and error-prone — they can overcome deficits (erasing a 13-point hole vs. Iowa State), but they also cough up leads (blowing a 17-point advantage vs. UCF, allowing 17-2 closing runs at Texas Tech, losing a late lead to BYU at home) and commit costly turnovers (11 in the Houston loss, 14 against BYU). Arizona's tournament ceiling is a legitimate Elite Eight, with a puncher's chance at the Final Four: the combination of Love's star power, interior size, offensive versatility, and big-game wins against top-3 Iowa State and the Big 12 regular-season champion Texas Tech proves this team can beat anybody on a given night — but the chronic 3-point volatility, Love's hot-and-cold nature, and an inability to solve Houston in two tries suggest

profile_summary:
Akron enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 13-seed with a 28-7 record that demands respect, though their résumé carries an important caveat: the bulk of their dominance came within the Mid-American Conference, where they went 17-1 in the regular season and ran the table as the MAC's undisputed best team. Against genuinely elite competition, the Zips struggled — early-season losses to Saint Mary's (87-68), Milwaukee (100-81), and Yale (74-58) exposed real vulnerabilities against high-major and quality mid-major opponents, and a gut-punch 76-75 loss at Princeton, where they blew a 15-point lead on a buzzer-beating 3-pointer, raised legitimate questions about their composure in tight moments. Their only meaningful non-conference win came in a comfortable home victory over Northern Kentucky. That said, the Zips are playing their best basketball heading into March: their final five games saw wins over Ball State (87-82), Kent State (77-72), Toledo (96-87), Buffalo (88-70), and three MAC Tournament victories — capped by a grinding 76-74 win over Miami (OH) in the championship — demonstrating they can close out games when it matters most, though several of those wins came against mid-to-lower-tier MAC competition. The MAC Tournament title run, including a 100-90 semifinal win over Toledo, confirms they can win on consecutive days under pressure.

Akron's style is best described as high-octane offense with a multi-headed scoring attack rather than a defensive juggernaut — they regularly crack 80, 90, and even 100 points, but they can also surrender big numbers, as Milwaukee's 100-point outburst and Toledo's 87 in the regular-season finale illustrate. The engine of this team is the Johnson duo: **Nate Johnson** and **Tavari Johnson** are both capable of explosive performances, with Nate dropping 28 on Toledo and Tavari erupting for 27 against Northern Kentucky earlier in the year, while **Shammah Scott** has emerged as a critical bench contributor averaging double-digit points in major moments, including 16 off the bench in the MAC title run. **Isaiah Gray** provides versatile two-way play and **Amani Lyles** offers a reliable interior presence with efficient shooting. Home-court has clearly been a comfort zone — Akron dominated at InfoCision Stadium all conference season — but their road and neutral-site record is mixed, with blowout losses at Saint Mary's and Milwaukee and a near-upset loss at Princeton on the road raising flags about their ability to win away from home. Their energy reads as confident and free-flowing when shots are falling, but they are susceptible to momentum swings and have shown a tendency to dig themselves early halftime deficits, needing second-half rallies to close out wins. As a 13-seed, Akron is genuinely dangerous for a bubble 4-seed — their offensive firepower and MAC championship pedigree make them a credible first-round upset threat — but their soft non-conference résumé and demonstrated inability to compete with high-major opponents caps their realistic ceiling at the **second round**. A Sweet 16 run would require back-to-back upsets against competition they have shown no ability to handle this season, making it an unlikely but not impossible outcome.

2024-11-07 - UConn: 92 vs Sacred Heart: 56

STORRS, Conn. -- — Alex Karaban had 20 points, seven assists, seven blocks and six rebounds as No. 3 UConn opened the season with a 92-56 win over Sacred Heart on Wednesday night. Liam McNeeley added 18 points and 10 rebounds for the Huskies, seeking their third consecutive NCAA championship. Solo Ball scored 16. Tarris Reed Jr. finished with 15 points and 11 rebounds off the bench as Connecticut outrebounded Sacred Heart 47-25. Amiri Stewart had 13 points and Bryce Johnson added 10 for the Pioneers (0-2). Tanner Thomas, who scored 22 points in Sacred Heart's season-opening loss to Temple, had just six against UConn (1-0). Before the game, the Huskies unveiled their 2023-24 national championship banner. UConn had four starters taken in the NBA draft last summer. Stephon Castle, Donovan Clingan, Tristen Newton and Cam Spencer all had video messages for the fans at Gampel Pavilion. Takeaways Sacred Heart: Three of the first four baskets for the Pioneers were 3-pointers. However, the team hit only one more. Sacred Heart is 9 for 34 from 3-point range in the first two games of the season. UConn: McNeeley and Reed both had a double-double in their UConn debuts. McNeeley was the top-rated recruit in the Huskies’ freshman class, while Reed is a Michigan transfer. Key moment Sacred Heart only trailed by five with 5:46 left in the first half. Karaban scored eight of UConn’s next 10 points as the Huskies closed the half on a 16-6 run to take a 46-31 lead at halftime. Key stats UConn had 14 offensive rebounds, 10 steals and 11 blocked shots. Up next Sacred Heart plays at Dartmouth on Saturday. LAHAINA, Hawaii -- — Andrej Jakimovski converted an off-balance layup with 8 seconds left, and Colorado handed No. 2 UConn its second loss in two days at the Maui Invitational, beating the two-time defending national champion 73-72 on Tuesday. A day after a 99-97 overtime loss to Memphis that left Huskies coach Dan Hurley livid about the officiating, UConn (4-2) couldn't shake the unranked Buffaloes (5-1), who shot 62.5% in the second half. With Colorado trailing 72-71 in the closing seconds, Jakimovski drove to his right and absorbed contact from UConn’s Liam McNeeley. He tossed the ball toward the glass and the shot was good as he fell to the floor. Hassan Diarra missed a 3-pointer just ahead of the buzzer for UConn. Elijah Malone and Julian Hammond III scored 16 points each for Colorado, and Jakimovski had 12 points and 10 rebounds. The Huskies led 40-32 at halftime and by nine points early in the second half, but Colorado quickly closed that gap. McNeeley led UConn with 20 points. Takeaways UConn: Hurley's squad is facing its first adversity in quite a while. The Huskies arrived on Maui with a 17-game winning streak that dated to February. Colorado: The Buffaloes were held to season lows in points (56) and field goal percentage (37%) in a 16-point loss to Michigan State on Monday but shot 51.1% overall and 56.3% (9 of 16) from 3-point range against the Huskies. profile_summary: UConn enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as an 8-seed with a 24-11 record — a mark that feels both disappointing and deceptive for a two-time defending national champion. The Huskies went 5-7 against ranked opponents this season, with notable wins over #8 Gonzaga (77-71 at Madison Square Garden), #15 Baylor (76-72), #9 Marquette (77-69 on the road), #24 Creighton (70-66 on the road), and #20 Marquette again (72-66 at home), while suffering losses to #12 St. John's twice, #24 Creighton at home, #9 Marquette (early season), and ranked Villanova. Their five final games tell a story of a team trending upward but with a ceiling: wins over Georgetown (93-79), Providence (75-63), and Marquette (72-66) showed real offensive firepower and rebounding dominance, but a blowout semifinal loss to Creighton (71-62) in the Big East Tournament — in which Creighton ran off 11 straight points late in the first half and never looked back — raises legitimate questions about UConn's ability to sustain momentum against elite competition over consecutive tournament days. The engine of this team is Alex Karaban, the only returning starter from the back-to-back championship rosters, who consistently delivers in big moments — his 21-point, 11-rebound performance at Texas, his clutch 3-pointers against Marquette and Butler, and 18 points in the Big East quarterfinal win over Villanova all speak to his reliability. Freshman Liam McNeeley missed eight games with a high ankle sprain before exploding for a season-high 38 points and 10 rebounds at Creighton upon his return, giving UConn a genuine second star when healthy. Solo Ball has emerged as a streaky but dangerous three-point shooter — his 7-of-9 performance from deep against Marquette and career-high 25 points demonstrated an elite ceiling — while Tarris Reed Jr. provides relentless interior production off the bench, including a 24-point, 18-rebound, six-block performance at Providence. The Huskies play best when they are a patient, inside-out team that dominates the paint, forces turnovers, and gets to the foul line; their worst losses — all three Maui Invitational defeats to Memphis, Colorado, and Dayton — came when opponents shot well from three and UConn struggled to defend the perimeter, a vulnerability that has never fully been corrected. Home-court UConn went 14-4 in Storrs and Hartford, including a 28-game home winning streak snapped by Creighton in January, while road and neutral-site play produced several painful collapses: the overtime loss to Seton Hall (a team that finished 8-18), the buzzer-beater loss at Colorado in Maui, and the Big East semifinal loss all point to a team that can be rattled when the game tightens late against sharp opponents. Dan Hurley's Huskies carry the pedigree, experience, and roster depth of a team capable of making a run — Karaban, Reed, Diarra, Ball, and McNeeley give them five legitimate contributors — but their inconsistency against top competition, persistent turnover problems (19 in one game alone, 25 in another), and susceptibility to late-game collapses against inferior opponents make a deep run feel more like a gamble than a guarantee. Their realistic ceiling is the Sweet 16: dangerous enough as an 8-seed to pull an upset in round one, with enough star power and tournament DNA to win a second game, but too prone to the kind of defensive breakdowns and late-game mistakes that elite tournament teams will punish.

Takeaways Oklahoma: The Sooners will have to wait for their first win against Kentucky after dropping their second this season and fifth all-time to the Wildcats. They also lost for the first time on a neutral court this season in their seventh such game. Kentucky: Winners of this tournament a league-high 31 times, this was just the second time the Wildcats had played in the second round. Now the Wildcats keep chasing their first title here since 2018. They did it with starting guard Lamont Butler playing only eight minutes, leaving at 9:35 of the first half with a right shoulder issue seconds after finishing a fast-break with a layup for his only points. Key moment Fears scored seven straight points capped by his layup to give the Sooners their first lead since 15:51. They trailed by as much as 77-65 with 4:31 left. Key stat The Sooners couldn't stop Oweh again when it mattered most. Up next Oklahoma heads home 1-1 in its SEC Tournament debut waiting for its NCAA Tournament destination. Kentucky gets a third chance at Alabama, which took both games during the regular season. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and
profile_summary:
Oklahoma enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 9-seed with a 20-14 record — a résumé that reads like a tale of two seasons. The Sooners opened the year a stunning 13-0, winning the Battle 4 Atlantis with victories over then-No. 24 Arizona and Louisville, and climbing as high as No. 12 in the AP Poll, before SEC play exposed real structural limitations. Against ranked opponents across the full season, Oklahoma went roughly 6-13: legitimate statement wins over Arizona, Michigan (87-86 on a Jeremiah Fears buzzer-beating four-point play), Louisville, Vanderbilt, Mississippi State, and Missouri bookend a brutal stretch of blowout losses to Alabama (107-79), Auburn (98-70), Tennessee (70-52), Florida (85-63), and Missouri (82-58), among others. Their final five games capture their maddening inconsistency — a gut-punch 83-82 loss to Kentucky on a banked Otega Oweh floater, an 87-84 loss at Ole Miss on a last-possession turnover, a career-high 31-point Fears explosion in a 96-84 win over No. 15 Missouri, a regular-season-closing road win at Texas, and then an SEC Tournament run of one win (81-75 over Georgia) followed by another Oweh-delivered heartbreak (85-84) — competitive to the end but unable to close. Senior big Sam Godwin, a consistent double-double threat, suffered a knee injury against Missouri with 5:32 left and did not return, and his availability is a legitimate concern entering the bracket.

Oklahoma's identity is built almost entirely around freshman guard Jeremiah Fears, a genuinely electric talent who has posted 28, 29, and 31-point performances in three of his last five games and has repeatedly willed this team into winnable positions late — only to see the result slip away due to turnovers (he had eight against Providence and has struggled with careless decisions under pressure), foul trouble for key contributors, or defensive breakdowns at the worst moments. Jalon Moore provides valuable secondary scoring and has stepped up in several big spots, including a 29-point career night against Texas, but the Sooners' depth is paper-thin and their rebounding against elite frontcourts has been catastrophically bad — outrebounded 51-26 by Alabama, 47-19 by Texas A&M, and routinely victimized by second-chance points. Positionally, Oklahoma plays noticeably better at home and on neutral sites; their neutral-court Battle 4 Atlantis run was dominant, and they covered themselves in both SEC Tournament games, but they went 1-7 in true road SEC games, a disqualifying trend against any elite opponent. This is a scrappy, Fears-dependent team that is capable of beating anyone on a given night — as their five wins over ranked opponents prove — but one that gets blown out by dominant frontcourts, turns the ball over at damaging rates, and has repeatedly lost winnable games in the final seconds due to mental lapses. Their realistic tournament ceiling is the Round of 32: Fears gives them enough shot-creation to upset a 8-seed or even make noise against a higher seed in the second round, but a matchup against an elite, frontcourt-driven team will end their run quickly.

2024-11-05 - Illinois: 112 vs Eastern Illinois: 67

CHAMPAIGN, Ill. -- — Will Riley scored 26 of his 31 points in the second half to set an Illinois scoring record in a freshman debut and the Illini eased by Eastern Illinois 112-67 on Monday night. Riley scored 15 of Illinois' 17 points late in the second half, including 12 straight to take a 41-point lead. He finished 10 of 13 from the field in just 25 minutes, making 5 of 6 from 3-point range and 6 of 7 at the free-throw line. Riley made all four of his 3-pointers in the second half, including a four-point play with 5:14 left. Illinois has won nine straight openers, a streak that began with an 81-62 victory over Southeast Missouri in 2016. The Fighting Illini have hosted Eastern Illinois for its season opener the last three seasons. Illinois sits just outside the Top 25 of the preseason AP poll, receiving the most points (92) among unranked teams. Dra Gibbs-Lawhorn added 21 points and four 3-pointers as Illinois went 16 of 42 (38%) from distance. Ben Humrichous and Tomislav Ivisic each scored 14. Nakyel Shelton led Eastern Illinois with 16 points. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP collegebasketball: and

2024-11-14 - Illinois: 66 vs Oakland: 54

CHAMPAIGN, Ill. -- — Tomislav Ivisic scored 20 points, Ben Humrichous added 10 and Illinois overcame 18 turnovers to beat Oakland 66-54 on Wednesday night. Illinois has started a season 3-0 for the fourth time under Brad Underwood, and the second time in three seasons after starting the 2022-23 season 4-0. Illinois had its lead trimmed to 38-36 early in the second half before going on a 17-4 run for a 55-40 lead. Ivisic started the run, that included 11 straight points, with three made field goals. Oakland was just 2 of 10 from the field during the run. Ivisic was 9 of 14 from the field, while the rest of his teammates combined to go 14 of 41. Jayson Woodrich scored 11 points and DQ Cole added 10 for Oakland (1-2). The Grizzlies shot just 38% from the field, including 4 of 25 from 3-point range. Oakland also turned it over 18 times. Both teams play a top-five team in their next game. Oakland plays at top-ranked Kansas on Saturday. Illinois has a week off before playing at No. 2 Alabama on Nov. 20 in the C.M. Newton Classic. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2024-11-21 - Alabama: 100 vs Illinois: 87

BIRMINGHAM, Ala. -- — Grant Nelson scored 23 points and Aden Holloway had 18 to lead No. 8 Alabama to a 100-87 win over No. 25 Illinois on Wednesday night in a matchup of Elite Eight teams from last season at Legacy Arena. Freshman Labaron Philon had 16 points, nine assists and seven rebounds to help the Crimson Tide (4-1) overcome a scoreless night from preseason All-American Mark Sears. Latrell Wrightsell Jr. also had 16 points for Alabama. Nelson opened the game with three straight 3-pointers. Will Riley led Illinois (3-1) with 18 points and nine rebounds while Kylan Boswell added 17 and Kasparas Jakucionis had 15. Tomislav Ivisic had 14 points and 10 rebounds. Sears missed all five of his shots, four of them 3-point attempts, and didn't return after heading to the bench with 11:27 left. Takeaways Illinois: Fell to 17-19 in Top 25 matchups since the start of the 2019-20 season. The Illini had their first tough test of the season after three double-digit wins. Alabama: Rebounded strongly from an 87-78 loss at No. 6 Purdue to get a win that should look good on the NCAA Tournament resume. Made four straight 3s and five of six to open the game. Key moment Alabama scored 13 straight points midway through the first half to build a 36-19 lead. Clifford Omoruyi's layup capped the run while Illinois missed 11 straight shots. The Tide went up by 18 points. Illinois sliced the deficit to eight in the second half but never got closer. Key stat Alabama made 11 of 13 free throws (84.6%). Illinois was just 13 of 24 (54.2%). Up next Illinois hosts Maryland-Eastern Shore on Saturday; Alabama faces No. 7 Houston next Tuesday in Las Vegas. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 all season. Sign up here. 2024-11-26 - Illinois: 92 vs Little Rock: 34

CHAMPAIGN, Ill. -- — Freshman Kasparas Jakucionis hit three 3-pointers and scored 21 points — both season highs — and Tomislav Ivisic had his third double-double of the season to help Illinois beat Little Rock 92-34 Monday night. The 7-foot-1 Ivisic scored 16 points on 7-of-10 shooting and grabbed 11 rebounds with two steals. Louisville transfer Tre White also scored 16 points and Will Riley added 13 for Illinois (5-1). After Little Rock's Mwani Wilkinson hit a 3-pointer to open the scoring, White made a layup and then hit two free throws to give Illinois the lead for good with 18:26 left in the first half. Riley hit a 3-pointer to make it 20-10 with 12 minutes left in the first half before the Fighting Illini scored 23 consecutive points — including four 3-pointers and three dunks — to take a 30-point lead when White made a layup with 4:05 left in the first half. The Trojans went 0 for 9 from the field and committed three turnovers during a scoring drought of nearly 8 minutes and Illinois scored eight second-chance points off four offensive rebounds during that span. Jakucionis, who played point guard for Lithuniana at the 2023 FIBA U18 European Championship, scored 13 points on 3-of-4 shooting and hit 6 of 6 from the free-throw line as Illinois took a 51-19 halftime lead. Jordan Jefferson led Little Rock (3-4) with 11 points. ---- Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

Jakucionis hit two free throws to give Illinois a double-digit lead with 3:49 remaining in the game. Head coach Brad Underwood broke a tie with J. Craig Ruby (1922-36) for fifth place in program history with 149 wins. Adou Thiero went 12 of 21 from the line and scored 26 points for Arkansas (5-2). Ben Humrichous made the Illini’s fifth 3-pointer with 12:36 left in the first half while Arkansas was 3 of 9 from the field. Key stat Illinois made 55% of its shots in the first half, including 9 of 16 from 3-point range, while Arkansas was 0 for 7 from long distance and shot 44% overall. Illinois plays at Northwestern on Dec. 6 to begin Big Ten play. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2024-12-07 - Northwestern: 70 vs Illinois: 66

EVANSTON, Ill. -- — Nick Martinelli scored 27 points, including seven in overtime, and Northwestern beat No. 19 Illinois 70-66 on Friday night. Brooks Barnhizer added 17 points and Jalen Leach had 16 as the Wildcats (7-3, 1-1 Big Ten) overcame a 10-point deficit. Barnhizer's free throw with 8 seconds left in OT helped seal it. Barnhizer scored on a jumper from the paint with 41 seconds left in regulation to tie it at 56-all. Illinois led 46-36 midway through the second half. Kasparas Jakucionis led Illinois (6-2, 0-1) with 20 points and 10 rebounds, Tomislav Ivisic had 15 points and 12 rebounds, and freshman Will Riley came off the bench to score 12 points. Northwestern beat a ranked team in its conference home opener for the second straight season after stunning Zach Edey and Purdue last year. Illinois: This was a far cry from the Illini's 90-77 win over then- No. 19 Arkansas on Thanksgiving, which they started on a 21-6 run and led throughout. Key moment Jakucionis was blocked out by Northwestern center Matthew Nicholson and missed on a driving layup with 39 seconds left in OT and the Wildcats leading 67-66. CHAMPAIGN, Ill. -- — Kasparas Jakucionis scored a career-high 24 points, Tre White had 23 points and eight rebounds and Kylan Boswell added 19 points and six assists to lead Illinois to an 86-80 win over No. 20 Wisconsin on Tuesday night. It was the fourth straight game in which Jakucionis scored 20 or more points for the Illini (7-2, 1-1 Big Ten), who beat Wisconsin for the ninth consecutive time. Nolan Winter led the Badgers (8-3, 0-2) with 15 points and seven rebounds, John Tonje had 14 points, Max Klesmit scored 13 and John Blackwell had 10. The Illini fell behind 47-46 with 16:32 left in the second half before regaining the lead on a 3-pointer by Boswell. They never trailed again. It was the 150th win in Brad Underwood’s eighth year as the Illinois coach. He’s now 150-90. Takeaways Illinois: The Illini aren’t afraid to shoot 3’s, but that didn’t affect Wisconsin. 2024-12-14 - Illinois: 64 vs Tennessee: 66

CHAMPAIGN, Ill. -- — Jordan Gainey scored on a driving layup as time expired and finished with a career-high 23 points as No. 1 Tennessee extended its season-opening winning streak to 10 games, beating Illinois 66-64 on Saturday. After Illinois tied the game at 64 on the second of two free throws by Kasparas Jakucionis with 5.7 seconds left, Gainey took control. The Vols' senior guard inbounded the ball to Igor Milicic, got it back and raced three-quarters the length of the court and scored over Jakucionis as time ran out. 2024-12-22 - Missouri: 77 vs Illinois: 80

ST. LOUIS -- — Kasparas Jakucionis scored 21 points, including the go-ahead basket with 28 seconds left and Illinois defeated Missouri 80-77 on Sunday in the annual Braggin' Rights game between the nonconference rivals. Illinois held the lead for nearly 30 minutes of game time, but a late rally by Missouri took the game down to the wire. An 11-0 run, capped by Trent Pierce’s layup gave the Tigers a 68-67 lead with about 4 minutes to go. Jakucionis hit a straight-on 3-pointer for a 75-72 Illinois lead with 2 minutes remaining, but Missouri's Tamar Bates hit a wide-open 3 in transition to tie it at 75 with 1:14 to go. After the teams exchanged free throws, Jakucionis, a freshman who has six consecutive 20-point games, drove the right side of the line, stopped, pivoted and hit a turnaround jumper to put Illinois ahead 79-77 with 28 seconds left. After a miss by Missouri, Kylan Boswell made one of two free throws for a three-point lead. Jacob Crews missed a 3-pointer that could have tied it for Missouri. Boswell made 11 of 12 free throws and Jakucionis went 8 for 8 for Illinois, which was 22 of 23 from the line. Missouri made 28 free throws but shot only 76% from the line. There 43 total fouls in the game. Boswell had 16 points, nine rebounds and five assists for Illinois (8-3). Tre White scored 13 and Tomislav Ivisic had 11 points and 10 rebounds. Mark Mitchell and Tony Perkins scored 18 points each and Bates had 17 for Missouri (10-2), which saw its 10-game winning streak come to an end. CHAMPAIGN, Ill. -- — Kylan Boswell had 18 points, 10 rebounds and 10 assists and Tomislav Ivisic scored 23 points to lead No. 24 Illinois to a 117-64 victory over winless Chicago State on Sunday. Ben Humrichous shot 4 of 7 from 3-point range and scored 18 points on a night when Illinois went 16 for 29 behind the arc. Kylan Boswell also made four 3s and finished with 15 points for the Fighting Illini (10-3, 2-1 Big Ten). Kasparas Jakucionis added 16 points, six rebounds and six assists. Jake Davis scored 12. Supreme Cook scored 20 to lead the Ducks (12-2, 1-2), while Nate Bittle added 13 points and five rebounds. Illinois built a seven-point lead at halftime before opening the second half on a 22-6 run to pull away. Takeaways Illinois: Earned its first win over a ranked team this season after losing top-10 matchups against Alabama and Tennessee. Oregon: Hosted a ranked opponent for the first time since 2020, but didn’t do much to cheer up Ducks fans still disappointed after their top-ranked football team lost 41-21 to Ohio State in the Rose Bowl on Wednesday. SEATTLE -- — Kasparas Jakucionis made a tiebreaking layup with 32 seconds left, and No. 22 Illinois survived a furious comeback bid by Washington to squeak out an 81-77 victory Sunday. The Fighting Illini (11-3, 3-1 Big Ten), playing at UW for the first time since the 1952 Final Four, had a 17-point lead but the Huskies tied it at 75 on Luis Kortright's layup with 47 seconds left. Jakucionis then scored and the Illini put it away at the free throw line. Jakucionis had 18 points and six assists, while Tre White pitched in 17 points and Kylan Boswell had 14. DJ Davis led the Huskies (10-5, 1-3) with 31 points, finishing 7 for 14 from beyond the arc. Illinois held Great Osobor, Washington's leading scorer, scoreless in the first half. He finished with nine points. Takeaways Illinois: The Illini have now won eight of their past 10 games, with the two losses coming by a combined six points — one in overtime and the other to No. 1 Tennessee. Washington: The Huskies, who came into the day shooting 45% from the field — second-worst in the Big Ten — shot just 31.4% to dig their hole, and 56.7% in the second half to nearly climb out of it. Key moment Kortright’s game-tying layup capped an 8-0 run for the Huskies, before Jakucionis answered. Key stat Illinois turned the ball over nine times in the first half, but cut the giveaways down to four in the second. Up next Illinois will return to State Farm Center on Wednesday to host Penn State. Washington will travel to traditional Big Ten country for the first time this season with a two-game swing to Michigan, opening with a matchup at No. 18 Michigan State on Thursday. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. 2025-01-09 - Illinois: 91 vs Penn State: 52

CHAMPAIGN, Ill. -- — Ben Humrichous scored a season-high 21 points, Morez Johnson Jr. had a career-high 20 points along with 11 rebounds and No. 13 Illinois beat Penn State 91-52 on Wednesday night for its fifth straight victory. Tre White also had 20 points to help Illinois (12-3, 4-1 Big Ten) win with scoring leader Kasparas Jakucionis sidelined by a bruised forearm. Penn State star Ace Baldwin Jr. aggravated a back injury early in the first half and didn’t play in the second half. He didn’t score, missing all six of his shots. Nick Kern Jr. had 13 points for the Nittany Lions (12-4, 2-3). Zach Hicks added 11. Takeaways Illinois: After sweeping No. 9 Oregon and Washington on a West Coast trip, Illinois was tasked with beating nemesis Penn State without Jakucionis, whose absence was announced just before the game. Humrichous and Johnson made up for the loss of Jakucionis. Penn State: The Nittany Lions came into the night as the 10th-highest scoring team in the nation, averaging 86.8 points. They had scored a program record 80-plus points in six straight games. Penn State shot 31% against Illinois. Key moment A 21-2 Illini run in the first half gave them a 26-13 lead. Penn State missed nine straight shots during the stretch, going 7:56 without a field goal. Up next Illinois: Hosts Southern California on Saturday. Penn State: Hosts No. 9 Oregon on Sunday. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2025-01-15 - Indiana: 69 vs Illinois: 94

BLOOMINGTON, Ind. -- — Kylan Boswell scored 22 points, Kasparas Jakucionis added 21 and No. 19 Illinois opened a 28-point halftime lead Tuesday night in a 94-69 blowout of Indiana. Tomislav Ivisic had 17 points and 11 rebounds as the Fighting Illini (13-4, 5-2 Big Ten) bounced back from a double-digit loss at home to Southern California. This time, Illinois left no doubt as Jakucionis and Ivisic combined for 34 first-half points to give the Illini a 60-32 halftime lead thanks largely to their dominance inside. Indiana scored the first 10 points of the second half but never got closer than 16. Oumar Ballo led the Hoosiers (13-5, 5-4) with 16 points and 15 rebounds and was involved in a brief shoving match with 2:24 left. Luke Goode, the former Illinois 3-point specialist, added 13 points for Indiana, which fell to 11-1 at home. Indiana played without starting forward Malik Reneau. All five Hoosiers losses this season have come by 16 or more points. Takeaways Illinois: The Illini certainly appeared to learn their lesson from Saturday's loss. Their usually strong rebounding returned, and they played a nearly perfect first half offensively and defensively. When Illinois plays this way, it is one of the best teams in the nation. Indiana: For whatever reason, the Hoosiers came out flat. They lacked the energy and effort to challenge Illinois in the first half, and the result was obvious. If they don't fight harder than this, it could be a long season in Bloomington. Key moment Illinois took control with a 15-2 flurry after the first media timeout to build a 25-10 lead. Indiana never got within single digits again. Key stat Illinois outscored Indiana 24-14 in the paint and outrebounded the Hoosiers 29-16 in the first half. Up next The Illini face another road test Sunday at No. 12 Michigan State. Indiana will try to rebound Friday night at Ohio State. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2025-01-19 - Michigan State: 80 vs Illinois: 78

EAST LANSING, Mich. -- — Tre Holloman had 17 points, including two free throws in the closing seconds, Coen Carr and Frankie Fidler scored 11 each and No. 12 Michigan State held on to beat No. 19 Illinois 80-78 on Sunday. The Spartans (16-2, 7-0 Big Ten) extended their winning streak to 11 games, their longest run since the 2018-19 season that ended with Hall of Fame coach Tom Izzo's eighth trip to the Final Four. The Fighting Illini (13-5, 6-2) took a 10-point lead in the first half and were trailing by one and had possession when Kylan Boswell turned over the ball with 5.9 seconds left. Holloman made two free throws on the ensuing possession. Izzo told his players to foul Boswell instead of giving up a 3-pointer. Boswell made the first free throw and after missing the second intentionally, he got to the ball and shot it from the baseline over the backboard, and the officials waved it off. Illini star Kasparas Jakucionis was held to season lows in points (three) and minutes (nine) because of foul trouble. Fellow freshman Will Riley came off the bench to pick up the scoring slack in the first half, scoring 16 points in eight minutes and finishing with 19. Takeaways Illinois: Coach Brad Underwood's team put together an impressive performance with Jakucionis, an NBA draft lottery prospect, on the bench for most of the game. Michigan State: The hard-to-please Izzo will have to give his players credit for bouncing back from a double-digit deficit in the first half against one of the Big Ten's top teams. Key moment Illinois' bench was called for a technical foul for arguing a call with 3:18 left and Fidler made two free throws to give Michigan State a six-point lead. Key stat Jakucionis was 1 of 3, a lack of production because of foul trouble. Up next Michigan State plays at Rutgers on Saturday and Illinois hosts Maryland on Thursday night. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. 2025-01-24 - Illinois: 70 vs Maryland: 91

CHAMPAIGN, Ill. -- — Julian Reese had 27 points and 17 rebounds and Derik Queen scored 25 points to lead Maryland to a 91-70 victory over No. 17 Illinois on Thursday night. Ja’Kobi Gillespie added 15 points and Selton Miguel 14 for the Terrapins (15-5, 5-4 Big Ten), who won for the fourth time in five games, with the lone loss a buzzer-beater by Northwestern. Kasparas Jakucionis had 21 points and seven assists and Dra Gibbs-Lawhorn scored 15 points for Illinois (13-6, 5-4), which lost for the third time in four games and dropped consecutive games for the first time in two seasons. Kylan Boswell had 14 points and nine rebounds. Illinois committed 16 turnovers that led to 27 Maryland points. The Illini were without leading rebounder and No. 2 scorer 7-foot-1 Tomislav Ivisic, who was sidelined with strep throat. profile_summary: Illinois enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 6-seed with a 22-13 record — a résumé that reflects genuine talent undermined by persistent inconsistency and a brutal late-season schedule. Against ranked opponents, the Illini went 7-11: notable wins include a dominant 109-77 blowout at #9 Oregon, a come-from-behind 90-77 victory over #19 Arkansas, a clutch 80-77 Braggin' Rights win over Missouri, an 88-80 home rally past #18 Purdue, and a regular-season-closing 93-73 rout at #15 Michigan — but losses to Duke (110-67, the worst loss in program history), Michigan State twice, Wisconsin, Maryland twice, and Nebraska in overtime reveal a team that crumbles against elite competition, especially away from Champaign. Their final five games tell a story of dramatic swings: a 95-74 blowout loss at Wisconsin, a 110-67 humiliation against #3 Duke in New York, followed by three straight wins over Iowa (81-61), #15 Michigan (93-73), and #18 Purdue (88-80) in the regular season, before the Big Ten Tournament delivered a 106-94 win over Iowa and then a 88-65 dismantling at the hands of #11 Maryland — a sequence that perfectly encapsulates this team's identity: capable of looking like a top-15 program one game and collapsing catastrophically the next. Illinois plays a high-volume, high-scoring style averaging 85 points per game, ranking among the nation's leaders, and wins at their best through dominant rebounding — entering as the nation's top rebounding team with a plus-9.7 margin — and perimeter volume shooting, going deep from three at an aggressive rate even when cold, which is alarmingly often; they shot 2-of-26 from three against Duke and have failed to top 30% from distance in multiple consecutive stretches. Freshman Kasparas Jakucionis is the engine, a legitimate NBA lottery prospect who has delivered multiple 20-plus-point performances and clutch buckets — his go-ahead turnaround jumper to beat Missouri and his tiebreaking layup at Washington being prime examples — but he has also been neutralized by foul trouble at Michigan State (3 points, 9 minutes) and is far from automatic. Will Riley has emerged as a dangerous second option, scoring 22 points in the Purdue comeback and going for 27 at Minnesota; Tre White brings veteran reliability with multiple 20-point, double-digit rebound performances; Kylan Boswell provides playmaking and clutch free-throw shooting; and 7-foot-1 Tomislav Ivisic, when healthy, is a force — posting multiple double-doubles and shooting 6-of-9 from three against Arkansas — but he missed three games with mononucleosis and has played through an ankle injury and illness in recent weeks, making his health the most critical variable entering March. The Illini also lack big-game composure as a unit: they committed 17 turnovers in the Big Ten Tournament loss to Maryland (leading to a 22-0 edge in points off turnovers), coughed up 11 turnovers in the overtime loss to Northwestern, and repeatedly self-destructed in first halves against elite opponents, falling behind 36-19 against Alabama and 29-10 against Maryland in the Big Ten Tournament. At home, Illinois is dominant and difficult to beat; on the road and at neutral sites, they are a coin flip — the Oregon blowout and Michigan rout stand as elite road performances, but the Rutgers loss, Nebraska overtime loss, and the MSG catastrophe against Duke reveal a team that can completely unravel without the State Farm Center crowd behind them. Illinois carries the energy of a resilient but fragile team: they fight back — erasing 11-point deficits against Ohio State and 17-point leads blown at Washington — but they are just as capable of going flat for an entire half and never recovering, as Maryland demonstrated twice. **The realistic ceiling for this Illinois team is the Sweet 16**: Jakucionis, Riley, and the rebounding machine give them the tools to knock off a 3-seed on the right night, but their chronic three-point misfires, turnover issues, injury concerns around Ivisic, and catastrophic performances against genuinely elite opponents make a run to the Elite Eight or beyond a significant stretch.

2024-11-05 - Michigan State: 81 vs Monmouth: 57

EAST LANSING, Mich. -- — Jaden Akins scored 23 points and Michigan State pulled away in the second half to defeat Monmouth 81-57 in a season opener on Monday night. Akins also had nine rebounds and five assists. On a night when 10 Michigan State players logged at least 10 minutes on the court, Jase Richardson with 10 points was the only other Spartan in double figures. The Spartans scored the first nine points and their largest lead of the first half was 15 points on three occasions. Monmouth's first five points were at the free-throw line and the Hawks' first field goal was a 3-pointer by Abdi Bashir Jr. that made it 19-8 with about 11 minutes left in the half. Michigan State led 38-27 at the break. Monmouth scored the first five points of the second half to get within six points but Michigan State stretched its lead to 17 on back-to-back dunks by Coen Carr and Akins near the 10-minute mark. Kur Teng hit a jumper and a 3-pointer to give the Spartans their largest lead, 81-57 with about a minute remaining. Bashir led Monmouth with 20 points and Madison Durr and Justin Ray scored 12 each. Cornelius Robinson Jr. grabbed 10 rebounds. The Spartans finished sixth in the Big Ten last season but advanced to the NCAA Tournament for the 26th consecutive time, officially the longest active streak. They have seven returning letterwinners but lost four of their regular starters. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2024-11-08 - Michigan State: 96 vs Niagara: 60

LANSING, Mich. -- — Jaxon Kohler came off the bench to post career highs of 20 points and 13 rebounds and Michigan State warmed up for a meeting with top-ranked Kansas with a 96-60 victory over Niagara on Thursday night. Michigan State (2-0) takes on the Jayhawks on Tuesday at the Champions Classic in Atlanta. Kohler was 8-of-12 shooting with the junior posting his second career double-double. Jase Richardson added 12 points, Tre Holloman and Frankie Fidler 11 each and Jaden Akins 10. The Spartans shot 52% and were plus-10 on the offensive boards, dominating in the paint where they outscored Niagara 56-18. Olumide Adelodun scored 13 points, Jahari Williamson 12 and Jhaylon Martinez 10 for the Purple Eagles (1-1), who shot 38%. A Martinez 3-pointer to open the second half cut Michigan State's lead to 46-42 but then Niagara went into a 1-of-9 shooting funk and the Spartans put together an 11-0 run including five straight points from Fidler to go up by 14. profile_summary:
Michigan State enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 2-seed with an impressive 30-7 record, having won the outright Big Ten regular-season title — their first conference championship since 2020 — by three full games in an 18-team league. Against ranked opponents, the Spartans went an estimated 10-6, with marquee wins over No. 12 North Carolina (94-91 OT at Maui), No. 19 Illinois (80-78), No. 13 Purdue (75-66), No. 12 Michigan (75-62 on the road), No. 16 Maryland (58-55 on a Holloman buzzer-beater from beyond midcourt), and No. 11 Wisconsin (71-62), while losses came against No. 1 Kansas (77-69 at a neutral site), Memphis (71-63 at Maui), USC (70-64 on the road), UCLA (63-61 on the road), and Indiana (71-67 at home) — a loss/win profile that reveals a team fully capable of beating elite competition but genuinely vulnerable when taken out of its comfort zone, particularly on the road in California where they were swept. Their five final games tell a story of a team that peaked at the right time: a 91-84 comeback win at Iowa (trailing 58-48 before a 19-2 run), a dominant 79-62 home victory over No. 17 Michigan in the regular-season finale, a 74-64 quarterfinal win over No. 23 Oregon in the Big Ten Tournament, and then a narrow 77-74 semifinal loss to No. 18 Wisconsin — a defeat that snapped an eight-game winning streak but came on a disputed late foul call with Jeremy Fears Jr. nearly tying the game at the buzzer. That loss is a mild concern but not a red flag; the Spartans had already clinched their seed and may benefit from the rest.

Tom Izzo's team wins in a distinctly balanced, paint-dominant style — they score 40+ points in the paint regularly, get to the free-throw line consistently, and compensate for chronically poor 3-point shooting (hovering around 20-35% depending on the night) by pounding the interior and converting turnovers into points. Their 3-point shooting remains a genuine liability and a tournament wild card; in a loss to Kansas, they shot 3-of-24 from deep, and against Indiana they were 4-of-23. What makes this team dangerous despite that weakness is extraordinary depth — seven players averaging seven or more points, and a bench that routinely outscores opponents' reserves (23-0 bench points against Maryland, 31-13 against Michigan). Key players include senior Jaden Akins as the leading scorer, freshman Jase Richardson who has exploded down the stretch (29 points against Oregon, 22 at Iowa, 21 against Michigan in the rivalry game), Tre Holloman as a composed floor general and clutch performer (midcourt buzzer-beater at Maryland, career-high 20 in the finale), Jaxon Kohler as a reliable double-double big, and Coen Carr as an energy spark who can ignite runs with thunderous lobs and dunks. The Spartans are 12-0 since Holloman moved into the starting lineup — a telling stat that underscores how much his presence stabilizes this roster. Attitude-wise, this team is scrappy and resilient rather than dominant wire-to-wire; they trailed Oregon by 14 at halftime and still won, erased a 10-point Iowa deficit late, and survived near-collapses against Illinois and Maryland — though they have also gone flat in stretches and surrendered big first-half runs. They are unquestionably better at home (17-3 in the Breslin Center environment) and notably shaky on the road (losses at USC, UCLA, and several competitive road games decided in the final minutes), but their neutral-site Big Ten Tournament performance — back-to-back wins before losing a one-possession game to Wisconsin — suggests they can compete in March's neutral settings. With elite coaching from Hall of Famer Tom Izzo (eight prior Final Fours), tournament-hardened depth, a resilient identity, and a proven ability to beat top-25 teams, Michigan State's realistic ceiling is the **Elite Eight**, with legitimate Final Four upside if Richardson continues his late-season ascent and the 3-point

profile_summary:
Bryant enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 15-seed with a 23-12 record, but that modest seed significantly undersells what this team accomplished in conference play. The Bulldogs won the America East regular-season title outright at 14-2, then ran through the conference tournament to earn an automatic bid — the program's first AEA title since joining the league, snapping Vermont's eight-year stranglehold on the conference. However, their non-conference résumé raises legitimate red flags against higher-caliber competition: losses to St. John's (99-77), St. Bonaventure (85-70), Chattanooga (84-76), and Brown (76-75 on a buzzer-beater) reveal a team that struggles to compete with mid-major and low-major power programs outside its own league. Bryant went a combined 0-4 against those programs, with the St. John's and St. Bonaventure defeats being particularly lopsided. There are no documented wins against ranked opponents in the provided summaries, making their tournament résumé almost entirely built on America East dominance against limited competition.

Heading into the tournament, Bryant is playing its best basketball of the season. Their final five games — wins over New Hampshire (90-56), UMBC (85-74), Albany (91-78), and Maine (77-59) in the conference tournament, plus the regular-season title-clincher over New Hampshire — show a team winning comfortably and with purpose, outscoring opponents by an average of roughly 20 points across that stretch. The engine of this team is Rafael Pinzon, a relentless scorer who regularly delivers 20-30 point performances and has been the Bulldogs' most consistent option all season, posting 22, 28, 17, 22, and then tournament runs of similar output. Earl Timberlake is a legitimate double-double threat — athletic, versatile, and capable of impacting the game in multiple ways simultaneously, as evidenced by his 21-point, 9-rebound, 8-assist, 4-block line against Albany in January. Connor Withers provides floor-spacing and playmaking, and Barry Evans gives Bryant a reliable third scoring option with rebounding punch. The Bulldogs play an up-tempo, high-scoring style and can put up points in bunches, but they have also proven collapse-prone in close games — losses to Siena in overtime, Brown on a last-second three, Fordham on a buzzer-beater three, and Stonehill by one point suggest this team has a troubling habit of letting winnable games slip away. At home, Bryant is noticeably stronger, building comfortable leads and controlling pace; on the road and at neutral sites, they are more vulnerable, as demonstrated by their early-season road losses. Their conference tournament run on a neutral site is an encouraging data point, but those wins came against America East opponents who have no bearing on what awaits in the NCAA bracket. As a 15-seed, Bryant is a dangerous, high-energy team with real star power in Pinzon and Timberlake, but the lack of any quality wins, a history of late-game collapses, and non-conference blowout losses to mid-major programs make a first-round upset extremely difficult to sustain. **Realistic tournament ceiling: First-round exit** — Bryant is a lively 15-seed that could keep a game close in the first half, but they do not have the defensive discipline, consistent depth, or proven big-game composure to pull off an upset against a high-major 2-seed.

name: Oregon
summaries:
2024-11-05 - Oregon: 91 vs UC Riverside: 76

EUGENE, Ore. -- — Kwame Evans Jr. scored 23 points and Nate Bittle added 16 points and 11 rebounds Monday night to help Oregon beat UC Riverside 91-76 in the season opener for both teams. Stanford transfer Brandon Angel had 17 points and TJ Bamba, who started at Washington State before playing last season at Villanova, scored 12 and grabbed seven rebounds for Oregon. Bamba hit a jumper and Angel converted a three-point play that gave the Ducks the lead for good. Jackson Sheldstad hit a 3-pointer and Bamba stole a pass and went the other way for a layup to cap a 10-0 spurt that made it 36-28 with 5:55 to play in the first half. Barrington Hargress, last season’s Big West freshman of the year, led UC Riverside with 20 points. Kaleb Smith added 14, Isaiah Moses scored 13 points with seven assists and Nate Bittle had 11 points. Moses hit a jumper that trimmed the UC Riverside deficit to seven points with 6:14 to play but Angel made 4 of 4 from the free-throw line and added a layup in an 8-0 spurt over the next 2 minutes and the Ducks led by double figures the rest of the way. Oregon shot 50% (33 of 66) from the field and made seven more free throws (19) than the Highlanders attempted. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. 2024-11-09 - Oregon: 79 vs Montana: 48

EUGENE, Ore. -- — Nate Bittle scored 17 points and grabbed nine rebounds and Oregon dominated the first half on the way to a 79-48 victory over Montana on Friday night. The Ducks took control early in the first half as their 15-0 run lasted eight minutes and produced a 22-7 lead. They also had a 9-0 run later in the half and led 40-22 at halftime. Oregon had a 9-0 run and held the Grizzlies without a field goal for a 5-minute stretch in the second half, building a 31-point lead with 5 minutes remaining. The only other time the lead was 30 or more came when Jamari Phillips hit a 3-pointer for the final margin. Joe Pridgen had 14 points and nine rebounds for the Grizzlies (1-1). TJ Bamba had 14 points and Jadrian Tracey added 12 off the bench for the Ducks (2-0). Montana shot 34% for the game and had only four assists, but the Grizzlies were outscored by only seven points in the second half. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2024-11-13 - Oregon: 80 vs Portland: 70

EUGENE, Ore. -- — Jadrian Tracey scored 19 points and Oregon scored the first 11 points in overtime to pull out an 80-70 win over Portland after erasing a 13-point second-half deficit on Tuesday night. The Ducks were down 54-41 with eight minutes to go and they were still in an 11-point hole with 4:46 to play. Tracey made a layup and then Keeshawn Barthelemy hit back-to-back 3-pointers to get back into the game, trailing 60-57 with three minutes left. Chris Austin made a pair of free throws to give Portland a 67-62 lead with 35.6 seconds left but Barthelemy knocked down a quick 3. The Pilots then missed two free throws and after getting a defensive rebound threw the ball away in the key. Barthelemy came up with the loose ball and found Tracey for the tying layup with 10.7 seconds left. Oregon's momentum carried into overtime with Tracey scoring the first three points and contributing a dunk. That was the first lead for the Ducks since the 8:19 mark of the first half. After Austin's layup with 1:52 left in regulation put the Pilots up 65-59 they missed six shots until Austin's three-point play with 35.7 seconds to go in overtime. They also had three turnovers. Jackson Shelstad, Nate Bittle and Barthelemy all had 13 points for Oregon (3-0). TJ Bamba added 10. Shelstad also had 10 rebounds. Vukasin Masic and Vincent Delano both had 12 points to lead the Pilots (1-2), who lost by 41 at home to UC Santa Barbara in their previous game. Austin had 11 points and Todd Jones 10 with 10 rebounds. The Pilots had a 12-3 run starting in the middle of the first half to open a 23-17 lead and went into halftime on top 31-23. Portland shot 43% and the Ducks just 27%. In the second half Oregon shot 53% but was just 3 of 11 on 3-pointers, finishing 7 of 31 (23%) behind the arc. Portland only shot 37% in the second half but made 6 of 12 on 3-pointers. Missing five 3s in overtime, the Pilots finished 11 of 31. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2024-11-17 - Oregon: 82 vs Troy: 61

EUGENE, Ore. -- — Keeshawn Barthelemy scored 15 points to lead a balanced attack and Oregon cruised to an 82-61 victory over Troy on Sunday. Barthelemy made 4 of 6 shots with three 3-pointers and all four of his free throws for the Ducks (4-0). TJ Bamba had 13 points and Nate Bittle scored 12 with eight rebounds and three blocked shots for Oregon. Supreme Cook added 11 points off the bench on 4-for-5 shooting. Brandon Angel scored 10. Myles Rigsby scored 15 on 6-for-12 shooting before fouling out for the Trojans (2-2). Troy shot 12% from 3-point range, missing 22 of 25 attempts. Oregon scored the first eight points and led 12-1 on a tip-in by Bittle. Bamba's layup off a Troy turnover upped the Ducks advantage to 21-6 with 9:50 left before halftime. Thomas Dowd's layup cut the Trojans' deficit to single digits at 26-17 at the 5-minute mark. But Barthelemy answered with two 3-pointers and two free throws in a 12-2 run for a 38-19 lead. Rigsby followed two foul shots with a dunk to get Troy within 15 at halftime. Bamba opened the second half with a 3-pointer and Jadrian Tracey had a fastbreak layup to up the Ducks' lead to 20 three minutes in and they were never threatened from there. Oregon shot 52% from the floor, made 7 of 22 from beyond the arc and 17 of 19 at the foul line. Troy shot 37% from the floor and hit 8 of 10 foul shots. Oregon travels to play Oregon State on Thursday. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2024-11-22 - Oregon State: 75 vs Oregon: 78

CORVALLIS, Ore. -- — Nate Biddle scored 17 of his career-high 23 points in the second half and grabbed a career-best 14 rebounds as Oregon rallied to defeat its rival Oregon State 78-75 on Thursday night. Jackson Shelstad added 15 points for the Ducks, including a 3-pointer that gave them the lead for good at 74-73 with 2:43 to go and a difficult, contested layup for a 76-73 edge with 29.5 seconds left. Parsa Fallah hit two free throws for the Beavers and Jadrian Tracey made two for the Ducks with 14 seconds to go, but a final 3-pointer by Oregon State's Michael Rataj with seconds remaining was off the mark. It was the Duck's seventh straight win in the country's most-played rivalry and fourth straight at OSU by three points or less. Damarco Minor hit a 3-pointer with 11:49 to put OSU on top 61-49. The Ducks then had a 10-2 run to close within 63-59 before Minor hit another 3 for a 66-59 lead with 8 1/2 minutes to go. Shelstad had a pair of 3s, the second ending a 10-0 run for a 69-66 Oregon lead, the Ducks' first since 5-4. Tracey and Keeshawn Barthelemy both added 10 points for Oregon (5-0). Rataj had 20 points and 10 rebounds for the Beavers (4-1). Liutauras Lelevicius had 13 points, all in the first half, and Fallah added 11. Rataj had 15 points and Lelevicius 13 at the half was the Beavers took a 47-37 lead. The final play was fitting for the first half as Minor came up with a steal but missed a layup with Matthew Marsh getting enough finger on the ball to tip it in as time ran out. That gave OSU an 11-0 difference on second-chance points. But after shooting 49% in the first half the Beavers shot 28% in the second with nine of their 10 turnovers. Oregon State had 11 second-chance points to none for Oregon. The Beavers went 7 of 8 from the line, Oregon didn't get there. Oregon shot 50% in the second half and only had three turnovers. Oregon State heads to North Texas for a Monday game, the only game away from home in the first 10 games. Oregon plays Texas A&M on Tuesday in Las Vegas. ------ Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. Sign up here. AP college basketball: and

2024-11-26 - Oregon: 80 vs Texas A&M: 70

profile_summary:
Oregon enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 5-seed with a 25-10 record, a résumé built on genuine early-season excellence that was tested — and occasionally cracked — by the demands of Big Ten play. The Ducks started 13-1 and cracked the top 10, logging impressive wins over then-ranked Alabama (83-81 on a Nate Bittle putback dunk with 4.4 seconds left), Texas A&M (80-70), and San Diego State (78-68) in neutral-site tournament play. Against ranked opponents, Oregon went roughly 5-8 on the season, with quality victories over Alabama, Texas A&M, Wisconsin (77-73 in OT), and Ohio State (73-71 on the road), but also suffered blowout losses to Illinois (109-77 at home), Michigan State (86-74), and UCLA twice, including a humiliating 78-52 road demolition. The Ducks hit a brutal mid-February skid, losing five straight for the first time since 2013-14, before reeling off eight consecutive wins to close the year. Their final five games tell an encouraging story: a 75-57 home win over Rutgers, an 80-78 road escape at Iowa on Bittle's clutch late block, a 77-73 overtime road win at No. 11 Wisconsin on a Shelstad desperation three, an 82-61 home blowout of USC, and a 73-64 home win over Indiana, capped by two solid Big Ten Tournament showings — a 72-59 win over Indiana and a competitive 74-64 loss to No. 7 Michigan State in which Oregon cut the deficit to one before the Spartans used a 15-0 run to pull away.

Oregon's identity is rooted in resilience and depth rather than dominance, with multiple players capable of taking over on any given night — though that same collective approach occasionally produces troubling offensive droughts. Jackson Shelstad is the engine, averaging big numbers down the stretch and delivering in clutch moments, including a 26-point career-high against Northwestern to snap the losing streak and back-to-back game-deciding free throws at Ohio State. Nate Bittle is a legitimate two-way force — his 36-point, 12-rebound regular-season finale at Washington and five-block performance against Rutgers project as genuine tournament-level production — and his ability to alter shots and command the paint gives Oregon a defensive anchor few 5-seeds can match. TJ Bamba provides scoring punch from multiple areas, Keeshawn Barthelemy is a dangerous microwave scorer off the bench, and Brandon Angel offers versatile wing play, giving Dana Altman genuine eight-man rotation depth. However, this team is strikingly split by location: Oregon went 8-0 on true road games and 4-0 on neutral courts, while going just 13-8 at home, suggesting the neutral-site tournament environment actually suits them well. The recurring concern is their vulnerability to elite interior pressure and perimeter shooting — Illinois torched them for 55% on threes, and UCLA buried 12-of-23 in a sweep — and their 3-point shooting has been wildly inconsistent, going 4-of-23 in the UCLA blowout. Still, a team that closes the year with eight straight wins, beats a top-10 Wisconsin squad on the road in overtime, and nearly hangs with a potential No. 1 seed Michigan State team in the Big Ten Tournament is a genuine threat. **Oregon's realistic tournament ceiling is the Sweet 16**: athletic, deep, and battle-tested enough to knock off a 4-seed in the second round, but their defensive lapses against elite perimeter shooting and inability to sustain leads against top-10 opponents make a run to the Elite Eight a stretch.

profile_summary:
Liberty enters the 2025 NCAA Tournament as a 12-seed with an impressive 28-7 record, having won the Conference USA regular season title and tournament championship — a résumé that reflects genuine mid-major excellence, though questions about performance against elite competition linger. The Flames' most notable quality win came early in the season at the Paradise Jam, where they knocked off Kansas State 67-65 on a Colin Porter 3-pointer with 2:31 remaining — a legitimate statement win over a Power conference opponent. Their losses are a mixed bag: tight defeats to Florida Atlantic (in overtime), Western Kentucky (on a buzzer-beating 3), UTEP (on a last-second jumper), and Louisiana Tech reveal a team that is regularly competitive but prone to late-game collapses in close games, often losing on the final possession rather than being dominated. Entering the tournament, Liberty's last five games have been outstanding — wins over Middle Tennessee (86-81), Western Kentucky (90-61), UTEP (81-60 in the C-USA quarterfinals), Kennesaw State (81-79 in the semis), and Jacksonville State (79-67 in the C-USA title game) represent their best sustained stretch of the season and confirm genuine momentum. The Conference USA tournament run was particularly telling: they rallied from a nine-point halftime deficit against Kennesaw State on the strength of Kaden Metheny's 16 second-half points, demonstrating both resilience and the star-power needed for tournament runs.

Liberty's identity is built around a deep, multi-threat offense with no shortage of capable scorers. Taelon Peter is playing at an elite level — his 33-point outing at Middle Tennessee (11-of-14 from the field) was the most impressive individual performance of the season and signals he is peaking at the right time. Metheny is a reliable engine, capable of exploding from three (7-of-13 in the C-USA semis), and Zach Cleveland functions as a steady, high-IQ playmaker who also contributed 19 points and six assists against UTEP in the tournament. Owen Aquino provides rebounding and interior presence, while Colin Porter and Jay Maughmer offer serviceable depth. Crucially, Liberty is a team that plays better at home (dominant in Lynchburg) and on neutral sites — their 7-1 record at neutral sites, including the Paradise Jam championship and the full C-USA tournament run, is genuinely encouraging for an NCAA tournament setting. However, they are 2-4 in true road games, and their tendency to lose tight games on the final possession raises legitimate concerns about execution under pressure against higher-caliber defenses. This is a dangerous, well-constructed mid-major with real offensive firepower and tournament experience, but their inability to beat ranked or upper-echelon opponents consistently caps their ceiling. **Realistic tournament verdict: Liberty is a prototypical dangerous 12-seed capable of pulling off a first-round upset, but is unlikely to advance past the Sweet 16 — a second-round exit is the most probable outcome.**
